opening_line: You know that something is coming. Something—a specific, dire, and awful something—will happen. You envision it, you push it away. It rolls slowly, inexorably, back into your mind. You make what preparation you can. Or you think you do, though your bones know the truth—there isn’t any way to sidestep, accommodate, lessen the impact. It will come, and you will be helpless before it. You know these things. And yet, somehow, you never think it will be today.

Troops went by the house and down the road and the dust they raised powdered the leaves of the trees. The trunks of the trees too were dusty and the leaves fell early that year and we saw the troops marching along the road and the dust rising and leaves, stirred by the breeze, falling and the soldiers marching and afterward the road bare and white except for the leaves.

Three times the mail had come with undesired letters and circulars to look through. I had done my breathing exercises, but found it convenient today to omit the thought exercises. I had been for an hour’s walk and seen the loveliest feathery cloud patterns penciled against the sky. That was very delightful. So was the reading of old books. So was the lying in the warm bath.

author: Dan Wakefield
title: Returning
opening_line: One balmy spring morning in Hollywood, a month or so before my forty-eighth birthday, I woke up screaming. I got out of bed, went into the next room, sat down on a couch, and screamed again.

author: Lew Wallace
title: Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ
opening_line: The Jebel es Zubleh is a mountain fifty miles and more in length, and so narrow that its tracery on the map gives it a likeness to a caterpillar crawling from the south to the north.

author: David Waltner-Toews
title: One Animal Among Many
opening_line: According to some commentators on the Jewish Talmud, God tried creation twenty-six times before this one. All of the early attempts failed. “Let’s hope it works this time,” said the Creator, sending us on our strange, beautiful—and uncertain—journey.

author: Rick Warren
title: The Purpose Driven Life
opening_line: It’s not about you.

author: Alan Watts
title: The Wisdom of Insecurity
opening_line: By all outward appearances our life is a spark of light between one eternal darkness and another.

author: Alan Watts
title: The Way of Zen
opening_line: Zen Buddhism is a way and a view of life which does not belong to any of the formal categories of modern Western thought. It is not religion or philosophy; it is not a psychology or a type of science. It is an example of what is known in India and China as a “way of liberation.”

author: Edith Wharton
title: Hudson River Bracketed
opening_line: By the time he was nineteen Vance Weston had graduated from the College of Euphoria, Illinois, where his parents then lived, had spent a week in Chicago, invented a new religion, and edited for a few months a college magazine called “Getting There,” to which he had contributed several love poems and a series of iconoclastic essays.

author: Ken Wilber
title: No Boundary
opening_line: Suddenly, without any warning, at any place or time, with no apparent cause, it can happen.

author: Ken Wilber
title: Sex, Ecology, Spirituality
opening_line: It is flat-out strange that something—that anything—is happening. There was nothing, then a Big Bang, then here we all are. This is extremely weird.

author: Ken Wilber
title: A Theory of Everything
opening_line: We live in an extraordinary time: all of the world’s cultures, past and present, are to some degree available to us, either in historical records or as living entities. In the history of the planet Earth, this has never happened before.

author: Robert S. Wistrich
title: A Lethal Obsession
opening_line: Future historians may well regard the past seven decades as a golden age of ideological politics.

author: Eric Zorn
title: The Chicago Tribune
opening_line: Straight from the mouth of Jesus come words that ought to appear, at least paraphrased, in 10-inch-high letters at the front of every public and private school classroom in America: “As you wish that men would do to you, do so to them.“

author: Mortimer J. Adler
title: The Saturday Review of Literature
opening_line: You know you have to read “between the lines” to get the most out of anything. I want to persuade you to do something equally important in the course of your reading. I want to persuade you to “write between the lines.” Unless you do, you are not likely to do the most efficient kind of reading.

author: Felipe Alfau
title: Chromos
opening_line: The moment one learns English, complications set in.

author: Isabel Allende
title: The Sum of Our Days
opening_line: There is no lack of drama in my life. I have more than enough three-ring-circus material for writing, but even so, I always approach the seventh of January with trembling. Last night I couldn’t sleep.

author: Isaac Asimov
title: Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction
opening_line: I have written three hundred ninety-nine essays for Fantasy & Science Fiction. The essays were written with enormous pleasure, for I have always been allowed to say what I wanted to say. It was with horror that I discovered I could not manage a four hundredth essay.

author: Isaac Asimov
title: I, Asimov
opening_line: In 1977, I wrote my autobiography. Since I was dealing with my favorite subject, I wrote at length and I ended with 640,000 words.

author: W. H. Auden
title: Introduction
opening_line: What every author hopes to receive from posterity—a hope usually disappointed—is justice.

author: W. H. Auden
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: I never enjoy having to find fault with a book, and when the author is someone I have met and like, I hate it.

author: W. H. Auden
title: Forewords and Afterwards
opening_line: So far as I know, Goethe was the first writer or artist to become a Public Celebrity.

author: W. H. Auden
title: Forewords and Afterwards
opening_line: Probably, more nonsense has been talked and written, more intellectual and emotional energy expended in vain, on the sonnets of Shakespeare than on any other literary work in the world.

author: W. H. Auden
title: Forewords and Afterwards
opening_line: The mating of minds is, surely, quite as fascinating a relationship as the mating of the sexes, yet how little attention novelists have paid to it.

author: Paul Auster
title: Burning Boy
opening_line: Born on the Day of the Dead and dead five months before his twenty-ninth birthday, Stephen Crane lived five months and five days into the twentieth century, undone by tuberculosis before he had a chance to drive an automobile or see an airplane, to watch a film projected on a large screen or listen to a radio, a figure from the horse-and-buggy world who missed out on the future that was awaiting his peers, not just the construction of those miraculous machines and inventions but the horrors of the age as well, including the destruction of tens of millions of lives in two wars.

author: James Baldwin
title: Notes of a Native Son
opening_line: I was born in Harlem thirty-one years ago. I began plotting novels at about the time I learned to read.

author: Dave Barry
title: Dave Barry Talks Back
opening_line: I am always getting letters from people who want my job. “Dave,” they start out. They always call me Dave. “Dave,” they say, “I want your job, because my current job requires me to be a responsible person doing productive work, whereas your job requires you mainly to think up booger jokes.

author: Greg Bellow
title: Saul Bellow’s Heart
opening_line: On a visit to Chicago when I was eight, I witnessed a terrible argument, in Yiddish, between my father and grandfather. Driving away from his father’s house, Saul started to cry so bitterly he had to pull off the road. After a few minutes, he excused his lapse of self-control by saying, “It’s okay for grown-ups to cry.“ I knew his heart was breaking. I knew because of the bond between my father’s tender heart and mine.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: Write It Right
opening_line: The author’s main purpose in this book is to teach precision in writing; and of good writing (which, essentially, is clear thinking made visible) precision is the point of capital concern.

author: Sven Birkets
title: Los Angeles Review of Books
opening_line: Teaching writing, unlike most other kinds of teaching, is an intervention, closer to therapy than to any transmissible instruction.

author: Erin Blakemore
title: The Heroine’s Bookshelf
opening_line: In times of struggle, there are as many reasons not to read as there are to breathe. Don’t you have better things to do? Reading, let alone rereading, is the terrain of milquetoasts and mopey spinsters. At life’s ugliest junctures, the very act of opening a book can smack of cowardly escapism. Who chooses to read when there’s work to be done?

author: Lawrence Block
title: The Crime of Our Lives
opening_line: It was in the eleventh grade that I knew I would be a writer. The conviction grew out of two awarenesses that dawned at about the same time.

author: Roy Blount, Jr.
title: The New York Times
opening_line: A feeling seems to have arisen that summer is the time for light reading. I don’t know where anyone got that idea.

author: Camille Bordas
title: The Material
opening_line: On Wednesdays, three of them had to perform, in turn, a four-to-six-minute routine that the whole class then proceeded to rip apart, joke by joke, beat by beat, until there wasn’t anything left and the budding comedians went home to consider other possible career paths.

author: Anita Brookner
title: The Debut
opening_line: Dr. Weiss, at forty, knew that her life had been ruined by literature.

author: Geraldine Brooks
title: March
opening_line: This is what I write to her: The clouds tonight embossed the sky. A dipping sun gilded and brazed each raveling edge as if the firmament were threaded through with precious filaments. I pause there to mop my aching eye, which will not stop tearing. The line I have set down is, perhaps, on the florid side of fine, but no matter: she is a gentle critic.

author: Rita Mae Brown
title: High Hearts
opening_line: “Girl, my fingernails could grow an inch just waiting for you.“ Di-Peachy leaned in the doorway to Geneva’s bedroom.

author: Rita Mae Brown
title: Starting From Scratch
opening_line: Writers will happen in the best of families. No one is quite sure why.

author: Rita Mae Brown
title: Rita Will
opening_line: My mother was mucking stalls at Hanover Shoe Farm outside of Hanover, Pennsylvania, within a shout of the Mason-Dixon line, when her water broke. Had the hospital not been nearby, I would have been born in a manger.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The Beauty of Dusk
opening_line: They say that death comes like a thief in the night. Lesser vandals have the same MO. The affliction that stole my vision, or at least a big chuck of it, did so as I slept. I went to bed seeing the world one way. I woke up seeing it another.

author: Bill Bryson
title: The Mother Tongue
opening_line: More than 300 million people in the world speak English and the rest, it sometimes seems, try to. It would be charitable to say the results are sometimes mixed.

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Losing Mum and Pup: A Memoir
opening_line: I’m not sure how this book will turn out. I mostly write novels, and I’ve found, having written half a dozen, that if you’re lucky, the ending turns out a surprise and you wind up with something you hadn’t anticipated in the outline. I suppose it’s a process of outsmarting yourself (not especially hard in my case).

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Has Anyone Seen My Toes?
opening_line: He shuffles to the bathroom scale and steps onto it with the enthusiasm of a man mounting the gallows.

author: Anthony Burgess
title: Earthly Powers
opening_line: It was the afternoon of my eighty-first birthday, and I was in bed with my catamite when Ali announced that the archbishop had come to see me.

author: Angela Carter
title: Expletives Deleted: Selected Writing
opening_line: I am known in my circle as notoriously foul-mouthed. It’s a familiar paradox—the soft-spoken, middle-aged English gentlewoman who swears like a trooper when roused.

author: Casey Cep
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Killing children is generally frowned upon, but Edward Gorey did it all the time.

author: Michael Chabon
title: Wonder Boys
opening_line: The first real writer I ever knew was a man who did all of his work under the name of August Van Zorn.

author: Lan Samantha Chang
title: All is Forgotten, Nothing Is Lost
opening_line: Miranda Sturgis was an exceptional poet. Among the School’s distinguished faculty, she was the brightest star, and graduate students fought to gain admission to her seminars.

author: Agatha Christie
title: Agatha Christie
opening_line: One of the luckiest things that can happen to you in life is, I think, to have a happy childhood. I had a very happy childhood.

author: Jenny Colgan
title: The Bookshop on the Corner
opening_line: The problem with good things that happen is that very often they disguise themselves as awful things.

author: Blayney Colmore
title: God Knows
opening_line: From what source, one might wonder, would anyone gain the energy to write a book? Or the narcissism to think anyone would want to read it? It beats therapy.

author: Pat Conroy
title: A Lowcountry Heart: Reflections on a Writing Life
opening_line: March 26, 2014 I’ve come to that point in my life when my memories seem as important as the life I’m now leading.

author: Maureen Corrigan
title: Leave Me Alone, I’m Reading
opening_line: It’s not that I don’t like people. It’s just that when I’m in the company of others—even my nearest and dearest—there always comes a moment when I’d rather be reading a book.

author: Harry Crews
title: A Childhood
opening_line: My first memory is of a time ten years before I was born, and the memory takes place where I have never been and involves my daddy whom I never knew.

author: Nina de Gramont
title: The Christie Affair
opening_line: A long time ago in another country, I nearly killed a man.

author: William Deresiewicz
title: A Jane Austen Education
opening_line: I was twenty-six, and about as dumb, in all human things, as any twenty-six-year-old has a right to be, when I met the woman who would change my life. That she’d been dead for a couple of hundred years made not the slightest difference whatsoever.

author: Denis Diderot
title: Rameau’s Nephew
opening_line: Come rain or shine, my custom is to go for a stroll in the Palais-Royal every afternoon about five. I am always to be seen there alone, sitting on a seat in the Allée d’Argenson, meditating.

author: Joan Didion
title: The White Album
opening_line: We tell ourselves stories in order to live.

author: Annie Dillard
title: The Writing Life
opening_line: When you write, you lay out a line of words. The line of words is a miner’s pick, a woodcarver’s gouge, a surgeon’s probe. You wield it, and it digs a path you follow.

author: Michael Dirda
title: An Open Book
opening_line: Daydreaming is my only hobby.

author: Michael Dirda
title: Classics for Pleasure
opening_line: Classics for pleasure? To some readers this may seem an oxymoron. Aren’t classics supposed to be difficult, esoteric, and a little boring? Yes, teachers and critics claim they’re good for you, but so are milk of magnesia and cod-liver oil. Really, after a hard day’s work, who wants to settle down for more…work? A fast-moving thriller or a steamy romance—those sound more like it.

author: Maggie Doherty
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Elizabeth Hardwick was a master of the opening sentence. Few writers have the guts to begin so boldly—or with so many adjectives.

author: Mark Doty
title: Granta
opening_line: Only a sentence, casually placed as a footnote in the back of Justin Kaplan’s thick 2003 biography of Walt Whitman, but it goes off like a little explosion: “Bram Stoker based the character of Dracula on Walt Whitman….”

author: Daphne du Maurier
title: Myself When Young
opening_line: All autobiography is self-indulgent.

author: Dominick Dunne
title: Justice
opening_line: I didn’t start writing until I was fifty years old although an observer’s eye had been observing for forty of those fifty years, while trying out different areas of occupation.

author: Jacqueline Faber
title: Writer’s Digest
opening_line: If the salesperson’s edict is to “always be closing,” the writer’s first mandate is to nail the opening. When it works, it feels like alchemy. Inevitable, a product that is more than the sum of its parts. When it doesn’t, we feel it as a creeping sense of distrust in the authorial prime mover who ushers us along.

author: Anne Fadiman
title: The Wine Lover’s Daughter
opening_line: My father was a lousy driver and a two-finger typist, but he could open a wine bottle as deftly as any swain ever undressed his lover.

author: Lucien Febvre
title: A New Kind of History
opening_line: It is never a waste of time to study the history of a word. Such journeys, whether short or long, monotonous or varied, are always instructive.

author: Jules Feiffer
title: The Great Comic Book Heroes
opening_line: Comic books, World War II, the Depression, and I all got going at roughly the same time. I was eight.

author: Edna Ferber
title: A Peculiar Treasure
opening_line: When I was a small girl living in Appleton, Wisconsin, I often was sent with a quart tin pail to the creamery which was three blocks away on the wrong side of the railroad tracks. The Ferber family, I hastily and grandly add, lived on the right side of the tracks. Any native Middle West American will get the social significance (and the revolting snobbery) of that statement.

author: Edna Ferber
title: A Kind of Magic
opening_line: To be alive is a fine thing. It is the finest thing in the world, though hazardous.

author: Jasper Fforde
title: The Eyre Affair
opening_line: My father had a face that could stop a clock.

author: John Ficara
title: The Washington Post
opening_line: The English language has something to confuse or annoy just about anyone—the mysteries of who and whom usage, the e.g. vs. i.e. standoff, the polarizing Oxford comma. I have a long-standing, personal problem with heteronyms—words that are spelled the same but don’t sound alike. Allow me to explain with a little story.

author: Judith Flanders
title: The Invention of Murder
opening_line: “Pleasant it is, no doubt, to drink tea with your sweetheart, but most disagreeable to find her bubbling in the tea-urn.“ So wrote Thomas de Quincy in 1826, and indeed, it is hard to argue with him.

author: Mark Forsyth
title: The Elements of Eloquence
opening_line: Shakespeare was not a genius. He was, without the distant shadow of a doubt, the most wonderful writer who ever breathed. But not a genius. No angels handed him his lines, no fairies proofread for him. Instead, he learnt techniques, he learnt tricks, and he learnt them well.

author: Gene Fowler
title: Skyline
opening_line: The building of castles in the air made architects of us all.

author: Karen Joy Fowler
title: The Jane Austen Book Club
opening_line: Each of us has a private Austen.

author: Kinky Friedman
title: ’Scuse Me While I Whip This Out
opening_line: If Carl Sandburg had come from Waco, his name would have been Billy Joe Shaver.

author: Kinky Friedman
title: The New York Times
opening_line: There is a fine line between fiction and nonfiction, and I believe Jimmy Buffett and I snorted it in 1976.

author: Kinky Friedman
title: Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die
opening_line: In April 1933, Willie’s mother, Myrle, gave birth to him in a manger somewhere along the old highway between Waco and Dallas.

author: Paul Gallico
title: The Silent Miaow
opening_line: When I was a very young kitten, I had the misfortune to lose my mother and find myself alone in the world at age six weeks. However, I was not unduly disturbed by this since I was intelligent, not ill favored, resourceful and full of confidence in myself. Also I had had the advantage of several weeks of instruction from my mother before her unfortunate encounter with a motorcar at night.

author: Dwight Garner
title: The New York Times
opening_line: It must have been a gas, to borrow one of his favorite terms, to get a letter from Terry Southern. Each was its own little acid trip, streaked with innuendo and poached in a satirical kind of intellectual flop sweat. He used thin, expensive paper and sealed some of his letters with wax. People were said to read them aloud to whoever was in the room.

author: Dwight Garner
title: The New York Times
opening_line: Sheila Heti’s new novel, Pure Colour, is about a young woman who turns into a leaf. “Unrequited love’s a bore,” Billie Holiday sang. So, it turns out, is photosynthesis.

author: James Geary
title: The World in a Phrase
opening_line: If not for an aphorism by W. H. Auden, I might never have met my wife.

author: James Geary
title: Geary’s Guide to the World’s Great Aphorists
opening_line: When I lost my job, an aphorism by Vilhelm Ekelund was the first thing that popped into my mind.

author: James Geary
title: I is an Other
opening_line: In later life, Arthur Rimbaud was an anarchist, businessman, arms dealer, financier, and explorer. But as a teenager, all he wanted to be was a poet.

author: David Gerrold
title: Worlds of Wonder
opening_line: The very best writing instructor I ever had was an incompetent. A terminal alcoholic who could barely find the classroom each day, he was a bleary-eyed, red-nosed, overstuffed, walking elbow-wrinkle of a human being. Whatever writing ability he’d ever had, he’d long since drowned it, and the corpse was a layer of dried sediment at the bottom of a bottle. He didn’t like me either.

author: Richard Goodman
title: The Writer’s Chronicle
opening_line: The beginning of your story, essay, or novel carries more weight than any other part of your work. This is simply because it is the beginning.

author: Richard Goodman
title: The Writer’s Chronicle
opening_line: Henry James the novelist largely overshadows Henry James the literary critic. In many ways, though, the critic is more appealing, and certainly more accessible, than the novelist.

author: Doris Kearns Goodwin
title: Leadership in Turbulent Times
opening_line: Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson—the lives and times of these four men have occupied me for half a century. I have awakened with them in the morning and thought about them when I went to bed at night.

author: John Green
title: Looking for Alaska
opening_line: The week before I left my family and Florida and the rest of my minor life to go to boarding school in Alabama, my mother insisted on throwing me a going-away party. To say that I had low expectations would be to underestimate the matter dramatically.

author: Graham Greene
title: The End of the Affair
opening_line: A story has no beginning or end: arbitrarily one chooses that moment of experience from which to look back or from which, to look ahead.

author: Kristin Hannah
title: The Four Winds
opening_line: Elsa Wolcott had spent years in enforced solitude, reading fictional adventures and imagining other lives. In her lonely bedroom, surrounded by the novels that had become her friends, she sometimes dared to dream of an adventure of her own, but not often. Her family repeatedly told her that it was the illness she’d survived in childhood that had transformed her life and left it fragile and solitary, and on good days, she believed it.

author: Don Hauptman
title: Cruel and Unusual Puns
opening_line: Have you heard about the inner-city video game called Super Barrio Mothers? The musical version of The Ten Commandments, to be titled Runelight and Moses? Or that new self-help book on postpartum depression, The Blues of the Birth?

author: Kirk Hazen
title: TheConversation.com
opening_line: What in tarnation is “tarnation?” Why do people in old books exclaim “zounds!” in moments of surprise? And what could a professor of linguistics possibly have against “duck-loving crickets?”

author: Emily Henry
title: Beach Read
opening_line: I have a fatal flaw.

author: Emily Henry
title: Book Lovers
opening_line: When books are your life—or in my case, your job—you get pretty good at guessing where a story is going.

author: O. Henry
title: The Four Million
opening_line: It was a day in March. Never, never begin a story this way when you write one. No opening could possibly be worse. It is unimaginative, flat, dry and likely to consist of mere wind. But in this instance it is allowable.

author: O. Henry
title: The Voice of the City
opening_line: There are a few editor men with whom I am privileged to come in contact. It has not been long since it was their habit to come in contact with me. There is a difference.

author: Joanna Hines [now writing as Joanna Hodgkin]
title: The Murder Bird
opening_line: Five weeks before Kirsten Waller’s body was found in a clifftop cottage in Cornwall, Grace Hobden cleared away the lunch, checked to make sure her three children were playing on the climbing frame at the bottom of the garden, then went indoors to murder her husband.

author: Richard Hofstadter
title: The Paranoid Style in American Politics
opening_line: The most difficult and delicate task that faces the author of a book of essays is that of writing an Introduction that makes his various pieces seem considerably more unified, in theme and argument, than they were in fact when they were written.

author: Helen Hudson
title: Criminal Trespass
opening_line: A public library, like a railway station, gets all kinds.

author: Langston Hughes
title: The New York Times
opening_line: I think that one definition of the great artist might be the creator who projects the biggest dream in terms of the least person.

author: John Irving
title: In One Person
opening_line: I’m going to begin by telling you about Miss Frost. While I say to everyone that I became a writer because I read a certain novel by Charles Dickens at the formative age of fifteen, the truth is I was younger than that when I first met Miss Frost and imagined having sex with her, and this moment of my sexual awakening also marked the fitful birth of my imagination.

author: Walter Isaacson
title: American Sketches
opening_line: I was once asked to contribute an essay to the Washington Post for a page called “The Writing Life”. This caused me some consternation.

author: Lily King
title: Writers and Lovers
opening_line: I have a pact with myself not to think about money in the morning. I’m like a teenager trying not to think about sex. Or Luke. Or death. Which means not thinking about my mother, who died on vacation last winter. There are so many things I can’t think about in order to write in the morning.

author: Stephen King
title: Night Shift
opening_line: Let’s talk, you and I. Let’s talk about fear.

author: Stephen King
title: Different Seasons
opening_line: The most important things are the hardest things to say.

author: Stephen King
title: Misery
opening_line: umber whunn yerrrnnn umber whunnn fayunnn These sounds: even in the haze.

author: Stephen King
title: On Writing
opening_line: My earliest memory is of imagining I was someone else—imagining that I was, in fact, the Ringling Brothers Circus Strongboy. This was at my Aunt Ethelyn and Uncle Oren’s house in Durham, Maine. My aunt remembers this quite clearly, and say I was two and a half or maybe three years old.

author: Stephen King
title: Secret Windows: Essays and Fiction on the Craft of Writing
opening_line: When I finally understand what my thirteen-year-old son was talking about, I told him no problem, I could find him a couple of good hookers easy—maybe even a couple of great ones.

author: Stephen King
title: Lisey’s Story
opening_line: To the public eye, the spouses of well-known writers are all but invisible, and no one knew it better than Lisey Landon.

author: Stephen King
title: Later
opening_line: I don’t like to start with an apology—there’s probably even a rule against it—but after reading over the first thirty pages I’ve written so far, I feel like I have to.

author: Rudyard Kipling
title: aspirations
opening_line: His name was Charlie Mears; he was the only son of his mother who was a widow, and he lived in the north of London, coming into the City every day to work in a bank. He was twenty years old and suffered from aspirations.

author: Anne Lamott
title: All New People
opening_line: I am living once again in the town where I grew up, having returned here several weeks ago in a state of dull torment for which the Germans probably have a word.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Bird by Bird
opening_line: The very first thing I tell my new students on the first day of a workshop is that good writing is about telling the truth.

author: Thomas Larson
title: The Memoir and the Memoirist
opening_line: Memoir is the speaking “I” of a trusting author, walking hand in hand with the reader down a path both know well.

author: Jane Leavy
title: Squeeze Play
opening_line: Opening Day April 3 You see a lot of penises in my line of work: short ones, stubby ones, hard ones, soft ones. Circumcised and uncircumcised; laid-back and athletic.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: Contrary to what many of you might imagine, a career in letters is not without its drawbacks—chief among them the unpleasant fact that one is frequently called upon to actually sit down and write.

author: Richard Lederer
title: Anguished English
opening_line: Mark Twain once wrote, “Man is the only animal that blushes. Or needs to.” He could have added, “The human being is the only animal that truly laughs. Or needs to.”

author: Richard Lederer
title: The Miracle of Language
opening_line: “Language is the Rubicon that divides man from beast,” declared the philologist Max Müller. The boundary between human and animal—between the most primitive savage and the highest ape—is the language line.

author: Richard Lederer
title: The Cunning Linguist
opening_line: In a junior high-school biology class the teacher asks a student, “Mary please name the part of the human body that expands to six times its normal size and explain under what conditions.” Blushing bright red, Mary simpers, “Teacher that is not a proper question to ask me, and I can’t answer it in front of the class.” The teacher turns to another student and asks, “All right, Johnny, do you have the answer?” “The pupil of the eye, and in dim light.”

author: Richard Lederer
title: Amazing Words
opening_line: At seventy-four years of youth, I consider myself to be one of the luckiest men on the face of the earth. Looking back on my life, I can honestly say that I have pretty much closed the distance between who I am and what I do.

author: Richard Lederer
title: Richard Lederer’s Ultimate Book of Literary Trivia
opening_line: Literature lives. Literature endures. Literature prevails. That’s because readers bestow a special kind of life upon people who have existed only in books.

author: Johannes Lichtman
title: The Paris Review
opening_line: Last spring, a friend of a friend visited my office and invited me to Langley to speak to Invisible Ink, the CIA’s creative writing group.

author: Katia Lief
title: Invisible Woman
opening_line: The first time the thought came to her, with clarity instead of anger, it was a warm evening in June not long before the party that was supposed to launch a new phase of her husband’s brilliant career. She was standing at the kitchen sink sponging tomato sauce off a white plate. She rinsed it and set it dripping in the dish drainer, then picked up a wineglass and scrubbed at a haze of lip gloss biting the rim. She put the glass down but left the water running, as if the sound could blot out her thoughts, as if he could hear them through the linkage of empty rooms. What if I killed him?

author: Alan Light
title: The Holy or the Broken
opening_line: Allen Ginzberg once said, “Dylan blew everybody’s mind except Leonard’s.”

author: Clarice Lispector
title: The Hour of the Star
opening_line: Everything in the world began with a yes. One molecule said yes to another molecule and life was born.

author: David Lodge
title: Changing Places
opening_line: High, high above the North Pole, on the first day of 1969, two professors of English Literature approached each other at a combined velocity of 1200 miles per hour.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: In the first grade I was in a bit of a fog.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: To Show and To Tell
opening_line: I should explain straight-out that I consider myself to be as much a teacher as writer. It’s not simply that a good deal of my annual income derives from teaching; it’s also that I find it a fascinating challenge, one that nourishes my psyche—and my own writing.

author: Charlie Lovett
title: First Impressions
opening_line: Fond as she was of solitary walks, Jane had been wandering rather longer than she had intended, her mind occupied not so much with the story she had lately been reading as with the one she hoped soon to be writing.

author: Charlie Lovett
title: The Further Adventures of Ebenezer Scrooge
opening_line: Scrooge was alive, to begin with. There could be no doubt whatever about that—alive and kicking.

author: W. Somerset Maugham
title: The Summing Up
opening_line: This is not an autobiography nor is it a book of recollections. In one way and another I have used in my writings whatever has happened to me in the course of my life.

author: W. Somerset Maugham
title: Strictly Personal
opening_line: I have a notion that it is well to tell the reader at the beginning of a narrative what he is in for, and so I shall start by telling you that this is not an account of great events, but of the small things that happened to me during the first fifteen months of the war.

author: W. Somerset Maugham
title: The Razor’s Edge
opening_line: I have never begun a novel with more misgiving. If I call it a novel it is only because I don’t know what else to call it.

author: Elizabeth McCracken
title: The Hero of This Book
opening_line: This was the summer before the world stopped.

author: Jay McInerney
title: Brightness Falls
opening_line: The last time I saw Russell and Corrine together was the weekend of the final softball game between the addicts and the depressives.

author: James Michener
title: The World Is My Home
opening_line: This will be a strange kind of autobiography because I shall offer the first seven chapters as if I had never written a book, the last seven as if that were all I had done.

author: Sue Miller
title: The Distinguished Guest
opening_line: In 1982, when she was seventy-two years old, Lily Roberts Maynard published her first book.

author: Lorrie Moore
title: Self-Help
opening_line: First, try to be something, anything, else. A movie star/astronaut. A movie star/missionary. A movie star/kindergarten teacher. President of the World. Fail miserably.

author: Lance Morrow
title: The Wall Street Journal
opening_line: I once knew a magazine journalist who was addicted to metaphors. He was, so to speak, an alcoholic of metaphors. If he took one sip from the demon rum of analogy, he would be in the gutter by the end of the paragraph. His journalism suffered from what might be called cirrhosis of the prose.

author: Alice Munro
title: Dance of the Happy Shades
opening_line: The solution to my life occurred to me one evening while I was ironing a shirt.

author: Iris Murdoch
title: The Black Prince
opening_line: It might be most dramatically effective to begin the tale at the moment when Arnold Baffin rang me up and said, “Bradley, could you come round here please, I think that I have just killed my wife.”

author: Vladimir Nabokov
title: Speak, Memory
opening_line: The cradle rocks above an abyss, and common sense tells us that our existence is but a brief crack of light between two eternities of darkness.

author: Meghan O’Rourke
title: The Invisible Kingdom
opening_line: The stories we tell about illness usually have startling beginnings—the fall at the supermarket, the lump discovered in the abdomen during a routine exam, the doctor’s call. Not mine. I got sick the way Hemingway says you go broke: “gradually and then suddenly.”

author: George Orwell
title: Gangrel
opening_line: From a very early age, perhaps the age of five or six, I knew that when I grew up I should be a writer.

author: George Orwell
title: Horizon
opening_line: Most people who bother with the matter at all would admit that the English language is in a bad way, but it is generally assumed that we cannot by conscious action do anything about it.

author: Orhan Pamuk
title: The New Life
opening_line: I read a book one day and my whole life was changed.

author: Nancy Pearl
title: Book Lust
opening_line: I love to read. And while I might not absolutely agree with the Anglo-American man of letters Logan Pearsall Smith, who said, “People say that life is the thing, but I prefer reading,” I come awfully close to subscribing to his sentiment.

author: Nancy Pearl
title: More Book Lust
opening_line: If we were at a twelve-step meeting together, I would have to stand up and say, “Hi, I’m Nancy P., and I’m a readaholic.”

author: Arturo Pérez-Reverte
title: The Club Dumas
opening_line: The flash projected the outline of the hanged man onto the wall. He hung motionless from a light fixture in the center of the room, and as the photographer moved around him, taking pictures, the flashes threw the silhouette onto a succession of paintings, glass cabinets full of porcelain, shelves of books, open curtains framing great windows beyond which the rain was falling.

author: Robert S. Phillips
title: Louis L’Amour
opening_line: Louis L’Amour. The name itself sounds highly improbable for the author of Western and adventure novels. As one of his early editors said, L’Amour on a paperback sounded like “a Western written in lipstick.”

author: Katherine Anne Porter
title: The Collected Essays and Occasional Writings of Katherine Anne Porter
opening_line: Of all fine sights in the world to me, the best is that of an artist growing great, adding to his art with his years, as his life and his art are inseparable.

author: Anna Quindlen
title: Lots of Candles, Plenty of Cake
opening_line: It’s odd when I think of the arc of my life, from child to young woman to aging adult. First I was who I was. Then I didn’t know who I was. Then I invented someone, and became her. Then I began to like what I’d invented. And finally I was what I was again.

author: Leonard E. Read
title: The Freeman
opening_line: I am a lead pencil—the ordinary wooden pencil familiar to all boys and girls and adults who can read and write. Writing is both my vocation and my avocation; that’s all I do.

author: Ruth Rendell
title: Asta’s Book
opening_line: My grandmother was a novelist without knowing it.

author: Rhonda Rich
title: The New Brunswick News
opening_line: On a Sunday morning, tucked into bed on the island of St. Simons, the place where I, at the age of 13, accepted the calling that had haunted me since I was four — that of becoming a writer—Tink brought me a copy of The New York Times and coffee loaded with cream.

author: Salman Rushdie
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: 1989. Afterward, when the world was exploding around him, he felt annoyed with himself for having forgotten the name of the BBC reporter who told him that his old life was over and a new, darker existence was about to begin. She called him at home, on his private line, without explaining how she got the number. “How does it feel,” she asked him, “to know that you have just been sentenced to death by Ayatollah Khomeini?”

author: Vita Sackville-West
title: The Edwardians
opening_line: Among the many problems which beset the novelist, not the least weighty is the choice of the moment at which to begin his novel.

author: Sam Savage
title: Firmin: Adventures of a Metropolitan Lowlife
opening_line: I had always imagined that my life story, if and when I wrote it, would have a great first line: something lyric like Nabokov’s “Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins”; or if I could not do lyric, then something sweeping like Tolstoy’s “All happy families are alike, but every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.” People remember those words even when they have forgotten everything else about the books. When it comes to openers, though, the best in my view has to be the beginning of Ford Madox Ford’s The Good Soldier: “This is the saddest story I have ever heard.” I’ve read that one dozens of times and it still knocks my socks off. Ford Madox Ford was a Big One.

author: Timothy Schaffert
title: The Titanic Survivors Book Club
opening_line: I spotted my name, again and again, on the lists of the dead. Even as the weeks went by and the reports got fixed, my name didn’t budge.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer
title: Parerga and Paralipomena
opening_line: Ignorance is degrading only when found in company with riches.

author: Charles M. Schulz
title: My Life with Charlie Brown
opening_line: And so, 25 years have gone by. At one strip per day, that comes to almost 10,000 comic strips. Actually, this is not so much when you consider the longevity of many other comic features. Employees receive wristwatches if they have put in this much time with a company, but a comic-strip artist just keeps on drawing. (Somehow a comic-strip artist is never regarded as an employee.)

author: Murray Schumach
title: The New York Times
opening_line: It was not quite proper to have printed The Carpetbaggers between covers of a book. It should have been inscribed on the walls of a public lavatory.

author: Parul Sehgal
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: It is a truth only fitfully acknowledged that whom the gods wish to destroy, they first give an opinion column.

author: Peter Selgin
title: Your First Page
opening_line: I once spoke with a New York City fireman whose job included talking suicidal “jumpers” down from building edges and bridges. He told me something that has stayed with me ever since. He said that in every case, without exception, when the person jumped, the look on his or her face was always the same. It said, in essence, “Wrong decision.”

author: Josh Shaffer
title: News & Observer
opening_line: To the ears of a musical novice, the tuba ranks lowest in the family of instruments—an oafish cousin with a voice like a bullfrog. It lacks the flash of a saxophone, the brashness of a trumpet or the showiness of a piccolo—the melodic equivalent of a St. Bernard, warbling from the orchestra’s back row.

author: Josh Shaffer
title: News & Observer
opening_line: The bagpipe occupies the strangest rung on the musical ladder, shaped like an octopus in plaid pants, sounding to some like a goose with its foot caught in an escalator and played during history’s most lopsided battles—by the losing side.

author: David Shields and Shane Salerno
title: Salinger
opening_line: J. D. Salinger spent ten years writing The Catcher in the Rye and the rest of his life regretting it.

author: Osbert Sitwell
title: Left Hand, Right Hand!
opening_line: A robust old country-neighbor, one of the last of the squires, was heard during a severe thunderstorm thus to address his faithful and aging servant: “Alec, you damn fool, don’t stand about there, doing nothing! Climb up the lightning-conductor, can’t you, and see if it’s working!”

author: Lemony Snicket (pen name of Daniel Handler)
title: The Reptile Room
opening_line: The stretch of road that leads out of the city, past Hazy Harbor and into the town of Tedia, is perhaps the most unpleasant in the world. It is called Lousy Lane.

author: Lemony Snicket (pen name of Daniel Handler)
title: The Bad Beginning, or, Orphans
opening_line: If you are interested in stories with happy endings, you would be better off reading some other book. In this book, not only is there no happy ending, there is no happy beginning and very few happy things in the middle.

author: Lemony Snicket (pen name of Daniel Handler)
title: The Austere Academy
opening_line: If you were going to give a gold medal to the least delightful person on Earth, you would have to give that medal to a person named Carmelita Spats, and if you didn’t give it to her, Carmelita Spats was the sort of person who would snatch it from your hands anyway.

author: Rebecca Solnit
title: Men Explain Things to Me
opening_line: One evening over dinner in March 2008, I began to joke, as I often had before, about writing an essay called “Men Explain Things to Me.” Every writer has a stable of ideas that never make it to the racetrack, and I’d been trotting this pony out recreationally once in a while.

author: Alexander Solzhenitsyn
title: The Oak and the Calf
opening_line: Underground is where you expect to find revolutionaries. But not writers.

author: Howard Sounes
title: Charles Bukowski
opening_line: Charles Bukowski raised himself up from his chair and got a beer from the refrigerator behind him on stage. The audience applauded as he drank, tipping the bottle until it was upside down and he had drained the last golden drop. “This is not a prop,” he said, speaking slowly with a lilt to his voice, like W. C. Fields. “It’s a necesssssity.”

author: Francis Spufford
title: The Child That Books Built
opening_line: “I can always tell when you’re reading somewhere in the house,“ my mother used to say. “There’s a special silence, a reading silence.“

author: Harvey Stanbrough
title: Writing Better Fiction
opening_line: Staple it to the inside of your eyeballs, folks: All good fiction is character-driven.

author: William Styron
title: Sophie’s Choice
opening_line: In those days cheap apartments were almost impossible to find in Manhattan, so I had to move to Brooklyn. This was in 1947, and one of the pleasant features of that summer which I so vividly remember was the weather, which was sunny and mild, flower-fragrant, almost as if the days had been arrested in a seemingly perpetual springtime. I was grateful for that if for nothing else, since my youth, I felt, was at its lowest ebb.

author: Gay Talese
title: The Kingdom and the Power
opening_line: Most journalists are restless voyeurs who see the warts on the world, the imperfections in people and places.

author: Greg Tamblyn
title: Atilla the Gate Agent
opening_line: I once had an engagement in the town of Normal, Illinois. I was delighted to learn that a place called Normal actually existed, because I happen to live just a few miles from the town of Peculiar, Missouri. I don’t think it’s any accident of the universe that I live a lot closer to Peculiar than Normal.

author: Rufi Thorpe
title: Margo’s Got Money Troubles
opening_line: You are about to begin reading a new book, and to be honest, you are a little tense. The beginning of a novel is like a first date. You hope that from the first lines an urgent magic will take hold, and you will sink into the story like a hot bath, giving yourself over entirely.

author: Calvin Trillin
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: To memorize the first ten digits of pi, you simply have to sing, to the tune of the Mousketeers song, “If numbers had a heaven / their god would surely be / 3.1415 / 92653.”

author: Calvin Trillin
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: It’s said that when James Thurber, as a young newspaper reporter, was told by an editor that his story’s first paragraph, what newspaper people might refer to as his lede, suffered from wordiness, he handed in a rewrite whose opening paragraph was, in its entirety, “Dead.” There followed a second paragraph: “That’s what the man was when they found him with a knife in his back at 4pm in front of Riley’s saloon at the corner of 52nd and 12th streets.”

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: The Observer
opening_line: Nobody has ever succeeded as Macbeth, and the reason is not far to seek. Instead of growing as the play proceeds, the hero shrinks; complex and many-levelled to begin with, he ends up a cornered thug, lacking even a death scene with which to regain lost stature.

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: The Observer
opening_line: Night- nurses at the bedside of good drama, we critics keep a holy vigil. Black circles rim our eyes as we pray for the survival of our pet patient….

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: Observer
opening_line: “Bloody sparklin’ dialogue,” said a pensive Irishman during the first interval of The Quare Fellow—and sparkle, by any standards, it amazingly did.

author: John Updike
title: Assorted Prose
opening_line: Pity the poor bore. He stands among us as a creature formidable and familiar yet in essence unknowable. We can read of the ten infallible signs whereby he may be recognized and of the seven tested methods whereby he may be rebuffed.

author: John Updike
title: Self-Consciousness
opening_line: Had not my twenty-five-year-old daughter undertipped the airline porter in Boston, our luggage might have shown upon the carrousel [sic] in Allentown that April afternoon in 1980, and I would not have spent an evening walking the sidewalks of Shillington, Pennsylvania, searching for the meaning for my existence, as once I had scanned those same sidewalks for lost pennies.

author: Gore Vidal
title: The New York Times
opening_line: A satirist is a man profoundly revolted by the society in which he lives. His rage takes the form of wit, ridicule, mockery.

author: Hugh Walpole
title: The Silver Thorn: A Book of Stories
opening_line: As Foster moved unconsciously across the room, bent towards the bookcase, and stood leaning forward a little, choosing now one book, now another with his eye, his host, seeing the muscles of the back of his thin, scraggy neck stand out above his low flannel collar, thought of the ease with which he could squeeze that throat and the pleasure, the triumphant, lustful pleasure, that such an action would give him.

author: Gene Weingarten
title: The Detroit Free Press
opening_line: Every day, liquid sewage—three million gallons of it from starting points across Metro Detroit—roars through subterranean channels to a single collecting point five miles down the road from The Renaissance Center, on West Jefferson. Then it hits the fan.

author: Fay Weldon
title: Auto da Fay
opening_line: I long for a day of judgment when the plot lines of our lives will be neatly tied, and all puzzles explained, and the meaning of events made clear. We take to fiction, I suppose, because no such thing is going to happen….

author: H. G. Wells
title: Certain Personal Matters
opening_line: The art of the essayist is so simple, so entirely free from canons of criticism, and withal so delightful, that one must needs wonder why all men are not essayists. Perhaps people do not know how easy it is. Or perhaps beginners are misled. Rightly taught it may be learnt in a brief ten minutes or so, what art there is in it. And all the rest is as easy as wandering among woodlands on a bright morning in the spring.

author: Colson Whitehead
title: Apex Hides the Hurt
opening_line: He came up with the names.

author: Thomas Williams
title: Leah, New Hampshire
opening_line: My name is Aaron Benham, and I am a writer of fiction, a college professor, and an unwilling collector of paranoiacs. Perhaps I am no more surrounded by paranoiacs than anyone else, but sometimes I wonder.

author: James Wood
title: How Fiction Works
opening_line: The house of fiction has many windows, but only two or three doors.

author: Kate Zambreno
title: To Write As If Already Dead
opening_line: There comes a moment when you are finally given some space and quiet, maybe an hour, possibly two, the occasional birdsong by an open window, and you must go to that other room and return to the problem you’ve been attempting to unravel.

author: Hans Zinsser
title: Rats, Lice, and History
opening_line: This book, if it is ever written, and—if written—it finds a publisher, and—if published—anyone reads it, will be recognized with some difficulty as a biography.

author: William Zinsser
title: Spring Training
opening_line: This book was born, though I didn’t know it at the time, seven years ago in Winter Haven, Florida, at the spring training camp of the Boston Red Sox. I was sitting in the grandstand in a sea of codgers, codging the time away.

author: William Zinsser
title: Inventing the Truth
opening_line: This is the age of the memoir. Never have personal narratives gushed so profusely from the American soil as in the closing decade of the twentieth century. Everyone has a story to tell, and everyone is telling it.

author: William Zinsser
title: Writing Places
opening_line: Of all the places where I’ve done my writing, none was more unusual than the office that had a fire pole.

author: Kevin F. Adler and Donald W. Burnes (with Amanda Banh and Andrijana Bilbija)
title: When We Walk By
opening_line: Everyone is someone’s somebody.

author: Gregg Allmann (with Alan Light)
title: My Cross to Bear
opening_line: I was sitting up talking, and I just kind of nodded off. But I didn’t nod off: I was Code Blue. I was bleeding inside, and I was drowning in blood.

author: Dave Barry
title: The Miami Herald
opening_line: OK. You turned 50. You know you’re supposed to get a colonoscopy. But you haven’t. Here are your reasons: 1. You’ve been busy. 2. You don’t have a history of cancer in your family. 3. You haven’t noticed any problems. 4. You don’t want a doctor to stick a tube 17,000 feet up your butt.

author: Catherine Belling
title: A Condition of Doubt
opening_line: Hypochondriacs have two significant beliefs; that their bodies contain something that will kill them, and that, if they could only read their bodies closely enough, they should be able to find that lurking threat before it is too late.

author: Elizabeth Berg
title: Talk Before Sleep
opening_line: This morning, before I came to Ruth’s house, I made yet another casserole for my husband and daughter. Meggie likes casseroles while Joe only endures them, but they are all I can manage right now. I put the dish in the refrigerator, with a note taped on it telling how long to cook it, and at what temperature, and that they should have a salad, too.

author: Cat Bohannon
title: Eve
opening_line: Elizabeth Shaw has a problem. The director Ridley Scott has impregnated her with a large, vicious alien squid. Aboard the spaceship Prometheus, she has to find a way to abort her uninvited guest without bleeding to death. Shambling to a futuristic surgery pod, she asks the computer for a C-section. “Error,” it says, “this medpod is calibrated for male patients only.” “Shit,” said a woman behind me, “who does that?”

author: Rutger Bregman
title: Humankind
opening_line: This is a book about a radical idea. An idea that’s long been known to make rulers nervous. An idea denied by religions and ideologies, ignored by the news media and erased from the annals of world history. At the same time, it’s an idea that’s legitimized by virtually every branch of science. One that’s corroborated by evolution and confirmed by everyday life. An ideal so intrinsic to human nature that it goes unnoticed and gets overlooked. If only we had the courage to take it more seriously, it’s an idea that might just start a revolution. Turn society on its head. Because once you grasp what it really means, it’s nothing less than a mind-bending drug that ensures you’ll never look at the world the same again. So what is this radical idea? That most people, deep down, are pretty decent.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The Beauty of Dusk
opening_line: They say that death comes like a thief in the night. Lesser vandals have the same MO. The affliction that stole my vision, or at least a big chuck of it, did so as I slept. I went to bed seeing the world one way. I woke up seeing it another.

author: Melvin Burgess
title: Junk
opening_line: A boy and girl were spending the night together in the back seat of a Volvo estate car. The car was in a garage. It was pitch black.

author: Kelly Corrigan
title: The Middle Place
opening_line: The thing you need to know about me is that I am George Corrigan’s daughter, his only daughter. You may have met him, in which case just skip this part. If you haven’t, I’ll do what I can to describe him, but really, you should try to meet him.

author: Norman Cousins
title: Anatomy of an Illness
opening_line: This book is about a serious illness that occurred in 1964. I was reluctant to write about it for many years because I was fearful of creating false hopes in others who were similarly afflicted. Moreover, I knew that a single case has small standing in the annals of medical research, having little more than “anecdotal” or “testimonial” value.

author: Michael Crichton
title: Travels
opening_line: It is not easy to cut through a human head with a hacksaw.

author: Gavin de Becker
title: The Gift of Fear
opening_line: He had probably been watching her for a while. We aren’t sure—but what we do know is that she was not his first victim.

author: Louise Dean
title: Becoming Strangers
opening_line: Before he’d had cancer he’d been bored with life. Since he’d taken dying seriously, he’d been busy; he was occupied with understanding the disease and training his body to resist it.

author: Joan Didion
title: The Year of Magical Thinking
opening_line: Life changes fast. Life changes in the instant. You sit down to dinner and life as you know it ends. The question of self-pity. Those were the first words I wrote after it happened.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The Extraordinary Healing Power of Ordinary Things
opening_line: There is an old saying: If you want to hide the treasure, put it in plain sight. Then no one will see it.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The Power of Premonitions
opening_line: Sometimes things grab hold and just won’t let go.

author: Larry Dossey
title: Reinventing Medicine
opening_line: During my first year of medical practice, I had a dream that shook my world.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The New Science and Spirituality Reader
opening_line: What is spirituality? I consider it a felt sense of connectedness with something higher, a presence that transcends the individual sense of self.

author: Caitlin Doughty
title: Smoke Gets in Your Eyes
opening_line: A girl always remembers the first corpse she shaves.

author: Caitlin Doughty
title: Will My Cat Eat My Eyeballs
opening_line: No, your cat won’t eat your eyeballs. Not right away, at least.

author: Nora Ephron
title: I Remember Nothing
opening_line: I’m old. I am sixty-nine years old. Really old is eighty. But if you are young, you would definitely think I’m old. No one actually likes to admit that they’re old. The most they will cop to is that they’re older. Or oldish.

author: Michael J. Fox
title: Lucky Man
opening_line: Gainesville, Florida—November 1990 I woke up to find the message in my left hand. It had me trembling. It wasn’t a fax, telegram, memo, or the usual sort of missive bringing disturbing news. In fact, my hand held nothing at all. The trembling was the message.

author: Ty Gagne
title: The Last Traverse
opening_line: James Osborne is on the precipice, barely holding on to the frayed rope of advanced life support. The hospital’s technology and medications are working to protect him from falling into the abyss, but just how long the fragile anchor system can keep him aloft is uncertain.

author: Lisa Genova
title: Inside the O’Briens
opening_line: Damn woman is always moving his things. He can’t kick off his boots in the living room or set his sunglasses down on the coffee table without her relocating them to “Where they belong.” Who made her God in this house? If he wants to leave a stinking pile of his own shit in the middle of the kitchen table, then that’s where it should stay until he moves it. Where the fuck is my gun? “Rosie!” Joe hollers from the bedroom.

author: John Green
title: The Fault is in Our Stars
opening_line: Late in the winter of my seventeenth year, my mother decided I was depressed, presumably because I rarely left the house, spent quite a lot of time in bed, read the same book over and over, ate infrequently, and devoted quite a bit of my abundant free time to thinking about death.

author: Pete Hamill
title: The Drinking Life
opening_line: This is a book about my time in the drinking life. It tells the story of the way one human being became aware of alcohol, embraced it, struggled with it, was hurt by it, and finally left it behind. The tale has no hero.

author: J. Patrick Henry
title: The Remembered Arts Journal
opening_line: Freda kept losing her husband.

author: Christopher Hitchens
title: Mortality
opening_line: I have more than once in my time woken up feeling like death. But nothing prepared me for the early morning in June when I came to consciousness feeling as if I were actually shackled to my own corpse.

author: Shere Hite
title: The Hite Report
opening_line: Women have never been asked how they feel about sex.

author: John Irving
title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
opening_line: I am doomed to remember a boy with a wrecked voice—not because of his voice, or because he was the smallest person I ever knew, or even because he was the instrument of my mother’s death, but because he is the reason I believe in God; I am a Christian because of Owen Meany.

author: Molly Ivins
opening_line: Having breast cancer is massive amounts of no fun. First they mutilate you; then they poison you; then they burn you. I have been on blind dates better than that.

author: Tracy Kidder
title: Mountains Beyond Mountains
opening_line: Six years after the fact, Dr. Paul Edward Farmer reminded me, “We met because of a beheading, of all things.”

author: Wally Lamb
title: I Know This Much Is True
opening_line: On the afternoon of October 12, 1990, my twin brother Thomas entered the Three Rivers, Connecticut Public Library, retreated to one of the rear study carrels, and prayed to God the sacrifice he was about to commit would be deemed acceptable.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Hard Laughter
opening_line: My family lived for fifteen years in a castle built more than a century ago by an eccentric man who wanted his Rhine-born wife to feel at home when he brought her to live in California.

author: Anne Lamott
title: The New York Times
opening_line: Getting older is almost like changing species, from cute middle-aged, white-tailed deer, to yak. We are both grass eaters, but that’s about the only similarity.

author: Andrew Leland
title: The Country of the Blind
opening_line: I’m going blind as I write this.

author: Daniel J. Levitin
title: Successful Aging
opening_line: The poet Dylan Thomas wrote that one should not go gently into that good night, that old age should burn and rage at close of day. As a younger man reading that poem, I saw futility in those words. I saw aging only as a failing: a failing of the body, of the mind, and even of the spirit.

author: Clancy Martin
title: How Not to Kill Yourself: A Portrait of the Suicidal Mind (2023)
opening_line: The last time I tried to kill myself was in my basement with a dog leash.

author: Robert McCrum
title: Every Third Thought
opening_line: No one will ever know exactly what happened inside my head on the night of 28 July 1995, but probably it went something like this. First, for reasons that remain mysterious, a surreptitious clot began to form in one of my cerebral arteries, cutting off the blood supply to the one organ in the body that, after the heart, is most greedy for blood.

author: Sherwin Nuland
title: How We Die
opening_line: Every life is different from any that has gone before it, and so is every death. The uniqueness of each of us extends even to the way we die.

author: Meghan O’Rourke
title: The Invisible Kingdom
opening_line: The stories we tell about illness usually have startling beginnings—the fall at the supermarket, the lump discovered in the abdomen during a routine exam, the doctor’s call. Not mine. I got sick the way Hemingway says you go broke: “gradually and then suddenly.”

author: Peter Olsson
title: Janusian Days
opening_line: My passion for medicine dawns in the realm of childhood idealism and spiritual innocence. I am ten years old and picture myself as a medical missionary like Albert Schweitzer or Tom Dooley.

author: Randy Pausch
title: The Last Lecture
opening_line: I have an engineering problem. While for the most part I’m in terrific physical shape, I have ten tumors in my liver and I have only a few months to live. I am a father of three young children, and married to the woman of my dreams. While I could easily feel sorry for myself, that wouldn’t do them, or me, any good. So, how to spend my very limited time.

author: Dolen Perkins-Valdez
title: Take My Hand
opening_line: Memphis 2016 A year never passes without me thinking of them. India. Erica. Their names are stitched inside every white coat I have ever worn.

author: Jodi Picoult
title: House Rules
opening_line: Everywhere I look, there are signs of a struggle. The mail has been scattered all over the kitchen floor; the stools are overturned. The phone has been knocked off its pedestal, its battery pack hanging loose from an umbilicus of wires. There’s one single faint footprint at the threshold of the living room, pointing toward the dead body of my son, Jacob.

author: Richard Powers
title: The Echo Maker
opening_line: Cranes keep landing as night falls. Ribbons of them roll down, slack against the sky. They float in from all compass points, in kettles of a dozen, dropping with the dusk.

author: Mary Roach
title: Stiff
opening_line: The way I see it, being dead is not terribly far off from being on a cruise ship. Most of your time is spent lying on your back. The brain has shut down. The flesh begins to soften. Nothing much new happens, and nothing is expected of you.

author: Mary Roach
title: Spook
opening_line: I don’t recall my mood the morning I was born, but I imagine I felt a bit out of sorts. Nothing I looked at was familiar. People were staring at me and making odd sounds and wearing incomprehensible items. Everything seemed too loud, and nothing made the slightest amount of sense.

author: Mary Roach
title: Bonk
opening_line: A man sits in a room, manipulating his kneecaps. It is 1983, on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. The man, a study subject, has been told to do this for four minutes, stop, and then resume for a minute more. Then he can put his pants back on, collect his payment, and go home with an entertaining story to tell at suppertime.

author: Jacqueline Rose
title: On Violence and On Violence Against Women
opening_line: It is a truism to say that everyone knows violence when they see it, but if one thing has become clear over the past decade it is that the most prevalent, insidious forms of violence are those that cannot be seen.

author: Peter Schjeldahl
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Lung cancer, rampant. No surprise. I’ve smoked since I was sixteen, behind the high-school football bleachers in Northfield, Minnesota. I used to fear the embarrassment of dying youngish, letting people natter sagely, “He smoked, you know.” But at seventy-seven I’m into the actuarial zone.

author: Gail Sheehy
title: Passages
opening_line: Without warning, in the middle of my thirties, I had a breakdown of nerve.

author: Benjamin Spock
title: The Common Sense of Baby and Child Care
opening_line: You know more than you think you do.

author: Sharon Stone
title: The Beauty of Living Twice
opening_line: I opened my eyes, and there he was standing over me, just inches from my face. A stranger looking at me with so much kindness that I was sure I was going to die. He was stroking my head, my hair; God, he was handsome. I wished he were someone who loved me instead of someone whose next words were “You’re bleeding into your brain.”

author: Cheryl Strayed
title: The Torch
opening_line: She ached. As if her spine were a zipper and someone had come up behind her and unzipped it and pushed his hands into her organs and squeezed, as if they were butter or dough, or grapes to be smashed for wine. At other times it was something sharp like diamonds or shards of glass engraving her bones.

author: William Styron
title: Darkness Visible
opening_line: In Paris on a chilly evening late in October of 1985, I first became aware that the struggle with the disorder in my mind—a struggle which had engaged me for several months—might have a fatal outcome.

author: Elizabeth Vargas
title: Between Breaths
opening_line: I don’t know if I was born an alcoholic, but I was definitely born anxious. The alcoholism came to me later in life, after years of drinking to ease stress and worry, and to fend off panic.

author: Jim Wahlberg
title: The Big Hustle
opening_line: I’d been in fights all my life. I’d been pummeled by the toughest guys you’d ever not want to meet. I’d been beaten up, knocked unconscious, whacked in the head with a crowbar, and thrashed by a prison guard. But far and away the worst gut punch I ever took was when I discovered that my son was on drugs.

author: David Waltner-Toews
title: On Pandemics
opening_line: Until a few years ago, many scientists had banished words like “threat” and “danger” from our vocabulary. In an attempt to be more rigorously quantitative and less emotional, we began to write about risks. Our response to danger was called “risk management.”

author: Hans Zinsser
title: Rats, Lice, and History
opening_line: This book, if it is ever written, and—if written—it finds a publisher, and—if published—anyone reads it, will be recognized with some difficulty as a biography.

author: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Raymond Obstfeld
title: Becoming Kareem
opening_line: I didn’t realize I was black until third grade.

author: Roger Angell
title: The Summer Game
opening_line: Today the Times reported the arrival of the first pitchers and catchers at the spring training camps, and the morning was abruptly brightened, as if by the delivery of a seed catalogue.

author: Roger Angell
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Coming up out of the dugout before his next at-bat in a big game, Reggie Jackson was always accompanied by an invisible entourage: he was the heavyweight champion headed down the aisle for another title defense.

author: Fredrik Backman
title: Beartown
opening_line: Late one evening toward the end of March, a teenager picked up a double-barreled shotgun, walked into the forest, put the gun to someone else’s forehead, and pulled the trigger. This is the story of how we got there.

author: Roy Blount, Jr.
title: Sports Illustrated
opening_line: In 1951 Marilyn Monroe was a starlet, Bobby Orr a baby, Hubert Humphrey a comer—and Willie Mays very nearly the same phenomenon he was last week.

author: Jim Bouton
title: Ball Four
opening_line: Fall 1968 I’m 30 years old and I have these dreams.

author: Rubin Carter
title: The Sixteenth Round
opening_line: RUBIN, my Christian name, comes from the Book of Genesis, Chapter 29, verse 32 of the Holy Scriptures. Other than both of us being black, that’s about the only thing the Bible and I ever had in common.

author: Pat Conroy
title: My Losing Season
opening_line: I was born to be a point guard, but not a very good one.

author: Ty Gagne
title: The Last Traverse
opening_line: James Osborne is on the precipice, barely holding on to the frayed rope of advanced life support. The hospital’s technology and medications are working to protect him from falling into the abyss, but just how long the fragile anchor system can keep him aloft is uncertain.

author: Jason Gay
title: The Wall Street Journal
opening_line: It was like watching a beloved but untrustworthy old truck, 270,000 miles on the odometer, tank near empty, bed rusted, bumper hanging, tires balding, snorting smoke, sputtering oil, conking out five times on the way home—somehow rumbling up the driveway and safely wheezing its way into the garage. In other words: beautiful.

author: Wayne Gretzky
title: Gretzky
opening_line: I have to admit, my childhood was a little different.

author: Laura Hillenbrand
title: Seabiscuit
opening_line: In 1938, near the end of a decade of monumental turmoil, the year’s number-one newsmaker was not Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Hitler, or Mussolini. It wasn’t Pope Pius XI, nor was it Lou Gehrig, Howard Hughes, or Clark Gable. The subject of the most newspaper column inches in 1938 wasn’t even a person. It was an undersized, crooked-legged racehorse named Seabiscuit.

author: Nick Hornby
title: Fever Pitch
opening_line: I fell in love with football as I was later to fall in love with women: suddenly, inexplicably, uncritically, giving no thought to the pain or disruption it would bring with it.

author: W. P. Kinsella
title: Shoeless Joe
opening_line: My father said he saw him years later playing in a tenth-rate commercial league in a textile town in Carolina, wearing shoes and an assumed name.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Crooked Little Heart
opening_line: Rosie and her friends were blooming like spring, budding, lithe, agile as cats. They wore tiny dresses and skirts so short that their frilly satin tennis bloomers showed.

author: Jane Leavy
title: Squeeze Play
opening_line: Opening Day April 3 You see a lot of penises in my line of work: short ones, stubby ones, hard ones, soft ones. Circumcised and uncircumcised; laid-back and athletic.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: When it comes to sports I am not particularly interested. Generally speaking, I look upon them as dangerous and tiring activities performed by people with whom I share nothing except the right to trial by jury.

author: George Leonard
title: The Ultimate Athlete
opening_line: In every fat man, the saying goes, there is a thin man struggling to get out. If this is so, then every skinny man must at times find himself surrounded by the ghostly outlines of muscles and heft. And there must somehow exist an ideal physique for every one of us—man, woman, and child.

author: Michael Lewis
title: Moneyball
opening_line: The first thing they always did was run you.

author: Norman Maclean
title: A River Runs Through It and Other Stories
opening_line: In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly fishing.

author: Tori Murden McClure
title: A Pearl in the Storm
opening_line: In the end, I know I rowed across the Atlantic to find my heart, but in the beginning, I wasn’t aware that it was missing.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: Like many who buy a motorcycle, there had been for me the problem of getting over the rather harrowing insurance statistics as to just what it is that is likely to happen to you.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: I have been bird hunting since I was ten years old. I was not much good at it when I was ten, and many years of experience have not made me any better. Sometimes, when asked about the results of my shooting, I am ashamed. Sometimes so ashamed that I lie about it vividly and recklessly.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: The fastest way to go from point to point on the face of the earth, assuming that you do not prepare the ground in front of you but take it rough and unimproved, is on a motorcycle.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: Lately I’ve been having trouble with golf. Which of us has not?

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: I concede that “mutton snapper” is hardly a prepossessing title. The sheep, from which the name derives, is not much of an animal. No civilized person deals with him except in chops and stews. To bleat is not to sing out in a commanding baritone; to be sheepish is scarcely to possess a virtue for which civilization rolls out its more impressive carpets.

author: Dave Meggyesy
title: Out of Their League
opening_line: You may not know it, but you’ve probably seen me on television a few times during the last seven years or so—that is if you’re one of the 25 million Americans who zeroes in on pro football for several hours every fall weekend. I wasn’t a glamour player, and the St. Louis Cardinals, where I played linebacker, wasn’t a glamour team; but I was out there, along with a thousand or so other guys, most of them as anonymous as me. But you won’t see me out there again.

author: Joe Namath
title: All the Way
opening_line: Something isn’t right. My chest is tight, and I’m just distracted, man, distracted. I’m drinking my daily eight-ounce Cheribundi at the kitchen table as an afternoon storm starts rolling in. Nothing out of the ordinary for August in south Florida, but I’m sure outta my element.

author: Craig Nettles and Peter Golenbock
title: Balls
opening_line: Some kids dream of joining the circus, others of becoming a major league baseball player. I have been doubly blessed. As a member of the New York Yankees, I have gotten to do both.

author: Mark Paul
title: The Greatest Gambling Story Every Told
opening_line: A girl with long red hair, perhaps eight years old, was sitting high atop her father’s shoulders, watching the horses load into the gate for the 110th running of the Kentucky Derby. They were standing in the packed grandstand at the stretch near the starting gate; nearly a quarter mile separated them and the finish line. She was holding a sign that read, “Beat the Boys! Althea!”

author: Robert Peterson
title: Only the Ball Was White
opening_line: They were saints and sinners, college professors and illiterates, serious men and clowns, teetotalers and Saturday night drunks. They were professional baseball players, some of them the equals of the greatest major-leaguers, with one other common tie: they were all Negroes.

author: Jackie Robinson
title: I Never Had It Made
opening_line: My grandfather was born into slavery, and although my mother and father, Mallie and Jerry Robinson, lived during an era when physical slavery had been abolished, they also lived in a newer, more sophisticated kind of slavery than the kind Mr. Lincoln struck down.

author: Philip Roth
title: The Great American Novel
opening_line: Call me Schmitty.

author: Dan Shaughnessy and Stan Grossfield
title: Fenway
opening_line: It’s personal. There’s no other way to explain the sentimental feelings many of us have for old, inanimate objects, like sweaters, cars, houses, and baseball parks.

author: Walter “Red” Smith
title: New York Herald-Tribune
opening_line: Now it is done. Now the story ends. And there is no way to tell it. The art of fiction is dead. Reality has strangled invention. Only the utterly impossible, the inexpressibly fantastic, can ever be plausible again.

author: Wright Thompson
title: ESPN.com
opening_line: Pat Conroy’s dad hit him after games. He hit him with fists, and with open palms, hit him until blood ran from Pat’s nose or lip onto his basketball jersey. Don Conroy didn’t hit his son only after games. He hit him for smiling at the wrong time, talking at the wrong time, crying at the wrong time, for trying to defend his battered mother at the wrong time. On occasion, he hit him just for the hell of it.

author: Colson Whitehead
title: The Noble Hustle
opening_line: I have a good poker face because I am half dead inside.

author: Ken Wilber
title: No Boundary
opening_line: Suddenly, without any warning, at any place or time, with no apparent cause, it can happen.

author: George F. Will
title: The Washington Post
