opening_line: A reader demands to know how I contracted the infectious conservatism for which he plans to horsewhip me. So if you have tears, prepare to shed them now as I reveal how my gloomy temperament received its conservative warp from early and prolonged exposure to the Chicago Cubs.

author: P. G. Wodehouse
title: The Heart of a Goof
opening_line: It was a morning when all nature shouted “Fore!”

author: John Wooden
title: My Personal Best
opening_line: I was raised on oatmeal.

author: William Zinsser
title: Spring Training
opening_line: This book was born, though I didn’t know it at the time, seven years ago in Winter Haven, Florida, at the spring training camp of the Boston Red Sox. I was sitting in the grandstand in a sea of codgers, codging the time away.

author: Jane Addams
title: Twenty Years at Hull House
opening_line: On the theory that our genuine impulses may be connected with our childish experiences, that one’s bent may be tracked back to that “No-Man’s Land” where character is formless but nevertheless settling into lines of future development, I begin this record with some impressions of my childhood.

author: Mortimer J. Adler
title: How to Speak, How to Listen
opening_line: How do you make contact with the mind of another person?

author: Mitch Albom
title: Tuesdays with Morrie
opening_line: The last class of my old professor’s life took place once a week in his house, by a window in the study where he could watch a small hibiscus plant shed its pink leaves. The class met on Tuesdays. It began after breakfast. The subject was The Meaning of Life. It was taught from experience.

author: James Allen
title: As a Man Thinketh
opening_line: The aphorism, “As a man thinketh in his heart, so is he,” not only embraces the whole of a man’s being, but is so comprehensive as to reach out to every condition and circumstance of his life.

author: Karé Anderson
title: Getting What You Want
opening_line: When trying to reach agreement, we always find a shorter path when we seek the truth beneath the apparent truth. Several people have helped teach me that, often not in any way they intended

author: Karé Anderson
title: Moving From Me to We
opening_line: Writing of her secret life as a prostitute, a blogger with the pseudonym Belle de Jour had a backstory worthy of a movie script.

author: Karé Anderson
title: Mutuality Matters
opening_line: After winning several music awards one year, Carlos Santana was asked by an eager young entertainment reporter how he felt about “this belated recognition after so many years as a professional musician.” In an apparent non sequitur, Santana smiled warmly and replied, “I am becoming the people I love,” to which the reporter responded, “But what does that have to do with these awards?”

author: Natalie Angier
title: The New York Times
opening_line: What feels as good as chocolate on the tongue or money in the bank but won't make you fat or risk a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission?

author: Karen Armstrong
title: The Bible
opening_line: Human beings are meaning-seeking creatures. Unless we find some pattern or significance in our lives, we fall very easily into despair.

author: Mary Kay Ash
title: Mary Kay
opening_line: There are four kinds of people in this world: I knew from a very early age that I wanted to be first on that list.

author: Francis Bacon
title: Essays
opening_line: Revenge is a kind of wild justice, which the more man’s nature runs to, the more ought law to weed it out.

author: Joan Baez
title: And a Voice to Sing With
opening_line: I was born gifted. I can speak of my gifts with little or no modesty, but with tremendous gratitude, precisely because they are gifts, and not things which I created, or actions about which I might be proud.

author: Julian Baggini
title: What’s It All About?
opening_line: “You’re T. S. Eliot,” said a taxi driver to the famous poet as he stepped into his cab. Eliot asked him how he knew. “Ah, I’ve got an eye for a celebrity,” he replied. “Only the other evening I picked up Bertrand Russell, and I said to him, ‘Well, Lord Russell, what’s it all about?’ And do you know he couldn’t tell me.’”

author: Catherine Belling
title: A Condition of Doubt
opening_line: Hypochondriacs have two significant beliefs; that their bodies contain something that will kill them, and that, if they could only read their bodies closely enough, they should be able to find that lurking threat before it is too late.

author: Sven Birkets
title: Los Angeles Review of Books
opening_line: Teaching writing, unlike most other kinds of teaching, is an intervention, closer to therapy than to any transmissible instruction.

author: Avery Bishop
title: Girl Gone Mad
opening_line: The girl cut herself. With a knife, most likely—with a paring knife or steak knife pilfered from the kitchen when her parents weren’t around—or maybe she used a pair of scissors already in her bedroom, opening them up and then pressing the tip of one of the blades against her skin.

author: Erin Blakemore
title: The Heroine’s Bookshelf
opening_line: In times of struggle, there are as many reasons not to read as there are to breathe. Don’t you have better things to do? Reading, let alone rereading, is the terrain of milquetoasts and mopey spinsters. At life’s ugliest junctures, the very act of opening a book can smack of cowardly escapism. Who chooses to read when there’s work to be done?

author: Hila Blum
title: How to Love Your Daughter
opening_line: The first time I saw my granddaughters, I was standing across the street, didn’t dare go any closer.

author: Laurel Braitman
title: What Looks Like Bravery
opening_line: Santa Paula, California, September 1994 It was a warm Saturday afternoon and the Santa Ana winds ruffled the tops of the avocado trees. I was at home with two good friends, all of us sixteen years old, draped like hormonal Dalí clocks over the living room furniture while we watched The Bodyguard on VHS and painted our nails.

author: Rutger Bregman
title: Humankind
opening_line: This is a book about a radical idea. An idea that’s long been known to make rulers nervous. An idea denied by religions and ideologies, ignored by the news media and erased from the annals of world history. At the same time, it’s an idea that’s legitimized by virtually every branch of science. One that’s corroborated by evolution and confirmed by everyday life. An ideal so intrinsic to human nature that it goes unnoticed and gets overlooked. If only we had the courage to take it more seriously, it’s an idea that might just start a revolution. Turn society on its head. Because once you grasp what it really means, it’s nothing less than a mind-bending drug that ensures you’ll never look at the world the same again. So what is this radical idea? That most people, deep down, are pretty decent.

author: Ian Bremmer
title: The Power of Crisis
opening_line: Away from the cameras and warmed by the fire, Ronald Reagan opened his first private conversation with Mikhail Gorbachev with a startling question: “What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?”

author: David Brooks
title: The Road to Character
opening_line: Recently I’ve been thinking about the difference between the resume virtues and the eulogy virtues.

author: David Brooks
title: How to Know a Person
opening_line: If you ever saw the old movie Fiddler on the Roof, you know how warm and emotional Jewish families can be. They are always hugging, singing, dancing, laughing, and crying together. I come from the other kind of Jewish family.

author: Helen Gurley Brown
title: Sex and the Single Girl
opening_line: I married for the first time at thirty-seven. I got the man I wanted. It could be construed as something of a miracle considering how old I was and how eligible he was.

author: Rita Mae Brown
title: Loose Lips
opening_line: Life will turn you inside out. No matter where you start you’ll end up someplace else even if you stay home. The one thing you can count on is that you’ll be surprised.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The Beauty of Dusk
opening_line: They say that death comes like a thief in the night. Lesser vandals have the same MO. The affliction that stole my vision, or at least a big chuck of it, did so as I slept. I went to bed seeing the world one way. I woke up seeing it another.

author: Melvin Burgess
title: Junk
opening_line: A boy and girl were spending the night together in the back seat of a Volvo estate car. The car was in a garage. It was pitch black.

author: Oliver Burkeman
title: Four Thousand Weeks
opening_line: The average human lifespan is absurdly, terrifyingly, insultingly short.

author: Leo Buscaglia
title: Living, Loving & Learning
opening_line: Nikos Kazantzakis suggests that ideal teachers are those who use themselves as bridges over which they invite their students to cross, then having facilitated their crossing, joyfully collapse, encouraging them to create bridges of their own.

author: Albert Camus
title: The Stranger
opening_line: Mother died today. Or maybe, yesterday; I can’t be sure.

author: Albert Camus
title: The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays
opening_line: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is suicide.

author: Richard Carlson
title: Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff…and It’s All Small Stuff
opening_line: Whenever we’re dealing with bad news, a difficult person, or a disappointment of some kind, most of us get into certain habits, ways of reacting to life—particularly adversity—that don’t serve us very well.

author: Casey Cep
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: It’s a good time to be dead—at least, if you want to keep in touch with the living.

author: Terri Cheney
title: Manic
opening_line: If you come with me on this journey, I think a word of warning is in order: manic depression is not a safe ride.

author: Terri Cheney
title: Modern Madness
opening_line: I was sitting next to Michael Jackson, admiring his feet.

author: E. M. Cioran
title: The Art of the Personal Essay
opening_line: Every form of talent involves a certain shamelessness.

author: Norman Cousins
title: Anatomy of an Illness
opening_line: This book is about a serious illness that occurred in 1964. I was reluctant to write about it for many years because I was fearful of creating false hopes in others who were similarly afflicted. Moreover, I knew that a single case has small standing in the annals of medical research, having little more than “anecdotal” or “testimonial” value.

author: Richard Dawkins
title: The Selfish Gene
opening_line: Intelligent life on a planet comes of age when it first works out the reason for its own existence.

author: Richard Dawkins
title: Time
opening_line: Years ago, in an Oxford tutorial, I taught a young woman who affected an unusual habit. When asked a question that required deep thought, she would screw her eyes tight shut, jerk her head down to her chest and then freeze for up to half a minute before looking up, opening her eyes and answering the question with fluency and intelligence.

author: Simone de Beauvoir
title: The Second Sex,
opening_line: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.

author: Gavin de Becker
title: The Gift of Fear
opening_line: He had probably been watching her for a while. We aren’t sure—but what we do know is that she was not his first victim.

author: Belle de Jour
title: Belle de Jour’s Guide to Men
opening_line: You might be wondering what, exactly, a prostitute might have to say about men and relationships… [ellipsis in original] Let’s put it this way: I have met men. Loads of men. Men of every conceivable shape, size, and type. In my work as a call girl, I have seen them at their most cocksure and at their most vulnerable. And if this experience has taught me anything at all, it is that this odd and inscrutable species we call Man is often libelously misrepresented in the female press.

author: Karl De Schweinitz
title: The Art of Helping People Out of Trouble
opening_line: Living has yet to be generally recognized as one of the arts.

author: Colin Dickey
title: Under the Eye of Power
opening_line: The United States was born in paranoia.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The Extraordinary Healing Power of Ordinary Things
opening_line: There is an old saying: If you want to hide the treasure, put it in plain sight. Then no one will see it.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The Power of Premonitions
opening_line: Sometimes things grab hold and just won’t let go.

author: Larry Dossey
title: Reinventing Medicine
opening_line: During my first year of medical practice, I had a dream that shook my world.

author: Larry Dossey
title: The New Science and Spirituality Reader
opening_line: What is spirituality? I consider it a felt sense of connectedness with something higher, a presence that transcends the individual sense of self.

author: Arthur Conan Doyle
title: The Sign of the Four
opening_line: Sherlock Holmes took his bottle from the corner of his mantelpiece, and his hypodermic syringe from its neat Morocco case. With his long, white nervous fingers he adjusted the delicate needle and rolled back his left shirt cuff.

author: Peter F. Drucker
title: Adventures of a Bystander
opening_line: Bystanders have no history of their own. They are on the stage but are not part of the action. They are not even audience. The fortunes of the play and of every actor in it depend on the audience whereas the reaction of the bystander has no effect except on himself.

author: Peter F. Drucker
title: Harvard Business Review
opening_line: History’s great achievers—a Napoleon, a da Vinci, a Mozart—have always managed themselves. That, in large measure, is what makes them great achievers.

author: Linnda Durré
title: Surviving the Toxic Workplace
opening_line: Do you dread getting out of bed each day and dealing with bosses and co-workers who drive you crazy? Are you surrounded by people who are incompetent, negative, verbally abusive, and impossible to deal with? Have you asked the human resources department for help, yet nothing changes?

author: Wayne W. Dyer
title: Your Erroneous Zones
opening_line: Look over your shoulder. You will notice a constant companion. For want of a better name, call him Your-Own-Death. You can fear this visitor or use him for your personal gain. The choice is up to you.

author: Wayne W. Dyer
title: Inspiration
opening_line: I love being inspired, and I trust that the idea of living an inspired life appeals to you as well.

author: Nora Ephron
title: I Remember Nothing
opening_line: I know you. I know you well. It’s true I always have a little trouble with your name, but I do know your name. I just don’t know it at this moment.

author: Joseph Epstein
title: Ambition

opening_line: When I walked into the bar and saw him on the corner stool alone, I could tell something was wrong.

title: Les Misérables
opening_line: In the year 1815 Monseigneur Charles-François-Bienvenu Myriel was Bishop of Digne. He was then about seventy-five, having held the bishopric since 1806.

author: William Bradford Huie
title: The Revolt of Mamie Stover
opening_line: A six-foot-tall, yellow-haired whore from Mississippi was the most successful revolutionary of the Second War. Her name was Mamie Stover.

author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God
opening_line: Ships at a distance have every man’s wish on board.

author: Francis Iles (pen name of Anthony Berkeley Cox)
title: Malice Aforethought
opening_line: It was not until several weeks after he had decided to murder his wife that Dr. Bickleigh took any active steps in the matter.

author: Greg Iles
title: The Quiet Game
opening_line: I am standing in line for Walt Disney’s It’s a Small World ride, holding my four-year-old daughter in my arms, trying to entertain her as the serpentine line of parents and children moves slowly toward the flat-bottomed boats emerging from the grotto to the music of an endless audio loop. Suddenly Annie jerks taut in my arms and points into the crowd. “Daddy! I saw Mama! Hurry!” I do not look. I don’t ask where. I don’t because Annie’s mother died seven months ago. I stand motionless in the line, looking just like everyone else except for the hot tears that have begun to sting my eyes.

author: John Irving
title: The World According to Garp
opening_line: Garp’s mother, Jenny Fields, was arrested in Boston in 1942 for wounding a man in a movie theater. This was shortly after the Japanese had bombed Pearl Harbor and people were being tolerant of soldiers, because suddenly everyone was a soldier, but Jenny Fields was quite firm in her intolerance of the behavior of men in general and soldiers in particular.

author: John Irving
title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
opening_line: I am doomed to remember a boy with a wrecked voice—not because of his voice, or because he was the smallest person I ever knew, or even because he was the instrument of my mother’s death, but because he is the reason I believe in God; I am a Christian because of Owen Meany.

author: John Irving
title: Last Night in Twisted River
opening_line: The young Canadian, who could not have been more than fifteen, had hesitated too long. For a frozen moment, his feet had stopped moving on the floating logs in the basin above the river bend; he’d slipped entirely underwater before anyone could grab his outstretched hand.

author: John Irving
title: In One Person
opening_line: I’m going to begin by telling you about Miss Frost. While I say to everyone that I became a writer because I read a certain novel by Charles Dickens at the formative age of fifteen, the truth is I was younger than that when I first met Miss Frost and imagined having sex with her, and this moment of my sexual awakening also marked the fitful birth of my imagination.

author: Kazuo Ishiguro
title: A Pale View of the Hills
opening_line: Niki, the name we finally gave my younger daughter, is not an abbreviation; it was a compromise I reached with her father. For paradoxically it was he who wanted to give her a Japanese name, and I—perhaps out of some selfish desire not to be reminded of the past—insisted on an English one. He finally agreed to Niki, thinking it had some vague echo of the East about it.

author: Kazuo Ishiguro
title: The Remains of the Day
opening_line: It seems increasingly likely that I really will undertake the expedition that has been preoccupying my imagination now for some days.

author: Kazuo Ishiguro
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: There was a time when I could travel England for weeks on end and remain at my sharpest—when if anything, the travelling gave me an edge. But now that I am older I become disoriented more easily.

author: Kazuo Ishiguro
title: Klara and the Sun
opening_line: When we were new, Rosa and I were mid-store, on the magazines table side, and could see through more than half the window.

author: Jeff Jacoby
title: The Boston Globe
opening_line: They were nice to my father the second time he went to Auschwitz.

author: Henry James
title: Harper’s New Monthly Magazine
opening_line: Never say you know the last word about any human heart!

author: Morgan Jerkins
title: Wandering in Strange Lands
opening_line: I was seven years old when I learned that I wasn’t my father’s only daughter.

author: Ha Jin
title: Waiting
opening_line: Every summer Lin Kong returned to Goose Village to divorce his wife, Shuyu.

author: Brian Johnson
title: The Lives of Brian
opening_line: The soundtrack of my early childhood was the clatter of my mother’s sewing machine, followed by the muffled sobs of her crying herself to sleep every night downstairs.

author: Gareth P. Jones
title: The Thornthwaite Inheritance
opening_line: Lorelli and Ovid Thornthwaite had been trying to kill each other for so long that neither twin could remember which act of attempted murder came first.

author: Gareth P. Jones
title: Constable & Toop
opening_line: In her last few moments of life, as the blood gushed from the knife wound in her neck, Emily Wilkins found her thoughts drifting to her mother’s death.

author: Erica Jong
title: Fear of Flying
opening_line: There were 117 psychoanalysts on the Pan Am flight to Vienna and I’d been treated by at least six of them. And married a seventh.

author: Erica Jong
title: How to Save Your Own Life
opening_line: I left my husband on Thanksgiving Day. It was nine years since I met him and almost that long since I married him—time enough to know something isn’t working, and yet it wasn’t easy.

author: Erica Jong
title: Parachutes and Kisses
opening_line: Isadora, separated from Josh, is like a kid in her twenties. Only like the kid she never was in her twenties—almost carefree. At thirty-nine, she finds herself possessed of a demoniacal sexuality—which has no need to justify itself with love.

author: Erica Jong
title: Inventing Memory
opening_line: Sometimes, in dreams, my firstborn son comes back to me. I think he is my guardian angel. “Mama, Mamichka, Mamanyu, Mamale,“ he says, let me warn you...“

author: Erica Jong
title: Fear of Dying
opening_line: I used to love the power I had over men.

author: Han Kang
title: The Vegetarian
opening_line: Before my wife turned vegetarian, I'd always thought of her as completely unremarkable in every way.

author: Mary Karr
title: The Liar’s Club
opening_line: Not long before my mother died, the tile guy redoing her kitchen pried from the wall a tile with an unlikely round hole in it. He sat back on his knees and held the tile up so the sun through aged yellow curtains seemed to pierce the hole like a laser. He winked at my sister Lecia and me before turning to my gray-haired mother, now bent over her copy of Marcus Aurelius and a bowl of sinus-opening chili, and he quipped, “Now Miss Karr, this looks like a bullet hole.“ Lecia didn’t miss a beat, saying, “Mother, isn’t that where you shot at daddy?“ And Mother squinted up, slid her glasses down her patrician-looking nose and said, very blasé?, “No, that’s where I shot at Larry.“ She wheeled to point at another wall, adding, “Over there’s where I shot at your daddy.“

author: Mary Karr
title: Cherry
opening_line: No road offers more mystery than that first one you mount from the town you were born to, the first time you mount it of your own volition, on a trip funded by your own coffee tin of wrinkled up dollars—bills you’ve saved and scrounged for, worked the all-night switchboard for, missed the Rolling Stones for, sold fragrant pot with smashed flowers going brown inside twist-tie plastic baggies for. In fact, to disembark from your origins, you’ve done everything you can think to scrounge money save selling your spanking young pussy.

author: Mary Karr
title: Lit
opening_line: Any way I tell this story is a lie, so I ask you to disconnect the device in your head that repeats at intervals how ancient and addled I am.

author: Lauren Kate
title: The Betrayal of Natalie Hargrove
opening_line: Once upon a time you knew nothing. It wasn’t your fault—you were just a kid. And growing up where you did, most people assumed that this was for the best. The longer it took a small town southern girl to catch on to the backward ways of her world, the better off everyone was.

author: Bel Kaufman
title: Love, etc.
opening_line: And they lived happily ever after. Well, not exactly. Actually, not at all. As a matter of fact, miserably. To tell the truth, their life together was sheer hell, and their struggles to free themselves from each other were disastrous.

author: Brian Keene
title: Jack’s Magic Beans
opening_line: The lettuce started talking to Ben Mahoney halfway through his shift at Save-A-Lot.

author: Brian Keene
title: The Complex
opening_line: When everyone starts killing each other, Sam doesn’t notice at first because he’s too busy preparing to kill himself.

author: Caroline Kepnes
title: You
opening_line: You walk into the bookstore and you keep your hand on the door to make sure it doesn’t slam. You smile, embarrassed to be a nice girl, and your nails are bare and your V-neck sweater is beige and it’s impossible to know if you’re wearing a bra but I don’t think that you are.

author: Ian Kerner
title: She Comes First
opening_line: The premise of this book is simple: when it comes to pleasuring women and conversing in the language of love, cunnilingus should be every man’s native tongue.

author: Alicia Keyes
title: More Myself
opening_line: I am seven. My mom and I are side by side in the back seat of a yellow taxi, making our way up Eleventh Avenue in Manhattan on a dead-cold day in December. We hardly ever take cabs. They’re a luxury for a single parent and part-time actress. But on this afternoon, maybe because Mom has just finished an audition near my school, PS 116 on East Thirty-third Street, or maybe because it’s so freezing we can see our breath, she picks me up.

author: Sue Monk Kidd
title: The Secret Life of Bees
opening_line: At night I would lie in bed and watch the show, how bees squeezed through the cracks of my bedroom wall and flew circles around the room, making that propeller sound, a high-pitched zzzzzz that hummed along my skin. I watched their wings shining like bits of chrome in the dark and felt the longing build in my chest. The way those bees flew, not even looking for a flower, just flying for the feel of the wind, split my heart down its seam.

author: Sue Monk Kidd
title: The Mermaid Chair
opening_line: In the middle of my marriage, when I was above all Hugh’s wife and Dee’s mother, one of those unambiguous women with no desire to disturb the universe, I fell in love with a Benedictine monk.

author: Sue Monk Kidd
title: The Book of Longings
opening_line: I am Ana. I was the wife of Jesus ben Joseph of Nazareth. I called him Beloved and he, laughing, called me Little Thunder.

author: Lily King
title: The English Teacher
opening_line: October, 1979 That she had not killed him in her sleep was still the great relief of every morning.

author: Lily King
title: Euphoria
opening_line: As they were leaving the Mumbanyo, someone threw something at them. It bobbed a few yards from the stern of the canoe. A pale brown thing. “Another dead baby,” Fen said.

author: Lily King
title: Writers and Lovers
opening_line: I have a pact with myself not to think about money in the morning. I’m like a teenager trying not to think about sex. Or Luke. Or death. Which means not thinking about my mother, who died on vacation last winter. There are so many things I can’t think about in order to write in the morning.

author: Stephen King
title: The Girl who Loved Tom Gordon
opening_line: The world had teeth and it could bite you with them anytime it wanted.

author: Stephen King
title: Lisey’s Story
opening_line: To the public eye, the spouses of well-known writers are all but invisible, and no one knew it better than Lisey Landon.

author: Stephen King
title: The Paris Review
opening_line: I didn’t think I would ever tell this story. My wife told me not to; she said no one would believe it and I’d only embarrass myself. What she meant, of course, was that it would embarrass her.

author: Stephen King
title: Joyland
opening_line: I had a car, but on most days in that fall of 1973 I walked to Joyland from Mrs. Shoplaw’s Beachside Accommodations in the town of Heaven’s Bay. It seemed like the right thing to do. The only thing, actually.

author: Stephen King
title: Later
opening_line: I don’t like to start with an apology—there’s probably even a rule against it—but after reading over the first thirty pages I’ve written so far, I feel like I have to.

author: Tabitha King
title: Survivor
opening_line: The girls came from nowhere, emerging from darkness suddenly, into the street directly in front of her.

author: Barbara Kingsolver
title: The Bean Trees
opening_line: I have been afraid of putting air in a tire ever since I saw a tractor tire blow up and throw Newt Hardbine’s father over the top of the Standard Oil sign. I’m not lying. He got stuck up there.

author: Barbara Kingsolver
title: Flight Behavior
opening_line: A certain feeling comes from throwing your good life away, and it is one part rapture. Or so it seemed for now, to a woman with flame-colored hair who marched uphill to meet her demise.

author: Laura Kipnis
title: Men
opening_line: Men have fascinated me, maybe too much. They’ve troubled me. They’re large and take up a lot of space—space in the imagination, I mean. They force you to think about them.

author: Milan Kundera
title: The Festival of Insignificance
opening_line: It was the month of June, the morning sun was emerging from the clouds, and Alain was walking slowly down a Paris street. He observed the young girls, who—every one of them—showed her naked navel between trousers belted very low and a T-shirt cut very short.

author: Stephanie LaCava
title: An Extraordinary Theory of Objects
opening_line: I was always strange.

author: Catherine Lacey
title: Nobody is Ever Missing
opening_line: There might be people in this world who can read minds against their will and if that kind of person exists I am pretty sure my husband is one of them. I think this because of what happened the week I knew I’d be leaving soon, but he didn’t know.

author: Catherine Lacey
title: The Answers
opening_line: I’d run out of options. That’s how these things usually happen, how a person ends up placing all her last hopes on a stranger, hoping that whatever that stranger might do to her would be the thing she needed done to her.

author: Laila Lalami
title: The Other Americans
opening_line: My father was killed on a spring night four years ago, while I sat in the corner booth of a new bistro in Oakland.

author: Wally Lamb
title: I Know This Much Is True
opening_line: On the afternoon of October 12, 1990, my twin brother Thomas entered the Three Rivers, Connecticut Public Library, retreated to one of the rear study carrels, and prayed to God the sacrifice he was about to commit would be deemed acceptable.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Hard Laughter
opening_line: My family lived for fifteen years in a castle built more than a century ago by an eccentric man who wanted his Rhine-born wife to feel at home when he brought her to live in California.

author: Anne Lamott
title: All New People
opening_line: I am living once again in the town where I grew up, having returned here several weeks ago in a state of dull torment for which the Germans probably have a word.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Blue Shoes
opening_line: The world outside the window was in flames. The leaves on the pistachio trees shone fire-red and orange. Mattie studied the early morning light. She was lying on the side of the bed where her husband should have been sleeping.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Imperfect Birds
opening_line: There are so many evils that pull on our children. Even in the mellow town of Landsdale, where it is easy to see only beauty and decency, a teenager died nearly every year after a party and kids routinely went from high school to psych wards, halfway houses, or jail. Once a year a child from the county of Marin jumped off the Golden Gate Bridge.

author: D. H. Lawrence
title: Lady Chatterley’s Lover
opening_line: Ours is essentially a tragic age, so we refuse to take it tragically.

author: Jenny Lawson
title: Let’s Pretend This Never Happened
opening_line: This book is totally true, except for the parts that aren’t. It’s basically like Little House on the Prairie but with more cursing.

author: Wendy Lazar
title: Day-by-Day and Heart-to-Heart
opening_line: I arrived October 6, 1964, knowing only one word of Japanese: Sayonara.

author: Jane Leavy
title: Squeeze Play
opening_line: Opening Day April 3 You see a lot of penises in my line of work: short ones, stubby ones, hard ones, soft ones. Circumcised and uncircumcised; laid-back and athletic.

author: Richard Lederer
title: The Cunning Linguist
opening_line: In a junior high-school biology class the teacher asks a student, “Mary please name the part of the human body that expands to six times its normal size and explain under what conditions.” Blushing bright red, Mary simpers, “Teacher that is not a proper question to ask me, and I can’t answer it in front of the class.” The teacher turns to another student and asks, “All right, Johnny, do you have the answer?” “The pupil of the eye, and in dim light.”

author: Harper Lee
title: To Kill a Mockingbird
opening_line: When he was nearly thirteen, my brother Jem got his arm badly broken at the elbow. When it healed, and Jem’s fears of never being able to play football were assuaged, he was seldom self-conscious about his injury. His left arm was somewhat shorter than his right; when he stood or walked, the back of his hand was at right angles to his body, his thumb parallel to his thigh. He couldn’t have cared less, so long as he could pass and punt.

author: Mackenzi Lee
title: The Gentleman’s Guide to Vice and Virtue
opening_line: On the morning we are to leave for our Grand Tour of the Continent, I wake up in bed beside Percy. For a disorienting moment, it’s unclear whether we’ve slept together or simply slept together.

author: Dennis Lehane
title: The Atlantic
opening_line: Your father picks you up from prison in a stolen Dodge Neon, with an 8-ball of coke in the glove compartment and a hooker named Mandy in the back seat.

author: Eva Leigh
title: The Good Girl’s Guide to Rakes
opening_line: London, England, 1818 The wedding hadn’t happened yet, and already the marriage was a disaster.

author: Raven Leilani
title: Luster
opening_line: The first time we have sex, we are both fully clothed, at our desks during working hours, bathed in blue computer light.

author: Elmore Leonard
title: The Tonto Woman and Other Western Stories
opening_line: A time would come, within a few years, when Ruben Vega would go to the church in Benson, kneel in the confessional, and say to the priest, “Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. It has been thirty-seven years since my last confession.”

author: Billie Letts
title: Where the Heart Is
opening_line: Novalee Nation, seventeen, seven months pregnant, thirty-seven pounds overweight—and superstitious about sevens—shifted uncomfortably in the seat of the old Plymouth and ran her hands down the curve of her belly.

author: Billie Letts
title: Made in the U.S.A.
opening_line: Lutie McFee struggled into the too tight red, sleeveless turtleneck, smoothed it across her ribs, then checked herself out in the mirror of the Wal-Mart dressing room.

author: Katia Lief
title: Invisible Woman
opening_line: The first time the thought came to her, with clarity instead of anger, it was a warm evening in June not long before the party that was supposed to launch a new phase of her husband’s brilliant career. She was standing at the kitchen sink sponging tomato sauce off a white plate. She rinsed it and set it dripping in the dish drainer, then picked up a wineglass and scrubbed at a haze of lip gloss biting the rim. She put the glass down but left the water running, as if the sound could blot out her thoughts, as if he could hear them through the linkage of empty rooms. What if I killed him?

author: Laura Lippman
title: By a Spider’s Thread
opening_line: They were in one of the “I” states when Zeke told Isaac he had to ride in the trunk for a little while.

author: Laura Lippman
title: Longreads.com
opening_line: My daughter was 10 days old the first time I was asked if I were her grandmother.

author: Patricia Lockwood
title: Priestdaddy
opening_line: “Before they allowed your father to be a priest,” my mother tells me, “they made me take the Psychopath Test. You know, a priest can’t have a psychopath wife, it would bring disgrace.”

author: Robert Hill Long
title: Flash Fiction: Very Short Stories
opening_line: Even when she was very little her hunger was worth something: hunger taught her to dance, and her father noticed.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: My mother was seeing another man. His name was Willy.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: I grew up in the era of the great Jewish Lovers.

author: Charlie Lovett
title: The Fat Lady Sings
opening_line: Cynthia Pirelli’s boobs are soooo fake.

author: Karen Martin
title: The Bringer of Happiness
opening_line: I should have assumed with parents known to the world as Mary Magdalene and Jesus Christ, I would be different.

author: Ilana Masad
title: All My Mother’s Lovers
opening_line: Maggie is in the midst of a second lazy orgasm when her brother, Ariel, calls to tell her their mother has died.

author: Armistead Maupin
title: Michael Tolliver Lives
opening_line: Not long ago, down on Castro Street, a stranger in a Giants parka gave me a loaded glance as we passed each other in front of Cliff’s Hardware.

author: Rollo May
title: Love and Will
opening_line: The striking thing about love and will in our day is that, whereas in the past they were always held up to us as the answer to life’s predicaments, they have now themselves become the problem.

author: Alexander McCall Smith
title: The Great Hippopotamus Hotel
opening_line: Mma Ramotswe had always understood that people who are one thing may at the same time be another. This insight, although not entirely original, is undoubtedly quite true. Embodying more than one identity is part of being human—and one of the things of which we might be justifiably proud.

author: Cormac McCarthy
title: The Road
opening_line: When he woke in the woods in the dark and the cold of the night he’d reach out to touch the child sleeping beside him. Nights dark beyond darkness and the days more gray each one than what had gone before. Like the onset of some cold glaucoma dimming away the world.

author: Cormac McCarthy
title: The Passenger
opening_line: It had snowed lightly in the night and her frozen hair was gold and crystalline and her eyes were frozen cold and hard as stones.

author: Frank McCourt
title: Angela’s Ashes
opening_line: My father and mother should have stayed in New York where they met and married and where I was born. Instead, they returned to Ireland when I was four, my brother, Malachy, three, the twins, Oliver and Eugene, barely one, and my sister, Margaret, dead and gone.

author: Elizabeth McCracken
title: The Hero of This Book
opening_line: This was the summer before the world stopped.

author: George Barr McCutcheon
title: Brewster’s Millions
opening_line: “The Little Sons of the Rich” were gathered about the long table in Pettingill’s studio. There were nine of them present, besides Brewster. They were all young, more or less enterprising, hopeful, and reasonably sure of better things to come. Most of them bore names that meant something in the story of New York. Indeed, one of them had remarked, “A man is known by the street that’s named after him,“ and as he was a new member, they called him “Subway.“

author: George Barr McCutcheon
title: A Fool and His Money
opening_line: I am quite sure it was my Uncle Rilas who said that I was a fool.

author: Freida McFadden
title: The Teacher
opening_line: Digging a grave is hard work.

author: Frieda McFadden
title: The Housemaid
opening_line: If I leave this house, it will be in handcuffs.

author: Frieda McFadden
title: The Housemaid’s Secret
opening_line: Tonight, I will be murdered.

author: Frieda McFadden
title: The Housemaid is Watching
opening_line: There’s blood everywhere

author: Thomas McGuane
title: Cloudbursts: Collected and New Stories
opening_line: The Smiths were a very old couple, whose lifelong habits of exercise and outdoor living and careful diet had resulted in their seeming tiny—tiny, pale and almost totemic—as they spread a picnic tablecloth on my front lawn and arranged their luncheon.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Ten years before Joan Krebs left her husband, Roger, and moved back to Cincinnati, I spotted the two of them dining alone by the bricked-up fireplace in the Old Eagle Grill. She was a devoted daughter, her father a sportsman with well-bred dogs, who arrived once a year to peer at Roger and inspect the marriage.

author: Jay McInerney
title: Brightness Falls
opening_line: The last time I saw Russell and Corrine together was the weekend of the final softball game between the addicts and the depressives.

author: Erin McKean
title: The Secret Lives of Dresses
opening_line: Dora had a rhythm going, or if not a rhythm, a pattern, and it went something like downshift, wipe tears away with back of hand, sob, upshift, scrub running nose with horrible crumpled fast-food napkin, stab at the buttons on the radio, and then downshift again.

author: Terry McMillan
title: Waiting to Exhale
opening_line: Right now I’m supposed to be all geeked up because I’m getting ready for a New Year’s Eve party that some guy named Lionel invited me to.

author: Terry McMillan
title: The Interruption of Everything
opening_line: The only reason I’m sitting on a toilet seat in the handicapped stall of the ladies’ room is because I’m hiding.

author: Larry McMurtry
title: Terms of Endearment
opening_line: “The success of a marriage invariably depends on the woman,” Mrs. Greenway said. “It does not,” Emma said, not looking up. She was sitting in the middle of her living-room floor sorting a large pile of laundry.

author: Larry McMurtry
title: Sin Killer
opening_line: In the darkness beyond the great Missouri’s shore at last lay the West, toward which Tasmin and her family, the numerous Berrybenders, had so long been tending.

author: Grace Metalious
title: Peyton Place
opening_line: Indian summer is like a woman. Ripe, hotly passionate, but fickle, she comes and goes as she pleases so that one is never sure whether she will come at all, nor for how long she will stay.

author: Stephenie Meyer
title: Twilight
opening_line: I’d never given much thought to how I would die–though I’d had reason enough in the last few months–but even if I had, I would not have imagined it like this.

author: Stephenie Meyer
title: New Moon
opening_line: I felt like I was trapped in one of those terrifying nightmares, the one where you have to run, run till your lungs burst, but you can’t make your body move fast enough.

author: Stephenie Meyer
title: Eclipse
opening_line: All our attempts at subterfuge had been in vain

author: Alex Michaelides
title: The Silent Patient
opening_line: Alicia Berenson was thirty-three years old when she killed her husband.

author: Ammi Midstokke
title: The Spokesman-Review
opening_line: Recently, while criticizing my husband for something flawed in his person, like how he laces his boots or something, I was struck by a realization. Either I am perfect or my husband enjoys the relative peace that reigns when we both pretend I am.

author: Henry Miller
title: Tropic of Cancer
opening_line: I am living at the Villa Borghese. There is not a crumb of dirt anywhere, nor a chair misplaced. We are all alone here and we are dead.

author: Henry Miller
title: Tropic of Capricorn
opening_line: Once you have given up the ghost, everything follows with dead certainty, even in the midst of chaos.

author: Henry Miller
title: Sexus
opening_line: It must have been a Thursday night when I met her for the first time—at the dance hall. I reported to work in the morning, after an hour or two’s sleep, looking like a somnambulist.

author: Henry Miller
title: Plexus
opening_line: In her tight-fitting Persian dress, with turban to match, she looked ravishing. Spring had come and she had donned a pair of long gloves and a beautiful taupe fur slung carelessly about her full columnar neck. We had chosen Brooklyn Heights in which to search for an apartment, thinking to get as far away as possible from everyone we knew….

author: Sue Miller
title: The Distinguished Guest
opening_line: In 1982, when she was seventy-two years old, Lily Roberts Maynard published her first book.

author: Dan Millman
title: Everyday Enlightenment
opening_line: One night, years ago, I fell into the depths of despair over a woman I loved and was losing.

author: David Mitchell
title: The Bone Clocks
opening_line: I fling open my bedroom curtains, and there’s the thirsty sky and the wide river full of ships and boats and stuff, but I’m already thinking of Vinny’s chocolaty eyes, shampoo down Vinny’s back, beads of sweat on Vinny’s shoulders, and Vinny’s sly laugh, and by now my heart’s going mental and, God, I wish I was waking up at Vinny’s place in Peacock Street and not in my own stupid bedroom.

author: Margaret Mitchell
title: Gone With the Wind
opening_line: Scarlett O’Hara was not beautiful, but men seldom realized it when caught by her charms as the Tarleton twins were.

author: Nancy Mitford
title: The Pursuit of Love
opening_line: There is a photograph in existence of Aunt Sadie and her six children sitting round the tea-table at Alconleigh. The table is situated, as it was, is now, and ever shall be, in the hall, in front of a huge open fire of logs. Over the chimney-piece plainly visible in the photograph, hangs an entrenching tool, with which, in 1915, Uncle Matthew had whacked to death eight Germans one by one as they crawled out of a dug-out.

author: Desmond Morris
title: The Naked Ape
opening_line: There are one hundred and ninety-three living species of monkeys and apes. One hundred and ninety-two of them are covered with hair. The exception is a naked ape self-named Homo sapiens.

author: Chandler Morrison
title: American Narcissus
opening_line: Only lies are sexy.

author: Toni Morrison
title: Beloved
opening_line: 124 was spiteful.

author: Haruki Murakami
title: After Dark
opening_line: Eyes mark the shape of the city.

author: Iris Murdoch
title: The Bell
opening_line: Dora Greenfield left her husband because she was afraid of him. She decided six months later to return to him for the same reason.

author: Iris Murdoch
title: A Severed Head
opening_line: “You’re sure she doesn’t know,” said Georgie. “Antonia? About us? Certain.”

author: Iris Murdoch
title: The Nice and the Good
opening_line: A head of department, working quietly in his room in Whitehall on a summer afternoon, is not accustomed to being disturbed by the nearby and indubitable sound of a revolver shot.

author: Iris Murdoch
title: The Black Prince
opening_line: It might be most dramatically effective to begin the tale at the moment when Arnold Baffin rang me up and said, “Bradley, could you come round here please, I think that I have just killed my wife.”

author: Caitlin Myer
title: Wiving
opening_line: I am fifty years old and have just moved to a seaside town in Portugal. I’m reading in a quiet bar when a man asks why a beautiful woman like me is alone. What he means is, What is happening between your legs? What he means is, You are breaking the rules of the story, but I can set you straight. What he means is, I can fill that terrible gap between your legs.

author: Vladimir Nabokov
title: Lolita
opening_line: Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul. Lo-lee-ta: the tip of the tongue taking a trip of three steps down the palate to tap, at three, on the teeth. Lo. Lee. Ta.

author: N. Richard Nash
title: Cry Macho
opening_line: He was not yet within sight of the ravine when Mike heard the first shot.

author: T. J. Newman
title: Falling
opening_line: When the shoe dropped into her lap the foot was still in it.

author: Audrey Niffenegger
title: The Time Traveller’s Wife
opening_line: It’s hard being left behind. I wait for Henry, not knowing where he is, wondering if he’s okay. It’s hard to be the one who stays.

author: Audrey Niffennegger
title: Her Fearful Symmetry
opening_line: Elspeth died while Robert was standing in front of a vending machine watching tea shoot into a small plastic cup. Later he would remember walking down the hospital corridor with the cup of horrible tea in his hand, alone under the fluorescent lights, retracing his steps to the room where Elspeth lay surrounded by machines. She had turned her head towards the door and her eyes were open; at first Robert thought she was conscious.

author: David Niven
title: The Moon’s a Balloon
opening_line: Nessie, when I first saw her, was seventeen years old, honey-blond, pretty rather than beautiful, the owner of a voluptuous but somehow innocent body and a pair of legs that went on for ever. She was a Picadilly whore. I was a fourteen-year-old heterosexual schoolboy and I met her thanks to my stepfather. (If you would like to skip on and meet Nessie more fully, she reappears on page 41.)

author: Trevor Noah
title: Born a Crime
opening_line: The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all.

author: Liz Nugent
title: Unraveling Oliver
opening_line: I expected more of a reaction the first time I hit her.

author: Liz Nugent
title: Lying in Wait
opening_line: My husband did not mean to kill Annie Doyle, but the lying tramp deserved it.

author: Liz Nugent
title: Skin Deep
opening_line: Once I had cleared the bottles away and washed the blood off the floor, I needed to get out of the flat.

author: Liz Nugent
title: Little Cruelties
opening_line: All three of the Drumm brothers were at the funeral, although one of us was in a coffin.

author: Liz Nugent
title: Strange Sally Diamond
opening_line: “Put me out with the trash,” he said, regularly. “When I die, put me out with the trash. I’ll be dead, so I won’t know any different. You’ll be crying your eyes out,” and he would laugh and I’d laugh too because we both knew that I wouldn’t be crying my eyes out. I never cry.

author: Edna O’Brien
title: Girls in Their Married Bliss
opening_line: Not long ago Kate Brady and I were having a few gloomy gin fizzes up London, bemoaning the fact that nothing would ever improve, that we’d die the way we were—enough to eat, married, dissatisfied.

author: Tim O’Brien
title: The Things They Carried
opening_line: First Lieutenant Jimmy Cross carried letters from a girl named Martha, a Junior at Mount Sebastian College in New Jersey. They were not love letters, but Lieutenant Cross was hoping, so he kept them folded in in plastic at the bottom of his rucksack.

author: Tim O’Brien
title: July, July
opening_line: The reunion dance had started only an hour ago, but already a good many of the dancers were tipsy, and most others were well along, and now the gossip was flowing and confessions were under way and old flames were being extinguished and rekindled under cardboard stars in the Darton Hall College gymnasium.

author: Flannery O’Connor
title: Accent: A Quarterly of New Literature
opening_line: Old Dudley folded into the chair he was gradually molding to his own shape and looked out the window fifteen feet away into another window framed by blackened brick. He was waiting for the geranium. They put it out every morning about ten and they took it in at five-thirty.

author: Flannery O’Connor
title: Wise Blood
opening_line: Hazel Motes sat at a forward angle on the green plush train seat, looking one minute at the window as if he might want to jump out of it, and the next down the aisle at the other end of the car.

author: Flannery O’Connor
title: The Violent Bear It Away
opening_line: Francis Marion Tarwater’s uncle had been dead for only half a day when the boy got too drunk to finish digging his grave and a Negro named Buford Munson, who had come to get a jug filled, had to finish it and drag the body from the breakfast table where it was still sitting and bury it in a decent and Christian way, with the sign of its Saviour at the head of the grave and enough dirt on top to keep the dogs from digging it up.

author: Flannery O’Connor
title: The Sewanee Review
opening_line: The doctor’s waiting room, which was very small, was almost full when the Turpins entered and Mrs. Turpin, who was very large, made it look even smaller by her presence.

author: Maggie O’Farrell
title: I Am, I Am, I Am
opening_line: On the path ahead, stepping out from behind a boulder, a man appears. We are, he and I, on the far side of a dark tarn that lies hidden in the bowl-curved summit of this mountain. The sky is a milky blue above us; no vegetation grows this far up so it is just me and him, the stones and the still black water. He straddles the narrow track with both booted feet and he smiles. I realize several things. That I passed him earlier, farther down the glen. We greeted each other, in the amiable yet brief manner of those on a country walk. That, on this remote stretch of path, there is no one near enough to hear me call. That he has been waiting for me: he has planned this whole thing, carefully, meticulously, and I have walked into his trap. I see all this, in an instant

author: Tracy O’Neill
title: Woman of Interest
opening_line: A few years back, despite a lifelong renunciation of the urge, I surrendered to obsession with a woman. So I was beside myself.

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: Expensive People
opening_line: I was a child murderer. I don’t mean child-murderer, though that’s an idea. I mean child murderer, that is, a murderer who happens to be a child, or a child who happens to be a murderer. You can take your choice.

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: You Must Remember This
opening_line: She had been waiting for a sign to release her into Death, now the sign was granted. She swallowed forty-seven aspirin tablets between 1:10 A.M. and 1:35 A.M. locked in the bathroom of her parents’ rented house.

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: Because It is Bitter, and Because It is My Heart
opening_line: “Little Red” Garlock, sixteen years old, skull smashed soft as a rotted pumpkin and body dumped into the Cassadaga River near the foot of Pitt Street, must not have sunk as he’d been intended to sink, or floated as far. As the morning mist begins to lift from the river a solitary fisherman sights him, or the body he has become, trapped and bobbing frantically in pilings about thirty feet offshore.

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: My Life as a Rat
opening_line: Once I’d been Daddy’s favorite of his seven kids. Before something terrible happened between us, I am trying still to make it right.

author: Lauren Oliver
title: Delirium
opening_line: It has been sixty-four years since the president and the Consortium identified love as a disease, and forty-three since the scientists perfected a cure.

author: Michael Ondaatje
title: Warlight
opening_line: In 1945 our parents went away and left us in the care of two men who may have been criminals.

author: Delia Owens
title: Where the Crawdads Sing
opening_line: The morning burned so August-hot, the marsh’s moist breath hung the oaks and pines with fog. The palmetto patches stood unusually quiet except for the low, slow flap of the heron’s wings lifting from the lagoon. And then, Kya, only six at the time, heard the screen door slap.

author: Gail Parent
title: Sheila Levine is Dead and Living in New York
opening_line: A few years ago, on the East Side of Manhattan, not far from Bloomingdale’s, a man set up a business where he sold diet shakes, delicious chocolate milk shakes having only seventy-seven calories. Well, I tell you, fat young girls came from near and far and lined up around the block at lunchtime. Only seventy-seven calories and such heaven! I was one of the ones that had two for lunch every day.

author: Gail Parent
title: A Little Bit Married
opening_line: Marjorie should have known that there were rough times ahead when her husband announced, over ordinary power, that he felt like God.

author: Robert B. Parker
title: Hugger Mugger
opening_line: I was at my desk, in my office, with my feet up on the windowsill, and a yellow pad in my lap, thinking about baseball. It’s what I always think about when I’m not thinking about sex.

author: Mary E. Pearson
title: The Kiss of Deception
opening_line: Today was the day a thousand dreams would die and a single dream would be born.

author: Esther Perel
title: The State of Affairs
opening_line: There is one simple act of transgression that can rob a couple of their relationship, their happiness, their very identity: an affair.

author: Louis Phillips
title: A Dream of Countries Where No One Dare Live
opening_line: My mother and I had moved, right in the height or depths of the Depression, over to New Mexico, in a town near Carlsbad, where her friend Milly Stamps lived. I was eleven years old, Mom was in her forties, and Dad was dead.

author: Susan Elizabeth Phillips
title: It Had to Be You
opening_line: Phoebe Somerville outraged everyone by bringing a French poodle and a Hungarian lover to her father’s funeral.

author: Mary Laura Philpott
title: I Miss You When I Blink: Essays
opening_line: It’s the perfect sentence, but I didn’t write it. My six-year-old did.

author: Jodi Picoult
title: House Rules
opening_line: Everywhere I look, there are signs of a struggle. The mail has been scattered all over the kitchen floor; the stools are overturned. The phone has been knocked off its pedestal, its battery pack hanging loose from an umbilicus of wires. There’s one single faint footprint at the threshold of the living room, pointing toward the dead body of my son, Jacob.

author: Jodi Picoult
title: The Book of Two Ways
opening_line: My calendar is full of dead people.

author: Jodi Picoult
title: Wish You Were Here
opening_line: When I was six years old, I painted a corner of the sky.

author: Jodi Picoult and Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Mad Honey
opening_line: From the moment I was having a baby, I wanted it to be a girl. I wandered the aisles of department stores, touching doll-size dresses and tiny sequined shoes. I pictured us with matching nail polish—me, who’d never had a manicure in my life. I imagined the day her fairy hair was long enough to capture in pigtails, her nose pressed to the glass of a school bus window; I saw her first crush, prom dress, heartbreak. Each vision was a bead on a rosary of future memories; I prayed daily. As it turned out, I was not a zealot…only a martyr. When I gave birth, and the doctor announced the baby’s sex, I did not believe it at first. I had done such a stellar job of convincing myself of what I wanted that I completely forgot what I needed. But when I held Asher, slippery as a minnow, I was relieved. Better to have a boy, who would never be someone’s victim.

author: Billy Porter
title: Unprotected
opening_line: This is not a coming-out-story. It’s not a down-low story either. I never could have passed for straight, even if I’d wanted to, and so I never had the dubious luxury of living a lie.

author: Charles Portis
title: True Grit
opening_line: People do not give it credence that a fourteen-year-old girl could leave home and go off in the wintertime to avenge her father’s blood but it did not seem so strange then, although I will say it did not happen every day.

author: Charles Portis
title: The Dog of the South
opening_line: My wife Norma had run off with Guy Dupree and I was waiting around for the credit card billings to come in so I could see where they had gone. I was biding my time. This was October.

author: Neil Postman
title: The Disappearance of Childhood
opening_line: Children are the living messages we send to a time we will not see.

author: Richard Powers
title: The Echo Maker
opening_line: Cranes keep landing as night falls. Ribbons of them roll down, slack against the sky. They float in from all compass points, in kettles of a dozen, dropping with the dusk.

author: Annie Proulx
title: Close Range: Wyoming Stories
opening_line: Ennis Del Mar wakes before five, wind rocking the trailer, hissing in around the aluminum door and window frames. The shirts hanging on a nail shudder slightly in the draft. He gets up, scratching the grey wedge of belly and pubic hair, shuffles to the gas burner, pours leftover coffee in a chipped enamel pan; the flame swathes it in blue. He turns on the tap and urinates in the sink, pulls on his shirt and jeans, his worn boots, stamping the heels against the floor to get them full on.

author: Mario Puzo
title: The Fourth K
opening_line: Oliver Oliphant was one hundred years old and his mind was a clear as a bell. Unfortunately for him.

author: Ann Quin
title: Berg
opening_line: A man called Berg, who changed his name to Greb, came to a seaside town intending to kill his father…

author: Heather Radke
title: Butts
opening_line: The first butt I remember isn’t my own. It’s my mother’s.

author: Alice Randall
title: Ada’s Rules
opening_line: Ada departed the island of fat as she arrived: with little fanfare and for her own reasons. Edited, she was still luscious. Thin again is not simply thin.

author: Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings
title: The Sojourner
opening_line: Three crows flew low over the fresh mound in the Linden burying-ground, dark as the thoughts of the three unmourning mourners.

author: Deanna Raybourn
title: Silent in the Grave
opening_line: To say I met Nicholas Brisbane over my husband’s dead body is not entirely accurate. Edward, it should be noted, was still twitching on the floor.

author: Nigel Rees
title: The Newsmakers
opening_line: It was when Jo threw the television at him that David briefly realized all was not well with their marriage.

author: Joy-Ann Reid
title: Medgar and Myrtle
opening_line: The thing about love is that it has no chill.

author: Mary Renault
title: The Last of the Wine
opening_line: When I was a young boy, if I was sick or in trouble, or had been beaten at school, I used to remember that on the day I was born my father had wanted to kill me.

author: Ruth Rendell
title: Asta’s Book
opening_line: My grandmother was a novelist without knowing it.

author: Richard Rhodes
title: A Hole in the World
opening_line: When I was thirteen months old, my mother killed herself.

author: Jean Rhys
title: Wide Sargasso Sea
opening_line: They say when trouble comes close ranks, and so the white people did. But we were not in their ranks.

author: Simon Rich
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: The detective woke up just after dawn. It was a typical morning. His knees were scraped and bruised, his clothes were damp and soiled, and his teeth felt like someone had socked him in the jaw. He reached for the bottle he kept under his pillow and took a sloppy swig. The taste was foul, but it did the trick.

author: Mary Roach
title: Bonk
opening_line: A man sits in a room, manipulating his kneecaps. It is 1983, on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. The man, a study subject, has been told to do this for four minutes, stop, and then resume for a minute more. Then he can put his pants back on, collect his payment, and go home with an entertaining story to tell at suppertime.

author: Tom Robbins
title: Still Life With Woodpecker
opening_line: If this typewriter can’t do it, then fuck it, it can’t be done.

author: Tom Robbins
title: Esquire
opening_line: When one is on a pilgrimage to the Canyon of the Vaginas, one has to be careful about asking directions.

author: Tom Robbins
title: Playboy
opening_line: Kissing is our greatest invention. On the list of great inventions, it ranks higher than the Thermos bottle and the Airstream trailer; higher, even, than room service, possibly because the main reason room service was created was so people could stay in bed and kiss without going hungry.

author: Nora Roberts
title: Three Fates
opening_line: Happily unaware he’d be dead in twenty-three minutes, Henry W. Wyley imagined pinching the nicely rounded rump of the young blonde who was directly in his line of sight.

author: Jackie Robinson
title: I Never Had It Made
opening_line: My grandfather was born into slavery, and although my mother and father, Mallie and Jerry Robinson, lived during an era when physical slavery had been abolished, they also lived in a newer, more sophisticated kind of slavery than the kind Mr. Lincoln struck down.

author: Marilynne Robinson
title: Home
opening_line: “Home to stay, Glory! Yes!” her father said, and her heart sank.

author: Jacqueline Rose
title: On Violence and On Violence Against Women
opening_line: It is a truism to say that everyone knows violence when they see it, but if one thing has become clear over the past decade it is that the most prevalent, insidious forms of violence are those that cannot be seen.

author: Philip Roth
title: Goodbye, Columbus
opening_line: The first time I saw Brenda she asked me to hold her glasses. Then she stepped out to the edge of the diving board and looked foggily into the pool; it could have been drained, myopic Brenda would never have known it.

author: Philip Roth
title: Portnoy’s Complaint
opening_line: She was so deeply imbedded in my consciousness that for the first year of school I seem to have believed that each of my teachers was my mother in disguise.

author: Philip Roth
title: The Anatomy Lesson
opening_line: When he is sick, every man wants his mother; if she’s not around other women must do. Zuckerman was making do with four other women.

author: Philip Roth
title: Sabbath’s Theater
opening_line: Either forswear fucking others or the affair is over.

author: Rita Rudner
title: Rita Rudner’s Guide to Men
opening_line: This is a guide to men. It’s not that I’ve had much experience, or that I’ve done lots of research—it’s just, they’re not very hard to figure out.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Why I Am Not a Christian
opening_line: Sex, more than any other element in human life, is still viewed by many, perhaps by most, in an irrational way.

author: William Saroyan
title: Chance Meetings
opening_line: The thing about the people one meets on arrival, upon being born, is that they are the people they are, and not the people any of us, had he indeed had a choice, might be likely to have chosen. These meetings are chance meetings.

author: May Sarton
title: The Fur Person
opening_line: When he was about two years old, and had been a Cat About Town for some time, glorious in conquests, but rather too thin for comfort, the Fur Person decided that it was time he settled down.

author: May Sarton
title: As We Are Now
opening_line: I am not mad, only old.

author: Virginia Satir
title: Peoplemaking
opening_line: When I was five, I decided that when I grew up I’d be a “children’s detective on parents.”

author: George Saunders
title: Harper’s
opening_line: Once again it was TorchLightNight. Around nine I went out to pee. Back in the woods was the big tank that sourced our fake river, plus a pile of old armor. Don Murray flew past me, looking frazzled. Then I heard a sob. On her back near the armor pile I found Martha from Scullery, peasant skirt up around her waist. Martha: That guy is my boss. Oh my God oh my God. I knew Don Murray was her boss because Don Murray was also my boss. All of a sudden she recognized me. Ted, don’t tell, she said. Please. It’s no big deal. Nate can’t know. It would kill him.

author: Erica Lorraine Scheit
title: Uses for Boys
opening_line: In the happy times, in the tell-me-again times, when I’m seven and there are no stepbrothers and it’s before the stepfathers, my mom lets me sleep in her bed. Her bed is a raft on the ocean. It’s a cloud, a forest, a spaceship, a cocoon we share. I stretch out big as I can, a five-pointed star, and she bundles me back up in her arms. When I wake I’m tangled in her hair. “Tell me again,” I say and she tells me again how she wanted me more than anything. “More than anything in the world,” she says, “I wanted a little girl.”

author: Sarah Schulman
title: The Sophie Horowitz Story
opening_line: I wanted to feed Lillian something delicious because I knew that’s what she was going to feed me.

author: Sarah Schulman
title: After Delores
opening_line: I walked out in the snow trying to get away from Delores’s ghost. It was sitting back in the apartment waiting for me.

author: Erich Segal
title: Love Story
opening_line: What can you say about a twenty-five-year-old girl who died?

author: Erich Segal
title: Acts of Faith
opening_line: I was baptized in blood. My own blood. This is not a Jewish custom. It is merely a fact of history.

author: Peter Selgin
title: The Inventors
opening_line: This book is about two men who were very important to me. The first was there at my conception, the second came along thirteen years later. Each had a profound influence on me. You could say they invented me, such was their influence.

author: Jennifer Senior
title: The Atlantic
opening_line: When Bobby McIlvane died on September 11, 2001, his desk at home was a study in plate tectonics, coated in shifting piles of leather-bound diaries and yellow legal pads.

author: Laurence Shames
title: Relative Humidity
opening_line: Now and then, not often, life offers up a perfect moment, a moment when everything just fits together, almost as if there was a plan, as if the world had been designed to be at least an occasional Paradise for those who took the trouble to notice its ingenious construction, as if life would be a calm and peaceful pleasure if that moment just went on and on. But of course it never does.

author: Emily Shugerman
title: The Daily Beast
opening_line: When volunteers at Venue Church in Chattanooga, Tennessee, arrived at their pastor’s house last November, they were hoping to raise his spirits with a surprise visit. Instead they got a shock: Pastor Tavner Smith was alone with a female church employee—she in a towel, he in his boxers.

author: Alan Sillitoe
title: Saturday Night and Sunday Morning
opening_line: The rowdy gang of singers who sat at the scattered tables saw Arthur walk unsteadily to the head of the stairs, and though they must all have known that he was dead drunk, and seen the danger he would soon be in, no one attempted to talk to him and lead him back to his seat.

author: Nina Simon
title: Mother-Daughter Murder Night
opening_line: Beth knew she couldn’t leave for work until she dealt with the dead body on the beach.

author: Upton Sinclair
title: The Autobiography of Upton Sinclair
opening_line: My first recollection of life is one that my mother insisted I could not possibly have, because I was only eighteen months old at the time.

author: Curtis Sittenfeld
title: Eligible
opening_line: Well before his arrival in Cincinnati, everyone knew that Chip Bingley was looking for a wife.

author: Grace Slick
title: Somebody to Love?
opening_line: It’s Chicago, 1973. Jefferson Airplane is tuning up and I’m standing onstage getting ready to sing. Some guy in the audience stands up and shouts, “Hey, Gracie—take off your chastity belt.”

author: Brendan Slocumb
title: The Violin Conspiracy
opening_line: On the morning of the worst, most earth-shattering day of Ray McMillan’s life, he ordered room service: scrambled eggs for two, one side of regular bacon (for Nicole), one side of vegan sausage (for him), one coffee (for Nicole), one orange juice (for him).

author: Dodie Smith
title: I Capture The Castle
opening_line: I write this sitting in the kitchen sink.

author: Dodie Smith
title: The Hundred and One Dalmatians
opening_line: Not long ago, there lived in London a young married couple of Dalmatian dogs named Pongo and Missis Pongo. (Missis had added Pongo’s name to her own on their marriage, but was still called Missis by most people.) They were lucky enough to own a young married couple of humans named Mr. and Mrs. Dearly, who were gentle, obedient, and unusually intelligent—almost canine at times.

author: Dalia Sofer
title: The Septembers of Shiraz
opening_line: When Isaac Amin sees two men with rifles walk into his office at half past noon on a warm autumn day in Tehran, his first thought is that he won’t be able to join his wife and daughter for lunch, as promised.

author: Dalia Sofer
title: Man of My Time
opening_line: Around me was an ant colony of black motorcars. In my jacket pocket, hidden inside a mint candy box, were the ashes of my father—Sadegh Mozaffarian—dead for two weeks and estranged from me for thirty-eight years.

author: Gilbert Sorrentino
title: Imaginative Qualities of Actual Things
opening_line: What if this young woman, who writes such bad poems, in competition with her husband, whose poems are equally bad, should stretch her remarkably long and well-made legs out before you, so that her skirt slips up to the tops of her stockings?

author: Sonia Sotomayor
title: My Beloved World
opening_line: I was barely awake, but my mother was already screaming. I knew Papi would start screaming in a second. That much was routine, but the substance of their argument was new, and it etched that morning into my memory.

author: Terry Southern and Mason Hoffenberg
title: Candy
opening_line: “I’ve read many books,” said Professor Mephesto, with an odd finality, wearily flattening his hands on the podium, addressing the seventy-six sophomores who sat in easy reverence, immortalizing his every phrase with their pads and pens, and now, as always, giving him the confidence to slowly, artfully dramatize his words, to pause, shrug, frown, gaze abstractly at the ceiling, allow a wan wistful smile to play at his lips, and repeat quietly, “many books . . .” [ellipsis in original]

author: Nicholas Sparks
title: Dear John
opening_line: What does it mean to truly love another?

author: Catherine Steadman
title: Look in the Mirror
opening_line: The letter must have sat unopened for a month on your abandoned hall table as things carried on around it, the correspondence inside quietly waiting for me to find it.

author: Wallace Stegner
title: Crossing to Safety
opening_line: Floating upward through a confusion of dreams and memory, curving like a trout through the rings of previous risings, I surface. My eyes open. I am awake.

author: Garth Stein
title: Raven Stole the Moon
opening_line: She closed her eyes and held herself under the water. She exhaled, sending little bubbles to the surface. It felt good to expel the used air, but then came the pain of empty lungs.

author: Garth Stein
title: The Art of Racing in the Rain
opening_line: Gestures are all that I have; sometimes they must be grand in nature. And while I occasionally step over the line and into the world of the melodramatic, it is what I must do in order to communicate clearly and effectively. In order to make my point understood without question.

author: Nina Stibbe
title: Man at the Helm
opening_line: My sister and I and our little brother were born (in that order) into a very good situation and apart from the odd new thing life was humdrum and comfortable until an evening in 1970 when our mother listened in to our father’s phone call and ended up blowing her nose on a tea towel—a thing she’d only have done in an absolute emergency.

author: Elizabeth Strout
title: Olive Kitteridge
opening_line: For many years Henry Kitteridge was a pharmacist in the next town over, driving every morning on snowy roads, or rainy roads, or summertime roads, when the wild raspberries shot their new growth in brambles along the last section of town before he turned off to where the wider road led to the pharmacy. Retired now, he still wakes early and remembers how mornings used to be his favorite, as though the world were his secret, tires rumbling softly beneath him and the light emerging through the early fog, the brief sight of the bay off to his right, then the pines, tall and slender, and almost always he rode with the window partly open because he loved the smell of the pines and the heavy salt air, and in the winter he loved the smell of the cold.

author: Lixing Sun
title: The Liars of Nature and the Nature of Liars
opening_line: She is pregnant. Raising a child takes a lot of time and energy, yet she is short of both. Homeless, she has no choice but to find somebody else to take care of her baby—for free. It’s not easy, but she knows how to pull it off.

author: Nicholas L. Syrett
title: An Open Secret
opening_line: On March 4, 1960, Robert Allerton became a father. He was 86-years-old at the time and his newly adopted son, John Gregg, was 60. The pair had already been living together and calling themselves father and son for almost four decades.

author: Shannon Taft
title: Reckless in Texas: Metroplex Mysteries
opening_line: My mother in law, Alberta Dolan, did not have an enemy in the world the night she was stabbed to death.

author: Gabriel Tallent
title: My Absolute Darling
opening_line: The old house hunkers on its hill, all peeling white paint, bay windows, and spindled wooden railings overgrown with climbing roses and poison oak.

author: Amy Tan
title: The Joy Luck Club
opening_line: My father has asked me to be the fourth corner at the Joy Luck Club. I am to replace my mother, whose seat at the mah jong table has been empty since she died two months ago. My father thinks she was killed by her own thoughts.

author: Amy Tan
title: The Kitchen God’s Wife
opening_line: Whenever my mother talks to me, she begins the conversation as if we were already in the middle of an argument.

author: Amy Tan
title: The Hundred Secret Senses
opening_line: My sister Kwan believes she has yin eyes.

author: Amy Tan
title: The Valley of Amazement
opening_line: When I was seven, I knew exactly who I was: a thoroughly American girl in race, manners, and speech, whose mother, Lulu Minturn, was the only white woman who owned a first-class courtesan house in Shanghai.

author: Booth Tarkington
title: The Magnificent Ambersons
opening_line: Major Amberson had “made a fortune” in 1873, when other people were losing fortunes, and the magnificence of the Ambersons began then.

author: Booth Tarkington
title: Image of Josephine
opening_line: “Boasting’s the vulgarest thing there is,“ the fair young girl, Josephine, informed her three guests as they came out of the big brick Oaklin house after lunch. “Boasting’s practically the same as bragging, and both are incredibly vulgar.“

author: Walter Tevis
title: The Queen’s Gambit
opening_line: Beth learned of her mother’s death from a woman with a clipboard.

author: William Makepeace Thackeray
title: The Luck of Barry Lyndon
opening_line: Since the days of Adam, there has been hardly a mischief done in this world but a woman has been at the bottom of it.

author: Wright Thompson
title: ESPN.com
opening_line: Pat Conroy’s dad hit him after games. He hit him with fists, and with open palms, hit him until blood ran from Pat’s nose or lip onto his basketball jersey. Don Conroy didn’t hit his son only after games. He hit him for smiling at the wrong time, talking at the wrong time, crying at the wrong time, for trying to defend his battered mother at the wrong time. On occasion, he hit him just for the hell of it.

author: Rufi Thorpe
title: Margo’s Got Money Troubles
opening_line: You are about to begin reading a new book, and to be honest, you are a little tense. The beginning of a novel is like a first date. You hope that from the first lines an urgent magic will take hold, and you will sink into the story like a hot bath, giving yourself over entirely.

author: Gene Tierney
title: Self-Portrait
opening_line: It is a terrible thing to feel no fear, no alarm, when you are standing on a window ledge fourteen stories above the street. I felt tired, lost, and numb—but unafraid.

author: Leo Tolstoy
title: Anna Karenina
opening_line: Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.

author: Jean Toomer
title: Cane
opening_line: Men had always wanted her, this Karintha, even as a child, Karintha carrying beauty, perfect as dusk when the sun goes down.

author: Natasha Trethewey
title: Memorial Drive
