title: Vanity Fair
opening_line: I am afraid of the cops. Absolutely petrified of the cops. Now understand, I’ve never been arrested or held for questioning. I’ve never been told that I “fit the description.” But that doesn’t change a thing. I am afraid of cops the way that spiders are afraid of boots. You’re walking along, minding your own business, and SQUISH! You are dead.

author: Catherine Belling
title: A Condition of Doubt
opening_line: Hypochondriacs have two significant beliefs; that their bodies contain something that will kill them, and that, if they could only read their bodies closely enough, they should be able to find that lurking threat before it is too late.

author: Greg Bellow
title: Saul Bellow’s Heart
opening_line: On a visit to Chicago when I was eight, I witnessed a terrible argument, in Yiddish, between my father and grandfather. Driving away from his father’s house, Saul started to cry so bitterly he had to pull off the road. After a few minutes, he excused his lapse of self-control by saying, “It’s okay for grown-ups to cry.“ I knew his heart was breaking. I knew because of the bond between my father’s tender heart and mine.

author: Ruth Ben-Ghiat
title: Strongmen
opening_line: On November 4, 2008, when many world leaders waited to hear the results of the American presidential election, Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was in his Roman residence preparing to have sex.

author: Elizabeth Berg
title: I’ll Be Seeing You
opening_line: I am seventy years old. I am astonished to be writing this, as doubtful of the truth of it as if I had written, “I am a peacock.“

author: Candice Bergen
title: A Fine Romance
opening_line: It was midway through October 1985, as I waddled in a huge plaid tent dress through the ground floor of Bergdorf’s. I’d put on almost fifty pounds since becoming pregnant. A woman kept peering at me, looking away, looking back. Finally she approached. “You know, you have Candice Bergen’s face.“ “But not her body,“ I said.

author: Peter Bernhardt
title: The Rose’s Kiss
opening_line: Fresh flowers accompany us through some of the most emotional moments of our lives.

author: Michael R. Beschloss
title: Presidents of War
opening_line: And so it had come to this. Horrified as he stood on a height above the Potomac, James Madison, the fourth President of the United States—and now, some wondered, the last?—watched his beloved Washington City as it seemed to vanish into a crimson-orange swirl of fire.

author: Cyril Bibby
title: T. H. Huxley
opening_line: On the 4th of May 1825, when Thomas Henry Huxley was born in the sleepy old village of Ealing, English society still had its roots deep in the eighteenth century. By the 29th June 1895, when he died at the newly developing seaside resort of Eastbourne, it was already feeling its way into the twentieth.

author: The Bible (King James Version)
title: Genesis
opening_line: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.

author: Joe Biden
title: Promises to Keep
opening_line: Joe Impedimenta, my classmates hung that nickname on me our first semester of high school when we were doing two periods of Latin a day. It was one of the first big words we learned. Impedimenta—the baggage that impedes one’s progress.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: Write It Right
opening_line: The author’s main purpose in this book is to teach precision in writing; and of good writing (which, essentially, is clear thinking made visible) precision is the point of capital concern.

author: Sven Birkets
title: Los Angeles Review of Books
opening_line: Teaching writing, unlike most other kinds of teaching, is an intervention, closer to therapy than to any transmissible instruction.

author: Jake Bittle
title: The Great Displacement
opening_line: The town had been there for a century and a half. Then one evening, in the summer of 2021, it disappeared.

author: Ned Blackhawk
title: The Rediscovery of America
opening_line: How can a nation founded on the homelands of dispossessed Indigenous peoples be the world’s most exemplary democracy?

author: Erin Blakemore
title: The Heroine’s Bookshelf
opening_line: In times of struggle, there are as many reasons not to read as there are to breathe. Don’t you have better things to do? Reading, let alone rereading, is the terrain of milquetoasts and mopey spinsters. At life’s ugliest junctures, the very act of opening a book can smack of cowardly escapism. Who chooses to read when there’s work to be done?

author: Karen Blixen
title: Out of Africa
opening_line: I had a farm in Africa, at the foot of the Ngong Hills.

author: Kate Block
title: Spinster
opening_line: Whom to marry, and when it will happen—these two questions define every woman’s existence, regardless of where she was raised or what religion she does or doesn’t practice. She may grow up to love women instead of men, or to decide she simply doesn’t believe in marriage. No matter. These dual contingencies govern her until they’re answered, even if the answers are nobody and never.

author: Lawrence Block
title: The Crime of Our Lives
opening_line: It was in the eleventh grade that I knew I would be a writer. The conviction grew out of two awarenesses that dawned at about the same time.

author: Roy Blount, Jr.
title: Sports Illustrated
opening_line: In 1951 Marilyn Monroe was a starlet, Bobby Orr a baby, Hubert Humphrey a comer—and Willie Mays very nearly the same phenomenon he was last week.

author: Roy Blount, Jr.
title: The New York Times
opening_line: A feeling seems to have arisen that summer is the time for light reading. I don’t know where anyone got that idea.

author: Roy Blount, Jr.
title: Garden & Gun
opening_line: “Whereya from?“ asks an intense-looking complete stranger sitting next to me in O’Hare airport as we experience quite possibly the only thing we will ever have in common: a weather delay.

author: Charles M. Blow
title: Fire Shut Up in My Bones
opening_line: Tears flowed out of me from a walled-off place, from another time, from a little boy who couldn’t cry. I had held on to the hurt and shame and doubt for so long, balling it up in the pit of me, that I never thought it would come out, or that it could. I certainly didn’t think it would come out like this. Not in a flash. But there it was. Some of my tears streamed over the arc of my cheeks and off the rim of my jaw. Others rounded the corners of my nose and puddled in the crease of my lips. I didn’t wipe them. I wore them. I looked over at the rusting pistol on the passenger seat. It was a .22 with a long black barrel and a wooden grip.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: The shortest distance between two points is a straight line. That’s Euclid. Basic geometry. Only you’re smarter. It’s easy. After all, you know how the investigators work. You’re a student of cop-think.**

author: Howard Blum
opening_line: Everybody’s looking for love, right? Love is all you need. At least that’s what they keep telling you. So why should you be any different? You have needs, too. So you just sit in your room and scroll through FB, or Insta, or Tok—and there they are. It might as well be Tinder. All of them looking so pretty.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: You know how cops work. You know what they look for. You know the questions they’ll ask. You know all their tricks. You’re prepared. Well trained. After all. You’ve taken the classes. Earned the degrees. You’ve gotten into the heads of bad guys; written “crime scripts,” as your profs call them. You learned from their mistakes.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: Stepping into the courtroom, you know the score. Only one thing matters: getting your client off the hook. So if the facts are on your side, you pound ’em. If not, pound the table.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: People say time heals all wounds. They tell you you’ll get over it. But they never buried their child.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: Suppose you wanted to kill someone. That would be easy. There are lots of ways. But suppose you wanted to kill four people. All in the same house. All within moments of one another. And you chose to use a knife. That could help eliminate the noise. But it would require skill, strength, and endurance. Murder is hard work, especially if people fight back.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: Every doctor takes the pledge: Do no harm. It’s damn good advice for any trial lawyer too.

author: Howard Blum
title: Air Mail
opening_line: Ever try dodging a bullet? That’s a challenge, all right. But suppose you need to dodge five bullets. And each of the five shooters has a long gun aimed straight at your heart. Oh, and you’re strapped tight to a chair, to boot.

author: Cat Bohannon
title: Eve
opening_line: Elizabeth Shaw has a problem. The director Ridley Scott has impregnated her with a large, vicious alien squid. Aboard the spaceship Prometheus, she has to find a way to abort her uninvited guest without bleeding to death. Shambling to a futuristic surgery pod, she asks the computer for a C-section. “Error,” it says, “this medpod is calibrated for male patients only.” “Shit,” said a woman behind me, “who does that?”

author: Erma Bombeck
title: Just Wait Until You Have Children of Your Own

author: Erma Bombeck

author: Erma Bombeck
title: Forever, Erma
opening_line: Of all the means of communication known to man, none is quite as effective as the Mother’s Eye.

author: Erma Bombeck
title: Forever, Erma

author: Jim Bouton

author: Warren A. Boyd, Jr.

author: Jennifer Finney Boylan

author: Peg Bracken

opening_line: Some women, it is said, like to cook. This book is not for them.

author: Peg Bracken

author: James Bradley

opening_line: In the spring of 1998, six boys called to me from half a century ago on a distant mountain and I went there.

author: Laurel Braitman
title: What Looks Like Bravery
opening_line: Santa Paula, California, September 1994 It was a warm Saturday afternoon and the Santa Ana winds ruffled the tops of the avocado trees. I was at home with two good friends, all of us sixteen years old, draped like hormonal Dalí clocks over the living room furniture while we watched The Bodyguard on VHS and painted our nails.

author: Rutger Bregman
title: Utopia for Realists
opening_line: Let’s start with a little history lesson: In the past everything was worse.

author: Rutger Bregman
title: Humankind
opening_line: This is a book about a radical idea. An idea that’s long been known to make rulers nervous. An idea denied by religions and ideologies, ignored by the news media and erased from the annals of world history. At the same time, it’s an idea that’s legitimized by virtually every branch of science. One that’s corroborated by evolution and confirmed by everyday life. An ideal so intrinsic to human nature that it goes unnoticed and gets overlooked. If only we had the courage to take it more seriously, it’s an idea that might just start a revolution. Turn society on its head. Because once you grasp what it really means, it’s nothing less than a mind-bending drug that ensures you’ll never look at the world the same again. So what is this radical idea? That most people, deep down, are pretty decent.

author: Ian Bremmer
title: The Power of Crisis
opening_line: Away from the cameras and warmed by the fire, Ronald Reagan opened his first private conversation with Mikhail Gorbachev with a startling question: “What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?”

author: Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin

opening_line: The universe would be nothing were it not for life, and all that lives must be fed.

author: Taffy Brodesser-Akner

author: David Brooks

opening_line: If you ever saw the old movie Fiddler on the Roof, you know how warm and emotional Jewish families can be. They are always hugging, singing, dancing, laughing, and crying together. I come from the other kind of Jewish family.

author: Mel Brooks

opening_line: The writing of this book serves as a kind of confession. You, the readers will be my confidants. I’m going to tell you all my secrets. Things I’ve never told anybody. Things I don’t want anybody to know! I don’t want you to breathe a word of what you find out in this book. Keep everything under your hat! Wait a minute, wait a minute…that might not work. I’m not in a confessional booth, and a lot of you are probably not priests. This is a book! And this book needs to sell!

author: Heywood Broun
title: Pieces of Hate and Other Enthusiasms
opening_line: One of my favorite characters in all fiction is D’Artagan. He was forever fighting duels with people and stabbing them, or riding at top speed over lonely roads at night to save a woman’s name or something.

author: Helen Gurley Brown

author: Liz Brown

author: Rita Mae Brown

author: Rita Mae Brown

author: Susan Brownmiller

opening_line: I was not there at the beginning. Few people were. And although I can speak with confidence of a beginning, of certain documented rebellions sparked by a handful of visionaries with stubborn courage, there were antecedents to those rebellions, and antecedents to the antecedents.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The Beauty of Dusk
opening_line: They say that death comes like a thief in the night. Lesser vandals have the same MO. The affliction that stole my vision, or at least a big chuck of it, did so as I slept. I went to bed seeing the world one way. I woke up seeing it another.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The New York Times
opening_line: If the Jan. 6 rioters weren’t going to be pointing their guns at him, then he didn’t care that they were armed.

author: Bill Bryson
title: The Lost Continent
opening_line: I come from Des Moines. Somebody had to.

author: Bill Bryson
title: The Mother Tongue
opening_line: More than 300 million people in the world speak English and the rest, it sometimes seems, try to. It would be charitable to say the results are sometimes mixed.

author: Bill Bryson
title: A Short History of Nearly Everything
opening_line: Welcome. And congratulations. I am delighted you could make it. Getting here wasn’t easy, I know. In fact, I suspect it was a little tougher than you think.

author: Bill Bryson
title: The Body
opening_line: Long ago, when I was a junior high school student in Iowa, I remember being taught by a biology teacher that all the chemicals that make up a human body could be bought in a hardware store for $5.00 or something like that.

author: Art Buchwald
title: Too Soon to Say Goodbye
opening_line: What started out the worst of times ended up the best of times. The big news of 2006 is that I’m still alive. After being in the hospice waiting to die, I said, “To hell with it, I’m going to write a book.”

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Losing Mum and Pup: A Memoir
opening_line: I’m not sure how this book will turn out. I mostly write novels, and I’ve found, having written half a dozen, that if you’re lucky, the ending turns out a surprise and you wind up with something you hadn’t anticipated in the outline. I suppose it’s a process of outsmarting yourself (not especially hard in my case).

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Forbes Life
opening_line: My wife, in her wisdom, decreed that we must have a fish tank in our bathroom. Like Rumpole of the Bailey, I refer to my darling as She Who Must Be Obeyed. So the only answer was “Darling, what an excellent idea. I am so excited to have fish in our bathroom.”

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Forbes Life
opening_line: It’s a bit cramped in the back of the Cessna 206. The windows are frosting over, and as I scrape away the rime with the edge of a credit card what I can make out is not entirely reassuring.

author: Christopher Buckley

opening_line: “Good to see you again,” I greeted the gentleman, a family friend, important businessman and former cabinet secretary. “How’s Carol?” The friendly grin remained, but I caught the suppressed wince. “She died three years ago,” he said. Where does one go from there? “Gosh, well…seen any good movies lately?” I made my way to the men’s room to bash my head against the wall in private.

author: William F. Buckley, Jr.
title: Nearer, My God: An Autobiography of Faith
opening_line: It was during the summer of 1938 that we were given the dreadful news.

author: Frederick Buechner

opening_line: One November morning in 1936 when I was ten years old, my father got up early, put on a pair of gray slacks and a maroon sweater, opened the door to look in briefly on my younger brother and me, who were playing a game in our room, and then went down into the garage where he turned on the engine of the family Chevy and sat down on the running board to wait for the exhaust to kill him.

author: Jimmy Buffett

opening_line: When I was growing up in Alabama, the beginning of the new school year was a bad time. It meant the end of summer, which is my season. I packed away my shorts and t-shirts, put on socks, shoes, and my parochial-school uniform, and dragged my ass to class.

author: Vincent Bugliosi
title: Helter Skelter
opening_line: Saturday, August 9, 1969 It was so quiet, one of the killers would later say, you could almost hear the sound of ice rattling in cocktail shakers in the homes way down the canyon.

author: Oliver Burkeman

opening_line: The average human lifespan is absurdly, terrifyingly, insultingly short.

author: Michael Burlingame

opening_line: If the legendary oddsmaker Jimmy the Greek had been alive when the Civil War began, he would probably have given the South a better-than-even chance of winning.

author: Michael Burlingame

opening_line: Abraham Lincoln was apparently one of those men who regard “connubial bliss” as an oxymoron.

author: George Burns

opening_line: For forty years my act consisted of one joke. And then she died.

author: Leo Buscaglia

opening_line: Nikos Kazantzakis suggests that ideal teachers are those who use themselves as bridges over which they invite their students to cross, then having facilitated their crossing, joyfully collapse, encouraging them to create bridges of their own.

opening_line: The word Irish is seldom coupled with the word civilization.

author: Michael Caine

This, the porter told me, was strictly illegal. He and I stood at the door to see who was so flagrantly flouting the law—presumably the President, of the United States or at least of the Beverly Hills Hotel. Across Sunset Boulevard, out of a swirling sun-flecked cloud of dust, six foot four and in full cowboy get-up, strode the unmistakable figure of John Wayne.

author: Michael Caine
title: The Elephant to Hollywood
opening_line: Well, it’s a long way from London’s Elephant and Castle to Hollywood. And the shortest distance between two points is not always a straight line—as my story is going to prove. But then I’ve never been known for doing things the easy way. I wouldn’t have minded easy, but things just never worked out quite like that. In fact—although I couldn’t have known it at the time—they worked out a whole lot better.

author: Ilia Calderón
title: My Time To Speak
opening_line: All my attention was focused on his face. It’s what I remember most clearly more than two years after our encounter. That face that had raged red as soon as he saw me, and continued angry, indignant. His nostrils flared with his agitated breathing, which he unsuccessfully attempted to control. He responded quickly, hot, like a lit fuse, not letting anyone else talk. And then, suddenly, I heard it from his own lips, “We’re going to burn you out.”

author: Joseph Campbell
title: Myths to Live By
opening_line: Mythology is apparently coeval with mankind.

author: Albert Camus
title: The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays
opening_line: The gods had condemned Sisyphus to ceaselessly rolling a rock up to the top of a mountain, whence the stone would fall back of its own weight. They had thought with some reason that there is no more dreadful punishment than this futile and hopeless labor.

author: Albert Camus
title: The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays
opening_line: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is suicide.

author: Frank Capra

author: Mariah Carey

opening_line: My intention was to keep her safe, but perhaps I have only succeeded in keeping her prisoner.

author: Richard Carlson

author: Robert A. Caro

opening_line: The room on the first floor of the Barbour County Courthouse in the little town of Eufaula, Alabama, was normally the County Clerk’s Office, but after it had closed for the day on August 2, 1957, it was being used by the county’s Board of Registrars, the body that registered citizens so they could vote in elections—not that the Board was going to register any of the three persons who were applying that day, for the skin of these applicants was black.

author: Rachel Carson

opening_line: Beginnings are apt to be shadowy, and so it is with the beginnings of that great mother of life, the sea.

author: Angela Carter

author: Rubin Carter

opening_line: RUBIN, my Christian name, comes from the Book of Genesis, Chapter 29, verse 32 of the Holy Scriptures. Other than both of us being black, that’s about the only thing the Bible and I ever had in common.

author: Casey Cep

author: Bennett Cerf

author: Bennett Cerf

author: Bennett Cerf

author: Agatha Christie

author: Stephen Colbert

author: Judy Collins

author: Blayney Colmore

Last I looked at the speedometer it read between 30 and 35 miles per hour. Exhilarating. Conrad and his daughter Karen were much more experienced and stronger bikers than I was. I followed them down the hill. They both skillfully avoided the board in the road. I never saw it. He told me later that he saw me launch from my bike like a rocket. “You must have gone 20 feet in the air before you landed.” When Karen saw me lying motionless on the road, she said, “Oh God, Dad, I think he’s dead.”

author: Barnaby Conrad III

author: Pat Conroy

Moreover, I knew that a single case has small standing in the annals of medical research, having little more than “anecdotal” or “testimonial” value.

author: Norman Cousins

opening_line: This book is about power—how it is perceived; how it is used; its illusions and realities; its benefits and dangers. What confronts the American people as they approach the twenty-first century is the truth of one of the best-known axioms on human behavior: “Power tends to corrupt; absolute power corrupts absolutely.”

author: Noël Coward

author: Harry Crews

What the fuck happened to me?” Somehow, overnight, it seemed I had turned from a hip, cool baby boomer into a Diane Arbus photograph.

author: Salvador Dalí

author: Belle de Jour

author: William Deresiewicz

opening_line: People ask, How did you get in there? What they really want to know is if they are likely to end up there as well. I can’t answer the real question. All I can tell them is, It’s easy.

author: Buster Keaton
title: My Wonderful World of Slapstick
opening_line: Down through the years my face has been called a sour puss, a dead pan, a frozen face, The Great Stone Face, and, believe it or not, "a tragic mask." On the other hand that kindly critic, the late James Agee, described my face as ranking "almost with Lincoln's as an early American archetype, it was haunting, handsome, almost beautiful."

author: John Keats
title: You Might as Well Live
opening_line: Once upon a time, the world was bright and new, and Dorothy Parker was one of the brightest and newest people in it.

author: Helen Keller
title: The Story of My Life
opening_line: It is with a kind of fear that I begin to write the history of my life. I have, as it were, a superstitious hesitation in lifting the veil that clings about my childhood like a golden mist.

author: John F. Kennedy
title: Profiles in Courage
opening_line: This is a book about that most admirable of human virtues—courage. “Grace under pressure,” Ernest Hemingway defined it.

author: Piper Kerman
title: Orange is the New Black
opening_line: International baggage claim in the Brussels airport was large and airy, with multiple carousels circling endlessly. I scurried from one to another, desperately trying to find my black suitcase. Because it was stuffed with drug money, I was more concerned than one might normally be about lost luggage.

author: Ian Kerner
title: She Comes First
opening_line: The premise of this book is simple: when it comes to pleasuring women and conversing in the language of love, cunnilingus should be every man’s native tongue.

author: Jean Kerr
title: Please Don't Eat the Daisies
opening_line: I had the feeling all along that this book should have an Introduction, because it doesn’t have an Index and it ought to have something.

author: Jean Kerr
title: The Snake Has All the Lines
opening_line: I make mistakes; I’ll be the second to admit it.

author: John Kerr
title: A Most Dangerous Method
opening_line: Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung met for the first time on 3 March 1907. They talked for thirteen hours straight.

author: Alicia Keyes
title: More Myself
opening_line: I am seven. My mom and I are side by side in the back seat of a yellow taxi, making our way up Eleventh Avenue in Manhattan on a dead-cold day in December. We hardly ever take cabs. They’re a luxury for a single parent and part-time actress. But on this afternoon, maybe because Mom has just finished an audition near my school, PS 116 on East Thirty-third Street, or maybe because it’s so freezing we can see our breath, she picks me up.

author: Tracy Kidder
title: Mountains Beyond Mountains
opening_line: Six years after the fact, Dr. Paul Edward Farmer reminded me, “We met because of a beheading, of all things.”

author: Stephen King
title: On Writing
opening_line: My earliest memory is of imagining I was someone else—imagining that I was, in fact, the Ringling Brothers Circus Strongboy. This was at my Aunt Ethelyn and Uncle Oren’s house in Durham, Maine. My aunt remembers this quite clearly, and say I was two and a half or maybe three years old.

author: Stephen King
title: Secret Windows: Essays and Fiction on the Craft of Writing
opening_line: When I finally understand what my thirteen-year-old son was talking about, I told him no problem, I could find him a couple of good hookers easy—maybe even a couple of great ones.

author: Martin Luther King, Jr.
title: Strength to Love
opening_line: A French philosopher said, “No man is strong unless he bears within his character antitheses strongly marked.” The strong man holds in a living blend strongly marked opposites.

author: Laura Kipnis
title: Men
opening_line: Men have fascinated me, maybe too much. They’ve troubled me. They’re large and take up a lot of space—space in the imagination, I mean. They force you to think about them.

author: Caroline Knapp
title: Drinking
opening_line: It happened this way: I fell in love and then, because the love was ruining everything I cared about, I had to fall out. This didn’t happen easily, or simply, but if I had to pinpoint it, I’d say the relationship started to fall apart the night I nearly killed my oldest friend’s two daughters.

author: Sam Knight
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: The Queen is the only royal who actually matters or does anything. That’s not fair, of course, but the monarchy is unfairness personified and glorified, long to reign over us.

author: Abbie Kozolchyk
title: The Best Women’s Travel Writing, 2007
opening_line: In theory, I’m a grownup. Crow’s feet, mortgage payments, shattered illusions…name the badge of adulthood, and I’m probably sporting it.

author: Natalie Kusz
title: Road Song
opening_line: Our first months in Alaska, that one long summertime before I was hurt, were hard—in the way, I think, that all immigrants’ lives must be hard—but they were also very grand, full of wood fires and campgrounds, full of people and the stories they told at night when we ate all together, full of clean dust that we washed from our bodies with water carried home from cold springs.

author: Chaney Kwak
title: The Passenger
opening_line: As the cruise ship almost tips over, the horizon that once bisected my lovely balcony door rises like a theater curtain and disappears. Now the sea is the stage. I tumble off my bed onto the floor and roll like a stuntman.

author: Chris Kyle
title: An American Sniper
opening_line: Every story has a beginning. Mine starts in north-central Texas. I grew up in small towns where I learned the importance of family and traditional values, like patriotism, self-reliance, and watching out for your family and neighbors.

author: Stephanie LaCava
title: An Extraordinary Theory of Objects
opening_line: I was always strange.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Bird by Bird
opening_line: The very first thing I tell my new students on the first day of a workshop is that good writing is about telling the truth.

author: Anne Lamott
title: Traveling Mercies
opening_line: My coming to faith did not start with a leap but rather a series of staggers from what seemed like one safe place to another.

author: Anne Lamott
title: The New York Times
opening_line: Getting older is almost like changing species, from cute middle-aged, white-tailed deer, to yak. We are both grass eaters, but that’s about the only similarity.

author: Steven E. Landsburg
title: The Armchair Economist
opening_line: Most of economics can be summarized in four words: “People respond to incentives.” The rest is commentary.

author: Erik Larson
title: The Devil in the White City
opening_line: In Chicago at the end of the nineteenth century amid the smoke of industry and the clatter of trains there lived two men, both handsome, both blue-eyed, and both unusually adept at their chosen skills. Each embodied an element of the great dynamic that characterized the rush of America toward the twentieth century.

author: Thomas Larson
title: The Memoir and the Memoirist
opening_line: Memoir is the speaking “I” of a trusting author, walking hand in hand with the reader down a path both know well.

author: Jenny Lawson
title: Let’s Pretend This Never Happened
opening_line: This book is totally true, except for the parts that aren’t. It’s basically like Little House on the Prairie but with more cursing.

author: Wendy Lazar
title: Day-by-Day and Heart-to-Heart
opening_line: I arrived October 6, 1964, knowing only one word of Japanese: Sayonara.

author: Jackson Lears
title: Boston Review
opening_line: Historians of the relation between art and advertising might ponder the sex life of the praying mantis.

author: Jackson Lears
title: Rebirth of a Nation
opening_line: All history is the history of longing.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: 12:35 P.M.—The phone rings. I am not amused. This is not my favorite way to wake up.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: When it comes to sports I am not particularly interested. Generally speaking, I look upon them as dangerous and tiring activities performed by people with whom I share nothing except the right to trial by jury.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: I love sleep because it is both pleasant and safe to use.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: Contrary to what many of you might imagine, a career in letters is not without its drawbacks—chief among them the unpleasant fact that one is frequently called upon to actually sit down and write.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: As one with a distinct aversion to newspapers I rely heavily for information on the random remarks of others. Therefore my sources are far from impeccable.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Metropolitan Life
opening_line: Democracy is an interesting, even laudable, notion and there is no question but that when compared to Communism, which is too dull, or Fascism, which is too exciting, it emerges as the most palatable form of government.

author: Fran Lebowitz
title: Social Studies
opening_line: People (a group that in my opinion has always attracted an undue amount of attention) have often been likened to snowflakes. This analogy is meant to suggest that each is unique—no two alike. This is quite patently not the case.

author: Richard Lederer
title: Anguished English
opening_line: Mark Twain once wrote, “Man is the only animal that blushes. Or needs to.” He could have added, “The human being is the only animal that truly laughs. Or needs to.”

author: Richard Lederer
title: The Miracle of Language
opening_line: “Language is the Rubicon that divides man from beast,” declared the philologist Max Müller. The boundary between human and animal—between the most primitive savage and the highest ape—is the language line.

author: Richard Lederer
title: The Cunning Linguist
opening_line: In a junior high-school biology class the teacher asks a student, “Mary please name the part of the human body that expands to six times its normal size and explain under what conditions.” Blushing bright red, Mary simpers, “Teacher that is not a proper question to ask me, and I can’t answer it in front of the class.” The teacher turns to another student and asks, “All right, Johnny, do you have the answer?” “The pupil of the eye, and in dim light.”

author: Richard Lederer
title: Amazing Words
opening_line: At seventy-four years of youth, I consider myself to be one of the luckiest men on the face of the earth. Looking back on my life, I can honestly say that I have pretty much closed the distance between who I am and what I do.

author: Richard Lederer
title: Richard Lederer’s Ultimate Book of Literary Trivia
opening_line: Literature lives. Literature endures. Literature prevails. That’s because readers bestow a special kind of life upon people who have existed only in books.

author: Ernest Lehman
title: Sweet Smell of Success: And Other Stories
opening_line: I just let her go on talking.

author: Mark Leibovich
title: This Town
opening_line: Tim Russert is dead. But the room is alive.

author: Mark Leibovich
title: The New York Times
opening_line: When I walk into John McCain’s office a week before Thanksgiving, he is not at all happy—and he seems to be enjoying it.

author: Andrew Leland
title: The Country of the Blind
opening_line: I’m going blind as I write this.

author: Don Lemon
title: This is the Fire
opening_line: May 25, 2020 Dear Trushaad, Today I heard a dying man call out to his mama, and I wept for the world that will soon belong to you. I know what comes next as surely as I know the Mississippi rolls down to the sea. The weeping passes, and rage takes hold. The rage burns out, and blame begins. The blame bounces back and forth, and promises are made. The promises wither, and complacency returns. And the complacency stays. It stagnates like a lullaby on autoplay, until another man dies facedown on another street in another city, and the weeping begins again.

author: George Leonard
title: Education and Ecstasy
opening_line: Teachers are overworked and underpaid. True. It is an exacting and exhausting business, this damming up the flood of human potentialities.

author: George Leonard
title: The Ultimate Athlete
opening_line: In every fat man, the saying goes, there is a thin man struggling to get out. If this is so, then every skinny man must at times find himself surrounded by the ghostly outlines of muscles and heft. And there must somehow exist an ideal physique for every one of us—man, woman, and child.

author: Jill Lepore
title: These Truths
opening_line: The course of history is unpredictable, as irregular as the weather, as errant as affection, nations rising and falling by whim and chance, battered by violence, corrupted by greed, seized by tyrants, raided by rogues, addled by demagogues.

author: Harriet Lerner
title: The Dance of Anger
opening_line: Anger is a signal, and one worth listening to.

author: Sam Levenson
title: In One Era and Out the Other
opening_line: It was on my fifth birthday that Papa put his hand on my shoulder and said, “Remember, my son, if you ever need a helping hand, you’ll find one at the end of your arm.“

author: Primo Levi
title: If This Is a Man
opening_line: It was my good fortune to be deported to Auschwitz...

author: Daniel J. Levitin
title: Successful Aging
opening_line: The poet Dylan Thomas wrote that one should not go gently into that good night, that old age should burn and rage at close of day. As a younger man reading that poem, I saw futility in those words. I saw aging only as a failing: a failing of the body, of the mind, and even of the spirit.

author: Michael Lewis
title: Moneyball
opening_line: The first thing they always did was run you.

author: Johannes Lichtman
title: The Paris Review
opening_line: Last spring, a friend of a friend visited my office and invited me to Langley to speak to Invisible Ink, the CIA’s creative writing group.

author: A. J. Liebling
title: The Telephone Booth Indian
opening_line: There was once a French-Canadian whose name I cannot at present recall but who had a window in his stomach. It was due to this fortunate circumstance, however unlikely, that a prying fellow of a doctor was able to study the man’s inner workings, and that is how we came to know all about the gastric juices, as I suppose we do.

author: Alan Light
title: The Holy or the Broken
opening_line: Allen Ginzberg once said, “Dylan blew everybody’s mind except Leonard’s.”

author: Laura Lippman
title: Longreads.com
opening_line: My daughter was 10 days old the first time I was asked if I were her grandmother.

author: Walter Lippmann
title: A Preface to Morals
opening_line: Among those who no longer believe in the religion of their fathers, some are proudly defiant, and many are indifferent. But there are also a few, perhaps an increasing number, who feel that there is a vacancy in their lives. This inquiry deals with their problem.

author: Patricia Lockwood
title: Priestdaddy
opening_line: “Before they allowed your father to be a priest,” my mother tells me, “they made me take the Psychopath Test. You know, a priest can’t have a psychopath wife, it would bring disgrace.”

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: In the first grade I was in a bit of a fog.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: My mother was seeing another man. His name was Willy.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: Getting Personal: Selected Essays
opening_line: I grew up in the era of the great Jewish Lovers.

author: Phillip Lopate
title: To Show and To Tell
opening_line: I should explain straight-out that I consider myself to be as much a teacher as writer. It’s not simply that a good deal of my annual income derives from teaching; it’s also that I find it a fascinating challenge, one that nourishes my psyche—and my own writing.

author: M. G. Lord
title: The Accidental Feminist
opening_line: You could say it began in 1944 with National Velvet, when Elizabeth Taylor, age twelve, dressed as a boy and stole America’s collective heart. By “it,” I mean the subversive drumbeats of feminism, which swelled in the star’s important movies over decades from a delicate pitty-pat to a resounding roar.

author: Mary J. Lore
title: Managing Thought
opening_line: There is no such thing as the future. The future is an illusion. What we have is a now, followed by a now, followed by a series of nows.

author: Richard Luscombe
title: The Guardian
opening_line: Cops in New Orleans are on the tail of a brazen gang of narcotics traffickers who broke into the evidence room at police headquarters and pilfered all the pot: a swarm of rodents with a hankering for the high life.

author: Robert Lynd
title: Essays on Life and Literature
opening_line: Max is in danger of being canonized.

author: Rose Macaulay
title: A Casual Commentary
opening_line: Here then we are—arrived at another spin of the wheel.

author: Maxwell Maltz
title: Adventures in Staying Young
opening_line: In attempting to help someone else, it often turns out that actually you are helping yourself.

author: Maxwell Maltz
title: The Magic Power of Self-Image Psychology
opening_line: Imagine that you are seated in a theatre, looking at the curtain which hides the blank screen, as you wait for the feature picture to begin. What will this picture do for you? How will it affect you? What impact will it have on your life? Will you feel moved—perhaps even to tears? Will you laugh at a comedy, or feel terrified at the crises faced by the hero or heroine? Will you feel wonderful waves of love and compassion—or surges of resentment?

author: Nelson Mandela
title: Long Walk to Freedom
opening_line: Apart from life, a strong constitution, and an abiding connection to the Thembu royal house, the only thing my father bestowed upon me at birth was a name, Rolihlahla. In Xhosa, Rolihlahla literally means “pulling the branch of a tree,” but its colloquial meaning more accurately would be “trouble maker.”

author: Mark Manson
title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck
opening_line: Charles Bukowski was an alcoholic, a womanizer, a chronic gambler, a lout, a cheapskate, a deadbeat, and on his worst days, a poet. He’s probably the last person on earth you would ever look to for life advice or expect to see in any sort of self-help book. Which is why he’s the perfect place to start.

author: Marvin Marshall
title: Discipline Without Stress, Punishment, or Rewards
opening_line: Life is a conversation. Interestingly, the most influential person we talk with all day is ourself, and what we tell ourself has a direct bearing on our behavior, our performance, and our influence on others.

author: Clancy Martin
title: How Not to Kill Yourself: A Portrait of the Suicidal Mind (2023)
opening_line: The last time I tried to kill myself was in my basement with a dog leash.

author: Groucho Marx
title: Groucho and Me
opening_line: The trouble with writing a book about yourself is that you can’t fool around. If you write about someone else, you can stretch the truth from here to Finland. If you write about yourself, the slightest deviation makes you realize instantly that there may be honor among thieves, but you are just a dirty liar.

author: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
title: The Communist Manifesto
opening_line: A specter is haunting Europe, the specter of Communism.

author: A. H. Maslow
title: Toward a Psychology of Being
opening_line: There is now emerging over the horizon a new conception of human sickness and of human health, a psychology that I find so thrilling and so full of wonderful possibilities that I yield to the temptation to present it publicly even before it is checked and confirmed, and before it can be called reliable scientific knowledge.

author: W. Somerset Maugham
title: The Summing Up
opening_line: This is not an autobiography nor is it a book of recollections. In one way and another I have used in my writings whatever has happened to me in the course of my life.

author: W. Somerset Maugham
title: Strictly Personal
opening_line: I have a notion that it is well to tell the reader at the beginning of a narrative what he is in for, and so I shall start by telling you that this is not an account of great events, but of the small things that happened to me during the first fifteen months of the war.

author: Rollo May
title: Man’s Search for Himself
opening_line: One of the few blessings of living in an age of anxiety is that we are forced to become aware of ourselves.

author: Rollo May
title: Love and Will
opening_line: The striking thing about love and will in our day is that, whereas in the past they were always held up to us as the answer to life’s predicaments, they have now themselves become the problem.

author: Mary McCarthy
title: Holiday
opening_line: Like Athena, goddess of wisdom, Vassar College sprang in full battle dress from the head of a man.

author: Mary McCarthy
title: Partisan Review
opening_line: Every age has a keyhole to which its eye is pasted.

author: Mary McCarthy
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Teaching for the wisest of the ancients, was only a form of prompting. Socrates’ pupils, who sought to know what was love, what was justice, what was beauty, and so on, were shown by the philosopher that they already knew the answers to these questions, though they did not know they knew them….

author: Mary McCarthy
title: Harper’s
opening_line: “Pour it on, Colonel,” cried the young man in the Dacron suit excitedly, making his first sortie into the club-car conversation. His face was white as Roquefort and of a glistening, cheeselike texture; he had a shock of tow-colored hair, badly cut and greasy, and a snub nose with large gray pores. Under his darting eyes were two black craters.

author: Tori Murden McClure
title: A Pearl in the Storm
opening_line: In the end, I know I rowed across the Atlantic to find my heart, but in the beginning, I wasn’t aware that it was missing.

author: Frank McCourt
title: Angela’s Ashes
opening_line: My father and mother should have stayed in New York where they met and married and where I was born. Instead, they returned to Ireland when I was four, my brother, Malachy, three, the twins, Oliver and Eugene, barely one, and my sister, Margaret, dead and gone.

author: Frank McCourt
title: Teacher Man
opening_line: Here they come. And I’m not ready. How could I be? I’m a new teacher and learning on the job.

author: Robert McCrum
title: Every Third Thought
opening_line: No one will ever know exactly what happened inside my head on the night of 28 July 1995, but probably it went something like this. First, for reasons that remain mysterious, a surreptitious clot began to form in one of my cerebral arteries, cutting off the blood supply to the one organ in the body that, after the heart, is most greedy for blood.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: Dawn: a curious mixture of noises. Birds, ocean trees soughing in a breeze off the Pacific; then, in the foreground, the steady cropping of buffaloes.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: Like many who buy a motorcycle, there had been for me the problem of getting over the rather harrowing insurance statistics as to just what it is that is likely to happen to you.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: I concede that “mutton snapper” is hardly a prepossessing title. The sheep, from which the name derives, is not much of an animal. No civilized person deals with him except in chops and stews. To bleat is not to sing out in a commanding baritone; to be sheepish is scarcely to possess a virtue for which civilization rolls out its more impressive carpets.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: I have been bird hunting since I was ten years old. I was not much good at it when I was ten, and many years of experience have not made me any better. Sometimes, when asked about the results of my shooting, I am ashamed. Sometimes so ashamed that I lie about it vividly and recklessly.

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: Lately I’ve been having trouble with golf. Which of us has not?

author: Thomas McGuane
title: An Outside Chance: Essays of Sport
opening_line: The fastest way to go from point to point on the face of the earth, assuming that you do not prepare the ground in front of you but take it rough and unimproved, is on a motorcycle.

author: Sharon McMahon
title: The Small and the Mighty
opening_line: New York 1804 Alexander Hamilton was going to die. And he knew it.

author: Dave Meggyesy
title: Out of Their League
opening_line: You may not know it, but you’ve probably seen me on television a few times during the last seven years or so—that is if you’re one of the 25 million Americans who zeroes in on pro football for several hours every fall weekend. I wasn’t a glamour player, and the St. Louis Cardinals, where I played linebacker, wasn’t a glamour team; but I was out there, along with a thousand or so other guys, most of them as anonymous as me. But you won’t see me out there again.

author: Aubrey Menen
title: Dead Man in the Silver Market
opening_line: Men of all races have always sought for a convincing explanation of their own astonishing excellence and they have frequently found what they were looking for.

author: Thomas Merton
title: No Man is an Island
opening_line: A happiness that is sought for ourselves alone can never be found; for a happiness that is diminished by being shared is not big enough to make us happy.

author: James Michener
title: The World Is My Home
opening_line: This will be a strange kind of autobiography because I shall offer the first seven chapters as if I had never written a book, the last seven as if that were all I had done.

author: Bette Midler
title: A View from A Broad
opening_line: I will never forget it! Only moments before I found out that a world tour was being planned for me, I was exactly where I most like to be—flat on my back on my lovely redwood deck, overlooking the glorious, ever-changing moods of the Santa Ana Freeway.

author: Ammi Midstokke
title: The Spokesman-Review
opening_line: Recently, while criticizing my husband for something flawed in his person, like how he laces his boots or something, I was struck by a realization. Either I am perfect or my husband enjoys the relative peace that reigns when we both pretend I am.

author: Dan Millman
title: Sacred Journey of the Peaceful Warrior
opening_line: I wept on my wedding night.

author: Dan Millman
title: Everyday Enlightenment
opening_line: One night, years ago, I fell into the depths of despair over a woman I loved and was losing.

author: Robert Moor
title: On Trails
opening_line: It is impossible to fully appreciate the value of a trail until you have been forced to walk through the wilderness without one.

author: Christopher Morley
title: Pipefuls
opening_line: Today we rather intended to write an essay on Laziness, but were too indolent to do so.

author: Desmond Morris
title: The Naked Ape
opening_line: There are one hundred and ninety-three living species of monkeys and apes. One hundred and ninety-two of them are covered with hair. The exception is a naked ape self-named Homo sapiens.

author: Desmond Morris
title: Catwatching
opening_line: The domestic cat is a contradiction. No animal has developed such an intimate relationship with mankind, while at the same time demanding and getting such independence of movement and action.

author: Edmund Morris
title: Beethoven
opening_line: The British playwright Enid Bagnold once asked a feminist what advice she would give to a twenty-three-year-old housewife who, having lost four children, found herself pregnant again by an abusive, alcoholic husband. “I would urge her to terminate the pregnancy,” the feminist replied. “Then,” said Ms. Bagnold, “you would have aborted Beethoven.”

author: Gouverneur Morris IV
title: The Novels and Stories of Richard Harding Davis
opening_line: He was almost too good to be true. In addition, the gods loved him, and so he had to die young.

author: Lance Morrow
title: The Wall Street Journal
opening_line: I once knew a magazine journalist who was addicted to metaphors. He was, so to speak, an alcoholic of metaphors. If he took one sip from the demon rum of analogy, he would be in the gutter by the end of the paragraph. His journalism suffered from what might be called cirrhosis of the prose.

author: Clark E. Moustakas
title: Loneliness
opening_line: I have experienced loneliness many times in my life but until recently I lived my loneliness without being aware of it.

author: Clark E. Moustakas
title: Loneliness and Love
opening_line: Every once in a while I awaken to the reality that I’m all I got.

author: Kate Murphy
title: The News & Observer
opening_line: I signed up to serve on the media review committee for my middle daughter’s public school library. Meetings are at 7:45 a.m. I am not a morning person and I do not know how I am going to manage one more thing, but as the white Christian mother of three public school students it is very important to me to have influence on what materials my daughters are exposed to in school.

author: Liz Murray
title: Breaking Night
opening_line: The first time Daddy found out about me, it was from behind glass during a routine visit to prison, when Ma lifted her shirt, teary-eyed, exposing her pregnant belly for emphasis.

author: Caitlin Myer
title: Wiving
opening_line: I am fifty years old and have just moved to a seaside town in Portugal. I’m reading in a quiet bar when a man asks why a beautiful woman like me is alone. What he means is, What is happening between your legs? What he means is, You are breaking the rules of the story, but I can set you straight. What he means is, I can fill that terrible gap between your legs.

author: Vladimir Nabokov
title: Speak, Memory
opening_line: The cradle rocks above an abyss, and common sense tells us that our existence is but a brief crack of light between two eternities of darkness.

author: Joe Namath
title: All the Way
opening_line: Something isn’t right. My chest is tight, and I’m just distracted, man, distracted. I’m drinking my daily eight-ounce Cheribundi at the kitchen table as an afternoon storm starts rolling in. Nothing out of the ordinary for August in south Florida, but I’m sure outta my element.

author: Alexei Navalny
title: Patriot
opening_line: Dying really didn’t hurt.

author: Jawaharlal Nehru
title: Jawaharlal Nehru
opening_line: This book was written entirely in prison.

author: Willie Nelson
title: It’s a Long Story
opening_line: A song is a short story.

author: Craig Nettles and Peter Golenbock
title: Balls
opening_line: Some kids dream of joining the circus, others of becoming a major league baseball player. I have been doubly blessed. As a member of the New York Yankees, I have gotten to do both.

author: David Niven
title: The Moon’s a Balloon
opening_line: Nessie, when I first saw her, was seventeen years old, honey-blond, pretty rather than beautiful, the owner of a voluptuous but somehow innocent body and a pair of legs that went on for ever. She was a Picadilly whore. I was a fourteen-year-old heterosexual schoolboy and I met her thanks to my stepfather. (If you would like to skip on and meet Nessie more fully, she reappears on page 41.)

author: David Niven
title: Bring on the Empty Horses
opening_line: When Gertrude Stein returned to New York after a short sojourn to Hollywood somebody asked her…“What is it like—out there?” To which, with little delay and the minimum of careful thought the sage replied…“There is no ‘there’—there.”

author: Richard Nixon
title: RN
opening_line: I was born in a house my father built.

author: Trevor Noah
title: Born a Crime
opening_line: The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all.

author: Sherwin Nuland
title: How We Die
opening_line: Every life is different from any that has gone before it, and so is every death. The uniqueness of each of us extends even to the way we die.

author: Maggie O’Farrell
title: I Am, I Am, I Am
opening_line: On the path ahead, stepping out from behind a boulder, a man appears. We are, he and I, on the far side of a dark tarn that lies hidden in the bowl-curved summit of this mountain. The sky is a milky blue above us; no vegetation grows this far up so it is just me and him, the stones and the still black water. He straddles the narrow track with both booted feet and he smiles. I realize several things. That I passed him earlier, farther down the glen. We greeted each other, in the amiable yet brief manner of those on a country walk. That, on this remote stretch of path, there is no one near enough to hear me call. That he has been waiting for me: he has planned this whole thing, carefully, meticulously, and I have walked into his trap. I see all this, in an instant

author: Tracy O’Neill
title: Woman of Interest
opening_line: A few years back, despite a lifelong renunciation of the urge, I surrendered to obsession with a woman. So I was beside myself.

author: Meghan O’Rourke
title: The Invisible Kingdom
opening_line: The stories we tell about illness usually have startling beginnings—the fall at the supermarket, the lump discovered in the abdomen during a routine exam, the doctor’s call. Not mine. I got sick the way Hemingway says you go broke: “gradually and then suddenly.”

author: P. J. O’Rourke
title: Parliament of Whores
opening_line: The subject of this book is government because I don’t have to do anything about it.

author: P. J. O’Rourke
title: Eat the Rich
opening_line: I had one fundamental question about economics: Why do some places prosper and thrive while others just suck?

author: P. J. O’Rourke
title: A Cry from the Middle
opening_line: What this country needs is fewer people who know what this country needs.

author: Barack Obama
title: A Promised Land
opening_line: Of all the rooms and halls and landmarks that make up the White House and its grounds, it was the West Colonnade that I loved best.

author: Michelle Obama
title: Becoming
opening_line: I spent much of my childhood listening to the sound of striving.

author: Peter Olsson
title: Janusian Days
opening_line: My passion for medicine dawns in the realm of childhood idealism and spiritual innocence. I am ten years old and picture myself as a medical missionary like Albert Schweitzer or Tom Dooley.

author: Susan Orlean
title: Rin Tin Tin
opening_line: He believed the dog was immortal.

author: George Orwell
title: Horizon
opening_line: Most people who bother with the matter at all would admit that the English language is in a bad way, but it is generally assumed that we cannot by conscious action do anything about it.

author: George Orwell
title: Gangrel
opening_line: From a very early age, perhaps the age of five or six, I knew that when I grew up I should be a writer.

author: Charles Osgood
title: Defending Baltimore Against Enemy Attack
opening_line: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times. Charles Dickens didn’t write those words about the year that I was nine in Baltimore, but they happen to fit. That year, 1942, was the best of times for a Baltimore boy who always seemed to be feeling good and the worst of times for a nation reeling from the first blows of World War II.

author: George Packer
title: Our Man
opening_line: Do you mind if we hurry through the early years? There are no mysteries here that can be unlocked by nursery school.

author: Michael A. Paesler and Patrick J. Moyer
title: Near-Field Optics
opening_line: “Siehst du?” in German, “Do you get the picture?” in English, and “Tu vois?” in French are more often than not metaphors that ask about understanding rather than vision.

author: Thomas Paine
title: The Pennsylvania Journal
opening_line: These are the times that try men’s souls.

author: C. Northcote Parkinson
title: Parkinson’s Law
opening_line: Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.

author: Dolly Parton
title: Dolly
opening_line: Once upon a time and far, far away, back in the hollers at the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains of East Tennessee there lived a little girl with yellow hair, blue-green eyes, fair skin, and freckles. She loved to read almost as much as she loved to dream.

author: Dolly Parton
title: Dolly Parton, Storyteller
opening_line: Ever since I was a small child, I’ve always had the gift to rhyme. So I was making up songs before I could even write. I would rhyme everything, whether it was whatever was on the table, what was on the floor, what the kids were doing.

author: Nilay Patel
title: The Verge
opening_line: You fucked up real good, kiddo.

author: Mark Paul
title: The Greatest Gambling Story Every Told
opening_line: A girl with long red hair, perhaps eight years old, was sitting high atop her father’s shoulders, watching the horses load into the gate for the 110th running of the Kentucky Derby. They were standing in the packed grandstand at the stretch near the starting gate; nearly a quarter mile separated them and the finish line. She was holding a sign that read, “Beat the Boys! Althea!”

author: Randy Pausch
title: The Last Lecture
opening_line: I have an engineering problem. While for the most part I’m in terrific physical shape, I have ten tumors in my liver and I have only a few months to live. I am a father of three young children, and married to the woman of my dreams. While I could easily feel sorry for myself, that wouldn’t do them, or me, any good. So, how to spend my very limited time.

author: Nancy Pearl
title: Book Lust
opening_line: I love to read. And while I might not absolutely agree with the Anglo-American man of letters Logan Pearsall Smith, who said, “People say that life is the thing, but I prefer reading,” I come awfully close to subscribing to his sentiment.

author: Nancy Pearl
title: More Book Lust
opening_line: If we were at a twelve-step meeting together, I would have to stand up and say, “Hi, I’m Nancy P., and I’m a readaholic.”

author: Scott Peck
title: The Road Less Travelled
opening_line: Life is difficult.

author: Scott Peck
title: People of the Lie
opening_line: This is a dangerous book.

author: Leonard Peikoff
title: Philosophy: Who Needs It
opening_line: Ayn Rand was not only a novelist and philosopher; she was also a salesman of philosophy—the greatest salesman philosophy has ever had.

author: Esther Perel
title: The State of Affairs
opening_line: There is one simple act of transgression that can rob a couple of their relationship, their happiness, their very identity: an affair.

author: Matthew Perry
title: Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing
opening_line: Hi, my name is Matthew, although you may know me by another name. My friends call me Matty. And I should be dead.

author: Robert Peterson
title: Only the Ball Was White
opening_line: They were saints and sinners, college professors and illiterates, serious men and clowns, teetotalers and Saturday night drunks. They were professional baseball players, some of them the equals of the greatest major-leaguers, with one other common tie: they were all Negroes.

author: Alexandra Petri
title: Washington Post
opening_line: It is a truth universally acknowledged that an American billionaire, in possession of sufficient fortune, must be in want of a Supreme Court justice.

author: Robert S. Phillips
title: Louis L’Amour
opening_line: Louis L’Amour. The name itself sounds highly improbable for the author of Western and adventure novels. As one of his early editors said, L’Amour on a paperback sounded like “a Western written in lipstick.”

author: Mary Laura Philpott
title: I Miss You When I Blink: Essays
opening_line: It’s the perfect sentence, but I didn’t write it. My six-year-old did.

author: Wintley Phipps
title: Your Best Destiny
opening_line: It is no accident that you picked up this book. You’re searching for something.

author: Sidney Poitier
title: The Measure of a Man
opening_line: Many years ago I wrote a book about my life, which was, necessarily, in large part a book about my life in Hollywood. More recently I decided that I wanted to write a book about life. Just life itself. What I’ve learned by living more than seventy years of it.

author: Billy Porter
title: Unprotected
opening_line: This is not a coming-out-story. It’s not a down-low story either. I never could have passed for straight, even if I’d wanted to, and so I never had the dubious luxury of living a lie.

author: Katherine Anne Porter
title: Flair
opening_line: Its beginnings were obscure. Like that of the human race whose history it was destined to adorn.

author: Katherine Anne Porter
title: The Collected Essays and Occasional Writings of Katherine Anne Porter
opening_line: Of all fine sights in the world to me, the best is that of an artist growing great, adding to his art with his years, as his life and his art are inseparable.

author: Neil Postman
title: The Disappearance of Childhood
opening_line: Children are the living messages we send to a time we will not see.

author: Neil Postman
title: Amusing Ourselves to Death
opening_line: We were keeping our eye on 1984. When the year came and the prophecy didn’t, thoughtful Americans sang softly in praise of themselves. The roots of liberal democracy had held. Wherever else the terror had happened, we, at least, had not been visited by Orwellian nightmares.

author: Colin Powell
title: My American Journey
opening_line: I usually trust my instincts. This time I did not, which almost proved fatal.

author: Joshua Prager
title: Roe
opening_line: Nearly half a century ago, Roe v. Wade secured a woman’s legal right to obtain an abortion. The ruling has been contested with ever-increasing intensity, dividing and reshaping American politics. And yet for all its prominence, the person most profoundly connected to it has remained unknown: the child whose conception occasioned the lawsuit.

author: Price Pritchett
title: You2
opening_line: I’m sitting in a quiet room at the Millcroft Inn, a peaceful little place hidden back among the pine trees about an hour out of Toronto. It’s just past noon, late July, and I’m listening to the desperate sounds of a life-or-death struggle going on a few feet away.

author: Mario Puzo
title: The Fourth K
opening_line: Oliver Oliphant was one hundred years old and his mind was a clear as a bell. Unfortunately for him.

author: Ernie Pyle
title: New York World-Telegram
opening_line: I took a walk along the historic coast of Normandy in the country of France. It was a lovely day for strolling along the seashore. Men were sleeping on the sand, some of them sleeping forever. Men were floating in the water, but they didn’t know they were in the water, for they were dead.

author: Anna Quindlen
title: Lots of Candles, Plenty of Cake
opening_line: It’s odd when I think of the arc of my life, from child to young woman to aging adult. First I was who I was. Then I didn’t know who I was. Then I invented someone, and became her. Then I began to like what I’d invented. And finally I was what I was again.

author: Heather Radke
title: Butts
opening_line: The first butt I remember isn’t my own. It’s my mother’s.

author: Randy Rainbow
title: Playing with Myself
opening_line: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times…. Fine, I didn’t write that. But it’s how I really wanted the opening chapter of this book to begin. No phrase could more perfectly epitomize the last six years of my life, full of unimaginable highs and lows, for me personally and on the world stage.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Philosophy, Who Needs It
opening_line: If you want me to name in one sentence what is wrong with the modern world, I will say that never before has the world been clamoring so desperately for answers to crucial problems—and never before has the world been so frantically committed to the belief that no answers are possible.

author: Ayn Rand
title: The Los Angeles Times
opening_line: The death of Marilyn Monroe shocked people with an impact different from their reaction to the death of any other movie star or public figure. All over the world, people felt a peculiar sense of personal involvement and of protest, like a universal cry of “Oh, no!”

author: Ayn Rand
title: Philosophy, Who Needs It
opening_line: The most appropriate title for this discussion would be “I told you so.” But since that would be in somewhat dubious taste, I shall leave this untitled.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Philosophy, Who Needs It
opening_line: “God grant me the serenity to accept things I cannot change, courage to change things I can, and wisdom to know the difference.” This remarkable statement is attributed to a theologian with whose ideas I disagree in every fundamental respect: Reinhold Niebuhr. But—omitting the form of a prayer, i.e., the implication that one’s mental-emotional states are a gift from God—that statement is profoundly true, as a summary and a guideline: It names the mental attitude which a rational man must seek to achieve.”

author: Tom Rath
title: It’s Not About You
opening_line: Life is not about you. It’s about what you do for others. The faster you are able to get over yourself, the more you can do for the people who matter most.

author: Ronald Reagan
title: An American Life
opening_line: If I’d gotten the job I wanted at Montgomery Ward, I suppose I never would have left Illinois.

author: Christopher Reeve
title: Still Me
opening_line: A few months after the accident I had an idea for a short film about a quadriplegic who lives in a dream. During the day, lying in his hospital bed, he can’t move, of course. But at night he dreams that he’s whole again, and is able to do anything and go everywhere.

author: Joy-Ann Reid
title: Medgar and Myrtle
opening_line: The thing about love is that it has no chill.

author: Carl Reiner
title: I Remember Me
opening_line: I Remember Me offers fifty-five chapters of varying lengths, containing remembrances of things past. It is my theory that these memories are stored in a part of one’s brain that does not allow your mind to access them until you are at least ninety years old. Three months ago, I became eligible, and the following is what my mind had stored in my brain.

author: Agnes Repplier
title: In Pursuit of Laughter (1936)
opening_line: No man pursues what he has at hand. No man recognizes the need of pursuit until that which he desires has escaped him.

author: James Reston
title: Deadline
opening_line: I started to write this book as a political memoir of my fifty years as a reporter, columnist, Washington correspondent, and executive editor of The New York Times, but it got away from me and turned into a personal memoir of love and hope.

author: Richard Rhodes
title: A Hole in the World
opening_line: When I was thirteen months old, my mother killed herself.

author: Rhonda Rich
title: The New Brunswick News
opening_line: On a Sunday morning, tucked into bed on the island of St. Simons, the place where I, at the age of 13, accepted the calling that had haunted me since I was four — that of becoming a writer—Tink brought me a copy of The New York Times and coffee loaded with cream.

author: Ann Richards
title: Straight from the Heart
opening_line: My Daddy used to say, “She looks like she was rode hard and put up wet,” and that is about the way I feel on finishing this book. Telling the story of your life is not an easy task.

author: Heather Cox Richardson
title: West from Appomattox
opening_line: A week after the 2004 presidential election, a friend sent me a map of America with the red and blue states superimposed over the Confederate and Union states of the Civil War years. The Republican red states fit almost perfectly over the southern states that supported the Confederacy…and the Democratic blue states fit closely over the states that had supported the Union.

author: Heather Cox Richardson
title: How the South Won the Civil War
opening_line: The moment in July 1964 when Arizona Senator Barry Goldwater took the stage at Cow Palace outside San Francisco and beamed at the cheering Republicans who had just nominated him for president is iconic—but not for the reasons we remember.

author: Mary Roach
title: Stiff
opening_line: The way I see it, being dead is not terribly far off from being on a cruise ship. Most of your time is spent lying on your back. The brain has shut down. The flesh begins to soften. Nothing much new happens, and nothing is expected of you.

author: Mary Roach
title: Spook
opening_line: I don’t recall my mood the morning I was born, but I imagine I felt a bit out of sorts. Nothing I looked at was familiar. People were staring at me and making odd sounds and wearing incomprehensible items. Everything seemed too loud, and nothing made the slightest amount of sense.

author: Mary Roach
title: Bonk
opening_line: A man sits in a room, manipulating his kneecaps. It is 1983, on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. The man, a study subject, has been told to do this for four minutes, stop, and then resume for a minute more. Then he can put his pants back on, collect his payment, and go home with an entertaining story to tell at suppertime.

author: Mary Roach
title: Fuzz: When Nature Breaks the Law
opening_line: On June 26, 1659, a representative from five towns in a province of northern Italy initiated legal proceedings against caterpillars.

author: Tom Robbins
title: Esquire
opening_line: When one is on a pilgrimage to the Canyon of the Vaginas, one has to be careful about asking directions.

author: Tom Robbins
title: Playboy
opening_line: Kissing is our greatest invention. On the list of great inventions, it ranks higher than the Thermos bottle and the Airstream trailer; higher, even, than room service, possibly because the main reason room service was created was so people could stay in bed and kiss without going hungry.

author: Jackie Robinson
title: I Never Had It Made
opening_line: My grandfather was born into slavery, and although my mother and father, Mallie and Jerry Robinson, lived during an era when physical slavery had been abolished, they also lived in a newer, more sophisticated kind of slavery than the kind Mr. Lincoln struck down.

author: Ginger Rogers
title: Ginger Rogers
opening_line: My mother told me I was dancing before I was born. She could feel my toes tapping wildly inside her for months.

author: James Haywood Rolling, Jr.
title: Growing Up Ugly
opening_line: I used to think I was born ugly. I wasn’t sure why in the beginning. I couldn’t pin down the source of my ill-fittedness and out-of-placeness until I finally stared myself down in a mirror one afternoon after being ridiculed by a little girl whose name I don’t remember.

author: Linda Ronstadt
title: Simple Dreams
opening_line: July 1946 On her way to the hospital the day I was born, my mother wanted to stop and eat a hamburger. She was hungry, and maybe wanted to fortify herself against the brutally hard work of pushing out a baby, a task that lay immediately and ominously before her.

author: Eleanor Roosevelt
title: This is My Story
opening_line: My mother was one of the most beautiful women I have ever seen. The Halls were noted for their beauty and charm in the days when New York City was small enough to have a society spelled with a capital S! She had been largely brought up by her father, who died when she was seventeen. It must have been a curious household, for my Grandfather Hall never engaged in business. He lived on what his father and mother gave him.

author: Jacqueline Rose
title: On Violence and On Violence Against Women
opening_line: It is a truism to say that everyone knows violence when they see it, but if one thing has become clear over the past decade it is that the most prevalent, insidious forms of violence are those that cannot be seen.

author: Rosemarie Rossetti
title: Take Back Your Life!
opening_line: It was Saturday, June 13, 1998, a glorious day for many reasons. My husband Mark and I were celebrating our third wedding anniversary, and the weather was beautiful—warm and windless. We decided to go for a bicycle ride on a trail in Granville, Ohio, and arrived about 5:00 p.m. We were happily riding for about ten minutes when Mark heard a loud noise that sounded like a gunshot. He slowed down to investigate, then called ahead to me, “Look over there, something’s falling!” I glanced to my right and saw a few leaves floating to the ground. Then Mark yelled, “Stop!”

author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
title: The Social Contract
opening_line: Man was born free, and everywhere he is in chains.

author: Rita Rudner
title: Naked Beneath My Clothes
opening_line: An Introduction: I Was a Teenage, Pregnant, Alcoholic, Junkie Ninja Hooker.

author: Rita Rudner
title: Rita Rudner’s Guide to Men
opening_line: This is a guide to men. It’s not that I’ve had much experience, or that I’ve done lots of research—it’s just, they’re not very hard to figure out.

author: Salman Rushdie
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: 1989. Afterward, when the world was exploding around him, he felt annoyed with himself for having forgotten the name of the BBC reporter who told him that his old life was over and a new, darker existence was about to begin. She called him at home, on his private line, without explaining how she got the number. “How does it feel,” she asked him, “to know that you have just been sentenced to death by Ayatollah Khomeini?”

author: Dan Ruskin
title: Tips
opening_line: In the beginning, there was a bar. And there was a piano. And the Bartender said “Let us bring the piano into the bar.” And so it was done. And it was good.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: The Problems of Philosophy
opening_line: Is there any knowledge in the world which is so certain that no reasonable man could doubt it?

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Our Knowledge of the External World
opening_line: Philosophy, from the earliest times, has made greater claims, and achieved fewer results, than any other branch of learning.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: The Dial
opening_line: Moralists, in the main, have been a somewhat forbidding race. Their main preoccupation has usually been to try to prevent people from doing that they wanted to do, on the ground—formerly explicit, but now seldom avowed—that the natural man is wicked.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: The Conquest of Happiness
opening_line: Animals are happy so long as they have health and enough to eat. Human beings, one feels, ought to be, but in the modern world they are not, at least in a great majority of cases.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Why I Am Not a Christian
opening_line: Sex, more than any other element in human life, is still viewed by many, perhaps by most, in an irrational way.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Why I Am Not a Christian
opening_line: Many people tell us that without a belief in God a man can be neither happy nor virtuous.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: My Philosophical Development
opening_line: My philosophical development may be divided into various stages according to the problems with which I have been concerned and the men whose work has influenced me. There is only one constant preoccupation: I have throughout been anxious to discover how much we can be said to know and with what degree of certainty or doubtfulness.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: The Autobiography of Bertrand Russell, 1872-1914
opening_line: Three passions, simple but overwhelmingly strong, have governed my life: the longing for love, the search for knowledge, and unbearable pity for the suffering of mankind.

author: Harold Russell
title: Victory in My Hands
opening_line: When I woke up I found I had no hands.

author: Carl Safina
title: Becoming Wild
opening_line: A flock of scarlet macaws bursts from the deep rainforest like flaming comets, several dozen big, bright birds with streaming tails and hot colors. With much self-generated fanfare, they settle into high trees above a steep riverbank. They’re noisy and playful. If this is the serious business of their lives, they seem to be enjoying themselves and each other.

author: Deborah Salomon
title: The Pilot
opening_line: If food were poetry, subs would be limericks, sushi a haiku and salad a sonnet—14 lines of freshness and exquisite flavor. An antidote to winter sludge. A rainbow of colors and often a surprise.

author: George Sanders
title: Memoirs of a Professional Cad
