opening_line: On July 3, 1906, the world was at peace. Nothing of any consequence seemed to be happening in the capital cities of any of its countries. Nothing disturbed the summer lethargy of its population. Everywhere people dozed contentedly, unaware that an event of major importance was taking place in St. Petersburg, Russia. At number 6 Petroffski Ostroff, to Margaret and Henry Sanders, a son of dazzling beauty and infinite charm was being born. It was I.

author: Robert M. Sapolsky
title: A Primate’s Memoir
opening_line: I joined the baboon troop during my twenty-first year. I had never planned to become a savanna baboon when I grew up; instead I had always assumed I would become a mountain gorilla.

author: William Saroyan
title: Chance Meetings
opening_line: The thing about the people one meets on arrival, upon being born, is that they are the people they are, and not the people any of us, had he indeed had a choice, might be likely to have chosen. These meetings are chance meetings.

author: Virginia Satir
title: Peoplemaking
opening_line: When I was five, I decided that when I grew up I’d be a “children’s detective on parents.”

author: Stacy Schiff
title: A Great Improvisation
opening_line: In December 1776, a small boat delivered an old man to France.

author: Stacy Schiff
title: The Witches
opening_line: In 1692 the Massachusetts Bay Colony executed fourteen women, five men, and two dogs for witchcraft.

author: Stacy Schiff
title: The Revolutionary
opening_line: Samuel Adams delivered what may count as the most remarkable second act in American life. It was all the more confounding after the first: he was a perfect failure until middle age.

author: Peter Schjeldahl
title: The Village Voice
opening_line: Did Pablo Picasso exist? It gets harder to believe. Think of him wielding pencil and pecker, astride a century. He rewired the world’s optic nerves and imagination.

author: Peter Schjeldahl
title: The Village Voice
opening_line: At a dinner party recently, a nice young political consultant rhapsodized to me about the portent of the millennium, in which he saw the dawn of, yes, a New Age. I wasn’t having it. I remarked that scholars now date the birth of Jesus to about 6 B.C., so the millennium passed already.

author: Peter Schjeldahl
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Lung cancer, rampant. No surprise. I’ve smoked since I was sixteen, behind the high-school football bleachers in Northfield, Minnesota. I used to fear the embarrassment of dying youngish, letting people natter sagely, “He smoked, you know.” But at seventy-seven I’m into the actuarial zone.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer
title: Parerga and Paralipomena
opening_line: Ignorance is degrading only when found in company with riches.

author: Charles M. Schulz
title: My Life with Charlie Brown
opening_line: And so, 25 years have gone by. At one strip per day, that comes to almost 10,000 comic strips. Actually, this is not so much when you consider the longevity of many other comic features. Employees receive wristwatches if they have put in this much time with a company, but a comic-strip artist just keeps on drawing. (Somehow a comic-strip artist is never regarded as an employee.)

author: Murray Schumach
title: The New York Times
opening_line: It was not quite proper to have printed The Carpetbaggers between covers of a book. It should have been inscribed on the walls of a public lavatory.

author: Alice Sebold
title: Lucky
opening_line: In the tunnel where I was raped, a tunnel that was once an underground entry to an amphitheater, a place where actors burst forth from underneath the seats of a crowd, a girl had been murdered and dismembered. I was told this story by the police. In comparison, they said I was lucky.

author: Parul Sehgal
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: It is a truth only fitfully acknowledged that whom the gods wish to destroy, they first give an opinion column.

author: Jerry Seinfeld
title: Is This Anything?
opening_line: “Is this anything?” is what every new comedian says to every other comedian about any new bit. Ideas that come from nowhere and mean nothing. But in the world of stand-up comedy, literal bars of gold.

author: Peter Selgin
title: Confessions of a Left-Handed Man
opening_line: In kindergarten, when I presented her with crayon drawings of the Queen Mary and of the Empire State Building lit up like a Christmas tree at night, Mrs. Decker kissed my cheek, my first taste of artistic glory.

author: Peter Selgin
title: The Inventors
opening_line: This book is about two men who were very important to me. The first was there at my conception, the second came along thirteen years later. Each had a profound influence on me. You could say they invented me, such was their influence.

author: Peter Selgin
title: Your First Page
opening_line: I once spoke with a New York City fireman whose job included talking suicidal “jumpers” down from building edges and bridges. He told me something that has stayed with me ever since. He said that in every case, without exception, when the person jumped, the look on his or her face was always the same. It said, in essence, “Wrong decision.”

author: Tom Selleck
title: You Never Know
opening_line: On a sweeping turn, one of the wheels slipped off the pavement onto the soft dirt shoulder. The rear-engine car immediately lost traction, went into an uncontrolled skid and over the edge.

author: Jennifer Senior
title: The Atlantic
opening_line: When Bobby McIlvane died on September 11, 2001, his desk at home was a study in plate tectonics, coated in shifting piles of leather-bound diaries and yellow legal pads.

author: Jennifer Senior
title: The Atlantic
opening_line: It is an insolent cliché, almost, to note that our culture lacks the proper script for ending friendships. We have no rituals to observe, no paperwork to do, no boilerplate dialogue to crib from.

author: Rod Serling
title: Los Angeles Times
opening_line: There is a bitter sadness and special irony that attends the passing of Martin Luther King. Quickly and with ease, we offer up a chorus of posthumous praise—the ritual dirge so time-honored and comfortable and undemanding of anything but rhetoric. In death, we offer the acknowledgement of the man and his dream that we denied him in life.

author: Josh Shaffer
title: News & Observer
opening_line: To the ears of a musical novice, the tuba ranks lowest in the family of instruments—an oafish cousin with a voice like a bullfrog. It lacks the flash of a saxophone, the brashness of a trumpet or the showiness of a piccolo—the melodic equivalent of a St. Bernard, warbling from the orchestra’s back row.

author: Josh Shaffer
title: News & Observer
opening_line: The bagpipe occupies the strangest rung on the musical ladder, shaped like an octopus in plaid pants, sounding to some like a goose with its foot caught in an escalator and played during history’s most lopsided battles—by the losing side.

author: William Shatner
title: Boldly Go
opening_line: Knowledge feeds me. It’s as necessary to my existence as oxygen. It thrills me.

author: Dan Shaughnessy and Stan Grossfield
title: Fenway
opening_line: It’s personal. There’s no other way to explain the sentimental feelings many of us have for old, inanimate objects, like sweaters, cars, houses, and baseball parks.

author: Gail Sheehy
title: Passages
opening_line: Without warning, in the middle of my thirties, I had a breakdown of nerve.

author: Sidney Sheldon
title: The Other Side of Me
opening_line: At the age of seventeen, working as a delivery boy at Afremov’s drugstore in Chicago was the perfect job, because it made it possible for me to steal enough sleeping pills to commit suicide.

author: Allan Sherman
title: A Gift of Laughter
opening_line: My life has been a wild ride, up-and-down, up-and-down. I have always been a yo-yo on a roller coaster, and if I never quite fell off—if I’ve been able to hang on and enjoy the ride this far—it is because God gave me one shining thing, a gift of laughter.

author: David Shields and Shane Salerno
title: Salinger
opening_line: J. D. Salinger spent ten years writing The Catcher in the Rye and the rest of his life regretting it.

author: Gary Shteyngart
title: The Atlantic
opening_line: My first glimpse of Royal Caribbean’s Icon of the Seas, from the window of an approaching Miami cab, brings on a feeling of vertigo, nausea, amazement, and distress. I shut my eyes in defense, as my brain tells my optic nerves to try again.

author: Emily Shugerman
title: The Daily Beast
opening_line: For weeks now, commenters have flooded Tennessee nurse Tiffany Dover’s Facebook wall with messages of tribute, praising her kindness and beauty and offering their condolences for her loss. “Tiffany died a hero,” they wrote—and “RIP Angel.” There are more than 22,000 comments on her last Facebook post, from people around the world—a collective grieving and outpouring of anger for the 30-year-old mother of two. But Tiffany Dover is not dead.

author: Emily Shugerman
title: The Daily Beast
opening_line: When volunteers at Venue Church in Chattanooga, Tennessee, arrived at their pastor’s house last November, they were hoping to raise his spirits with a surprise visit. Instead they got a shock: Pastor Tavner Smith was alone with a female church employee—she in a towel, he in his boxers.

author: Phil Silvers
title: This Laugh Is On Me
opening_line: When I was eight I sang at a stag coming-out-of-jail party for a local hoodlum named Little Doggie. In the middle of my number, a man was shot dead at my feet.

author: Nina Simone
title: I Put a Spell on You
opening_line: When I used to get blue years ago James Baldwin would say the same thing to me each time, “This is the world you have made for yourself Nina, now you have to live in it.“ Jimmy was always a man to see things as they really are and his gaze would never flinch no matter how unpleasant the things he saw were.

author: Upton Sinclair
title: The Autobiography of Upton Sinclair
opening_line: My first recollection of life is one that my mother insisted I could not possibly have, because I was only eighteen months old at the time.

author: Michael A. Singer
title: The Untethered Soul
opening_line: In case you haven’t noticed, you have a mental dialogue going on inside your head that never stops. It just keeps going and going.

author: Osbert Sitwell
title: Left Hand, Right Hand!
opening_line: A robust old country-neighbor, one of the last of the squires, was heard during a severe thunderstorm thus to address his faithful and aging servant: “Alec, you damn fool, don’t stand about there, doing nothing! Climb up the lightning-conductor, can’t you, and see if it’s working!”

author: Robert Slater
title: Warrior Statesman
opening_line: The black eyepatch dominated Moshe Dayan’s appearance, like some dark, spidery animal wrapped around his face.

author: Grace Slick
title: Somebody to Love?
opening_line: It’s Chicago, 1973. Jefferson Airplane is tuning up and I’m standing onstage getting ready to sing. Some guy in the audience stands up and shouts, “Hey, Gracie—take off your chastity belt.”

author: Scott A. Small
title: Forgetting
opening_line: As a memory specialist, all I hear about is forgetting.

author: H. Allen Smith
title: Lost in the Horse Latitudes
opening_line: This is the last chapter.

author: H. Allen Smith
title: The Life and Legend of Gene Fowler
opening_line: The picturesque and comfortable little town of Nyack snuggles up to the Hudson River at the point where it widens into the Tappan Zee. Nyack is on the west shore of the Hudson. Once widely acclaimed as the most beautiful river on earth, today the Hudson is only 9.2 percent water.

author: Patti Smith
title: Just Kids
opening_line: I was asleep when he died. I had called the hospital to say one more good night, but he had gone under, beneath layers of morphine. I held the receiver and listened to his labored breathing through the phone, knowing I would never hear him again.

author: Walter “Red” Smith
title: New York Herald-Tribune
opening_line: Now it is done. Now the story ends. And there is no way to tell it. The art of fiction is dead. Reality has strangled invention. Only the utterly impossible, the inexpressibly fantastic, can ever be plausible again.

author: Tim Snyder
title: On Tyranny
opening_line: History does not repeat, but it does instruct.

author: Rebecca Solnit
title: Men Explain Things to Me
opening_line: One evening over dinner in March 2008, I began to joke, as I often had before, about writing an essay called “Men Explain Things to Me.” Every writer has a stable of ideas that never make it to the racetrack, and I’d been trotting this pony out recreationally once in a while.

author: Rebecca Solnit
title: Men Explain Things to Me
opening_line: It was a key match in the World Cup of Ideas. The teams vied furiously for the ball. The all-star feminist team tried repeatedly to kick it through the goalposts marked Widespread Social Problems, while the opposing team, staffed by the mainstream media and mainstream dudes, was intent on getting it into the net called Isolated Event.

author: Alexander Solzhenitsyn
title: The Oak and the Calf
opening_line: Underground is where you expect to find revolutionaries. But not writers.

author: Alexander Solzhenitsyn
title: Foreign Affairs
opening_line: Anyone not hopelessly blinded by his own illusions must recognize that the West today finds itself in a crisis, perhaps even in mortal danger.

author: Sonia Sotomayor
title: My Beloved World
opening_line: I was barely awake, but my mother was already screaming. I knew Papi would start screaming in a second. That much was routine, but the substance of their argument was new, and it etched that morning into my memory.

author: Howard Sounes
title: Charles Bukowski
opening_line: Charles Bukowski raised himself up from his chair and got a beer from the refrigerator behind him on stage. The audience applauded as he drank, tipping the bottle until it was upside down and he had drained the last golden drop. “This is not a prop,” he said, speaking slowly with a lilt to his voice, like W. C. Fields. “It’s a necesssssity.”

author: Benjamin Spock
title: The Common Sense of Baby and Child Care
opening_line: You know more than you think you do.

author: Bruce Springsteen
title: Born to Run
opening_line: I come from a boardwalk town where almost everything is tinged with a bit of fraud. So am I.

author: Francis Spufford
title: The Child That Books Built
opening_line: “I can always tell when you’re reading somewhere in the house,“ my mother used to say. “There’s a special silence, a reading silence.“

author: Harvey Stanbrough
title: Writing Better Fiction
opening_line: Staple it to the inside of your eyeballs, folks: All good fiction is character-driven.

author: Tim Stanley
title: The Telegraph
opening_line: A lot of Lefties are learning today that it’s messy to cry through a nose ring.

author: John Steinbeck
title: Travels with Charley
opening_line: When I was very young and the urge to be someplace else was on me, I was assured by mature people that maturity would cure this itch. When years described me as mature, the remedy prescribed was middle age. In middle age I was assured that greater age would calm my fever and now that I am fifty-eight perhaps senility will do the job. Nothing has worked.

author: David Steinberg
title: Inside Comedy
opening_line: Insecurity combined with arrogance is good DNA for a comedian. So is anger, aggression, and sadness.

author: Richard Stengel
title: You’re Too Kind
opening_line: Perfect, gentle reader: I will not begin this book with a tribute to your discernment, because a person of your obvious accomplishments would certainly be immune to such blandishments. You would surely see through such transparent puffery and reject it out of hand. Someone with as much self-assurance and insight as you would not want any soft soap and sycophancy, but rather candor and direct truth. Well, nothing personal, dear reader, but I doubt it.

author: Robert Louis Stevenson
title: Across the Plains: With Other Memories and Essays
opening_line: It had thundered on the Friday night, but the sun rose on Saturday without a cloud. We were at sea—there is no other adequate expression—on the plains of Nebraska.

author: Sharon Stone
title: The Beauty of Living Twice
opening_line: I opened my eyes, and there he was standing over me, just inches from my face. A stranger looking at me with so much kindness that I was sure I was going to die. He was stroking my head, my hair; God, he was handsome. I wished he were someone who loved me instead of someone whose next words were “You’re bleeding into your brain.”

author: Anthony Storr
title: Human Aggression
opening_line: That man is an aggressive creature will hardly be disputed.

author: Anthony Storr
title: Churchill Revised
opening_line: The psychiatrist who takes it upon himself to attempt a character study of an individual who he has never met is engaged upon a project which is full of risk.

author: Anthony Storr
title: British Medical Journal
opening_line: Isaac Newton is generally acknowledged to have been one of the greatest creative men of genius who ever existed. It also happened that he showed many striking abnormalities of personality, and at one time was considered mad by his contemporaries.

author: Anthony Storr
title: Churchill's Black Dog, Kafka's Mice, and Other Phenomena of the Human Mind
opening_line: Men who commit violent crimes are not infrequently told by magistrates or judges that they have behaved like animals. This is grossly unfair to other species.

author: Dee Stuart
title: The Astonishing Armadillo
opening_line: Slowly, slowly for the past 150 years, a small army has trundled steadily northward from Mexico. In 1854 the army crossed the Mexican border and invaded Texas. The invaders were small creatures, each with a head like a lizard’s, eyes like a pig’s, ears like a mule’s, a shout like a hog’s, claws like a bear’s, and a tail like a rat’s. These astonishing creatures were nine-banded armadillos.

author: William Styron
title: Darkness Visible
opening_line: In Paris on a chilly evening late in October of 1985, I first became aware that the struggle with the disorder in my mind—a struggle which had engaged me for several months—might have a fatal outcome.

author: Lixing Sun
title: The Liars of Nature and the Nature of Liars
opening_line: She is pregnant. Raising a child takes a lot of time and energy, yet she is short of both. Homeless, she has no choice but to find somebody else to take care of her baby—for free. It’s not easy, but she knows how to pull it off.

author: Willie Sutton
title: Where the Money Was
opening_line: What am I doing, I ask myself, standing on a corner at six o’clock in the morning freezing my ass off? Hell, I am almost forty-nine years old. I have been a fugitive for three full years now. I am number one on the FBI Wanted List. If I am caught I will go back to prison for life. They don’t even have to catch me for another bank robbery, all they have to do is get their hands on me.

author: Earl Swift
title: The Big Roads
opening_line: I was overdue for a road trip. It had been years since I’d last embraced that most cherished of American freedoms: to slide behind the wheel of a car equipped with a good stereo and comfortable seats, and head out into the country, beholden to no particular route, no timetable; to grow inured to the road, the thrum of the tires, the warbling silence and thuds of a big truck’s slipstream, the whistle of hot summer past the windows. To live off the contents of a cooler on the floorboards and whatever sustenance the road happened to offer.

author: Earl Swift
title: Auto Biography
opening_line: Behold Tommy Arney: six-one, two-forty, biceps big as most men’s thighs and displayed to maximum effect in the black wifebeater that is his warm-weather fashion essential.

author: Jonathan Swift
title: Miscellanies
opening_line: We have just religion enough to make us hate, but not enough to make us love one another.

author: Nicholas L. Syrett
title: An Open Secret
opening_line: On March 4, 1960, Robert Allerton became a father. He was 86-years-old at the time and his newly adopted son, John Gregg, was 60. The pair had already been living together and calling themselves father and son for almost four decades.

author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
title: The Black Swan
opening_line: Before the discovery of Australia, people in the Old World were convinced that all swans were white, an unassailable belief as it seemed completely confirmed by empirical evidence. The sighting of the first black swan might have been an interesting surprise for a few ornithologists (and others extremely concerned with the coloring of birds), but that is not where the significance of the story lies.

author: Gay Talese
title: Esquire
opening_line: Frank Sinatra, holding a glass of bourbon in one hand and a cigarette in the other, stood in a dark corner of the bar between two attractive but fading blondes who sat waiting for him to say something.

author: Gay Talese
title: The Kingdom and the Power
opening_line: Most journalists are restless voyeurs who see the warts on the world, the imperfections in people and places.

author: Greg Tamblyn
title: Atilla the Gate Agent
opening_line: I once had an engagement in the town of Normal, Illinois. I was delighted to learn that a place called Normal actually existed, because I happen to live just a few miles from the town of Peculiar, Missouri. I don’t think it’s any accident of the universe that I live a lot closer to Peculiar than Normal.

author: Barbara Brown Taylor
title: An Altar in the World
opening_line: If I had a dollar for every time I heard someone say, “I am spiritual but not religious,” then I might not be any wiser about what that means—but I would be richer. I hear the phrase on the radio. I read it in interviews. People often say it to my face when they learn that I am a religion professor who spent years as a parish priest.

author: Barbara Brown Taylor
title: Holy Envy
opening_line: The book in your hands is a small window on a large subject. Set at a private liberal arts college in the foothills of the Appalachians, it is the story of a Christian minister who lost her way in the church and found a new home in the classroom.

author: Nikola Tesla
title: Electrical Experimenter
opening_line: The progressive development of man is vitally dependent on invention. It is the most important product of his creative brain. Its ultimate purpose is the complete mastery of mind over the material world, the harnessing of the forces of nature to human needs.

author: Lewis Thomas
title: The Youngest Science: Notes of a Medicine Watcher
opening_line: I have always had a bad memory, as far back as I can remember.

author: Wright Thompson
title: ESPN.com
opening_line: Pat Conroy’s dad hit him after games. He hit him with fists, and with open palms, hit him until blood ran from Pat’s nose or lip onto his basketball jersey. Don Conroy didn’t hit his son only after games. He hit him for smiling at the wrong time, talking at the wrong time, crying at the wrong time, for trying to defend his battered mother at the wrong time. On occasion, he hit him just for the hell of it.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Walden
opening_line: When I wrote the following pages, or rather the bulk of them, I lived alone, in the woods, a mile from any neighbor, in a house which I had built myself, on the shore of Walden Pond, in Concord, Massachusetts, and earned my living by the labor of my hands only. I lived there two years and two months. At present I am a sojourner in civilized life again.

author: Gary G. Tibbetts
title: How the Great Scientists Reasoned
opening_line: In the beginning was the book of Nature. For eon after eon, the pages of the book turned with no human to read them.

author: Gene Tierney
title: Self-Portrait
opening_line: It is a terrible thing to feel no fear, no alarm, when you are standing on a window ledge fourteen stories above the street. I felt tired, lost, and numb—but unafraid.

author: Natasha Trethewey
title: Memorial Drive
opening_line: The last image of my mother, but for the photographs taken of her body at the crime scene, is the formal portrait made only a few months before her death.

author: Hugh Trevor-Roper
title: The Last Days of Hitler
opening_line: Now that the new order is past, and the thousand-year reich has crumbled in a decade, we are able at last, picking among the still smoking rubble, to discover the truth about that fantastic and tragical episode.

author: Calvin Trillin
title: Quite Enough of Calvin Trillin
opening_line: The reason so many Hollywood movies are made about nerds in high school who triumph in some improbable way over the jocks is this: Nearly everybody who makes movies in Hollywood was himself a nerd in high school.

author: Calvin Trillin
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: To memorize the first ten digits of pi, you simply have to sing, to the tune of the Mousketeers song, “If numbers had a heaven / their god would surely be / 3.1415 / 92653.”

author: Calvin Trillin
title: Quite Enough of Calvin Trillin
opening_line: It’s common these days for memoirs of childhood to concentrate on some dark secret within the authors ostensibly happy family. It’s not just common; it’s pretty much mandatory.

author: Calvin Trillin
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: It’s said that when James Thurber, as a young newspaper reporter, was told by an editor that his story’s first paragraph, what newspaper people might refer to as his lede, suffered from wordiness, he handed in a rewrite whose opening paragraph was, in its entirety, “Dead.” There followed a second paragraph: “That’s what the man was when they found him with a knife in his back at 4pm in front of Riley’s saloon at the corner of 52nd and 12th streets.”

author: Harry S Truman
title: Memoirs
opening_line: Within the first few months I discovered that being a President is like riding a tiger. A man has to keep on riding or be swallowed.

author: Mary L. Trump
title: Too Much and Never Enough
opening_line: I’d always liked my name. As a kid at sailing camp in the 1970s, everybody called me Trump. It was a source of pride not because the name was associated with power and real estate (back then my family was unknown outside of Brooklyn and Queens) but because something about the sound of it suited me, a tough six-year-old, afraid of nothing.

author: Barbara W. Tuchman
title: The Guns of August
opening_line: So gorgeous was the spectacle on the May morning of 1910 when nine kings rode in the funeral of Edward VII of England that the crowd, waiting in hushed and black-clad awe, could not keep back gasps of admiration.

author: Barbara W. Tuchman
title: The March of Folly
opening_line: A phenomenon noticeable throughout history regardless of place or period is the pursuit by governments of policies contrary to their own interests.

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: The Observer
opening_line: Night- nurses at the bedside of good drama, we critics keep a holy vigil. Black circles rim our eyes as we pray for the survival of our pet patient….

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: The Observer
opening_line: Nobody has ever succeeded as Macbeth, and the reason is not far to seek. Instead of growing as the play proceeds, the hero shrinks; complex and many-levelled to begin with, he ends up a cornered thug, lacking even a death scene with which to regain lost stature.

author: Kenneth Tynan
title: Observer
opening_line: “Bloody sparklin’ dialogue,” said a pensive Irishman during the first interval of The Quare Fellow—and sparkle, by any standards, it amazingly did.

author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
title: Astrophysics for People in a Hurry
opening_line: In the beginning, nearly fourteen billion years ago, all the space and all the matter and all the energy of the known universe was contained in a volume less than one-trillionth the size of the period that ends this sentence.

author: Laurel Thatcher Ulrich
title: American Quarterly
opening_line: Cotton Mather called them “The hidden ones.“ They never preached or sat in a deacon’s bench. Nor did they vote or attend Harvard. Neither, because they were virtuous women, did they question God or the magistrates. They prayed secretly, read the Bible through at least once a year, and went to hear the minister preach even when it snowed. Hoping for an eternal crown, they never asked to be remembered on earth. And they haven’t been. Well-behaved women seldom make history.

author: John Updike
title: Assorted Prose
opening_line: Pity the poor bore. He stands among us as a creature formidable and familiar yet in essence unknowable. We can read of the ten infallible signs whereby he may be recognized and of the seven tested methods whereby he may be rebuffed.

author: John Updike
title: Self-Consciousness
opening_line: Had not my twenty-five-year-old daughter undertipped the airline porter in Boston, our luggage might have shown upon the carrousel [sic] in Allentown that April afternoon in 1980, and I would not have spent an evening walking the sidewalks of Shillington, Pennsylvania, searching for the meaning for my existence, as once I had scanned those same sidewalks for lost pennies.

author: Stevie Van Zandt
title: Unrequited Infatuations
opening_line: My first epiphany came at the age of ten, in 1961, in my room at 263 Wilson Avenue, New Monmouth, Middleton, New Jersey, during my fifty-fifth consecutive time listening to “Pretty Little Angel Eyes” by Curtis Lee. That’s what we did in those days.

author: Elizabeth Vargas
title: Between Breaths
opening_line: I don’t know if I was born an alcoholic, but I was definitely born anxious. The alcoholism came to me later in life, after years of drinking to ease stress and worry, and to fend off panic.

author: Gore Vidal
title: The New York Times
opening_line: A satirist is a man profoundly revolted by the society in which he lives. His rage takes the form of wit, ridicule, mockery.

author: Judith Viorst
title: Necessary Losses
opening_line: We begin life with a loss. We are cast from the womb without an apartment, a charge plate, a job or a car.

author: Steve Vogel
title: Reasonable Doubt
opening_line: Like his father and grandfather, Mike Hibbens was a Bloomington, Illinois, policeman. Nothing in the youngest Hibbens’s eleven years as a patrolman (or anything his dad or grandpa had taught him) would prepare him for what he would see the night of November 8, 1983.

author: David Von Drehle
title: The Washington Post
opening_line: Early one August morning during a heat wave in Kansas City, Mo., I stepped outside to fetch the Sunday newspaper—and something stopped me in my tracks.

author: Michael J. Wagner
title: Stumbling Forward
opening_line: Rochester, New York had one more resident on Wednesday, the 9th of November 1938. Exactly ten days earlier, my parents had the proverbial shit scared out of them after listening to H. G. Wells’ “War of the Worlds” broadcast on the radio; a national Halloween deception orchestrated by Orson Wells, and now folk history.

author: Jim Wahlberg
title: The Big Hustle
opening_line: I’d been in fights all my life. I’d been pummeled by the toughest guys you’d ever not want to meet. I’d been beaten up, knocked unconscious, whacked in the head with a crowbar, and thrashed by a prison guard. But far and away the worst gut punch I ever took was when I discovered that my son was on drugs.

author: Dan Wakefield
title: The New York Times Magazine
opening_line: Just before Christmas of 1980, I was sitting in the Sevens, a neighborhood bar on Beacon Hill (don’t all these stories of revelation begin in bars?), when a housepainter named Tony remarked out of the blue that he wanted to find a place to go to mass on Christmas Eve. I didn’t say anything, but a thought came into my mind, as swift and unexpected as it was unfamiliar: I’d like to do that, too.

author: Dan Wakefield
title: Returning
opening_line: One balmy spring morning in Hollywood, a month or so before my forty-eighth birthday, I woke up screaming. I got out of bed, went into the next room, sat down on a couch, and screamed again.

author: David Wallace-Wells
title: The Uninhabitable Earth
opening_line: It is worse, much worse, than you think.

author: Jeannette Walls
title: The Glass Castle
opening_line: I was sitting in a taxi, wondering if I had overdressed for the evening, when I looked out the window and saw Mom rooting through a Dumpster.

author: David Waltner-Toews
title: One Animal Among Many
opening_line: According to some commentators on the Jewish Talmud, God tried creation twenty-six times before this one. All of the early attempts failed. “Let’s hope it works this time,” said the Creator, sending us on our strange, beautiful—and uncertain—journey.

author: David Waltner-Toews
title: On Pandemics
opening_line: Until a few years ago, many scientists had banished words like “threat” and “danger” from our vocabulary. In an attempt to be more rigorously quantitative and less emotional, we began to write about risks. Our response to danger was called “risk management.”

author: Rick Warren
title: The Purpose Driven Life
opening_line: It’s not about you.

author: Booker T. Washington
title: Up From Slavery
opening_line: I was born a slave on a plantation in Franklin County, Virginia. I am not quite sure of the exact place or exact date of my birth, but at any rate I suspect I must have been born somewhere and at some time.

author: Bruce Watson
title: Freedom Summer
opening_line: In the fall of 1963, America was suffused with an unbearable whiteness of being.

author: Bruce Watson
title: American Heritage
opening_line: Comedians yammer on and on, but humorists are a somber bunch.

author: Wallace D. Wattles
title: The Science of Getting Rich
opening_line: Whatever may be said in praise of poverty, the fact remains that it is not possible to live a really complete or successful life unless one is rich.

author: Alan Watts
title: The Wisdom of Insecurity
opening_line: By all outward appearances our life is a spark of light between one eternal darkness and another.

author: Alan Watts
title: The Way of Zen
opening_line: Zen Buddhism is a way and a view of life which does not belong to any of the formal categories of modern Western thought. It is not religion or philosophy; it is not a psychology or a type of science. It is an example of what is known in India and China as a “way of liberation.”

author: Evelyn Waugh
title: A Little Learning
opening_line: Only when one has lost all curiosity about the future has one reached the age to write an autobiography.

author: Gene Weingarten
title: The Detroit Free Press
opening_line: Every day, liquid sewage—three million gallons of it from starting points across Metro Detroit—roars through subterranean channels to a single collecting point five miles down the road from The Renaissance Center, on West Jefferson. Then it hits the fan.

author: Gene Weingarten
title: The Detroit Free Press
opening_line: Yesterday, I hardly knew anything about what an auto mechanic does. Today, I am one.

author: Fay Weldon
title: Auto da Fay
opening_line: I long for a day of judgment when the plot lines of our lives will be neatly tied, and all puzzles explained, and the meaning of events made clear. We take to fiction, I suppose, because no such thing is going to happen….

author: H. G. Wells
title: Certain Personal Matters
opening_line: The art of the essayist is so simple, so entirely free from canons of criticism, and withal so delightful, that one must needs wonder why all men are not essayists. Perhaps people do not know how easy it is. Or perhaps beginners are misled. Rightly taught it may be learnt in a brief ten minutes or so, what art there is in it. And all the rest is as easy as wandering among woodlands on a bright morning in the spring.

author: Mae West
title: Goodness Had Nothing to Do With It
opening_line: A book about one’s life necessarily demands a tremendous amount of recollection and research, and I have never kept a diary. I once told an interviewer that if I ever kept a diary it would have to be written in invisible ink.

author: Chris Whipple
title: Uncharted
opening_line: Joe Biden looked like a dead man walking.

author: Colson Whitehead
title: The Noble Hustle
opening_line: I have a good poker face because I am half dead inside.

author: Paul Whiteman
title: Jazz
opening_line: Jazz came to America three hundred years ago in chains.

author: Ken Wilber
title: Sex, Ecology, Spirituality
opening_line: It is flat-out strange that something—that anything—is happening. There was nothing, then a Big Bang, then here we all are. This is extremely weird.

author: Ken Wilber
title: A Theory of Everything
opening_line: We live in an extraordinary time: all of the world’s cultures, past and present, are to some degree available to us, either in historical records or as living entities. In the history of the planet Earth, this has never happened before.

author: George F. Will
title: The Washington Post
opening_line: A reader demands to know how I contracted the infectious conservatism for which he plans to horsewhip me. So if you have tears, prepare to shed them now as I reveal how my gloomy temperament received its conservative warp from early and prolonged exposure to the Chicago Cubs.

author: Caroline Randall Williams
title: The New York Times
opening_line: I have rape-colored skin.

author: Jill Wine-Banks
title: The Watergate Girl
opening_line: I didn’t think I was nervous, but I could hardly breathe.

author: Jeannette Winterson
title: Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal
opening_line: When my mother was angry with me, which was often, she said, “The Devil led us to the wrong crib.”

author: Robert S. Wistrich
title: A Lethal Obsession
opening_line: Future historians may well regard the past seven decades as a golden age of ideological politics.

author: Esther Wojcicki
title: How to Raise Successful People
opening_line: There are no Nobel Prizes for parenting or education, but there should be.

author: Naomi Wolf
title: The Beauty Myth
opening_line: At last, after a long silence, women took to the streets.

author: Naomi Wolf
title: Vagina
opening_line: Why write a book about the vagina?

author: James Wood
title: How Fiction Works
opening_line: The house of fiction has many windows, but only two or three doors.

author: John Wooden
title: My Personal Best
opening_line: I was raised on oatmeal.

author: Bob Woodward
title: Rage
opening_line: During the Top Secret President’s Daily Brief the afternoon of Tuesday, January 28, 2020, discussion in the Oval Office turned to a mysterious pneumonia-like virus outbreak in China. Public health officials and President Trump himself were telling the public the virus was low-risk for the United States. “This will be the biggest national security threat you face in your presidency,” Robert O’Brien, the national security adviser, told Trump, expressing a jarring, contrarian view as deliberately and as strongly as possible. Trump’s head popped up.

author: Bob Woodward and Robert Costa
title: Peril
opening_line: Two days after the January 6, 2021, violent assault on the United States Capitol by supporters of President Donald Trump, General Mark Milley, the nation’s senior military officer and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, placed an urgent call on a top secret, back-channel line at 7:03 a.m. to his Chinese counterpart, General Li Zuocheng, chief of the Joint Staff of the People’s Liberation Army.

author: Bob Woodward
title: War
opening_line: As rioters stormed the Capitol on January 6, 2021, President Donald Trump watched on television from his private dining room next to the Oval Office.

author: Richard Wright
title: Uncle Tom’s Children
opening_line: My first lesson in how to live as a Negro came when I was quite small.

author: Richard Wright
title: Black Boy
opening_line: One winter morning in the long-ago, four-year-old days of my life I found myself standing before a fireplace, warming my hands over a mound of glowing coals, listening to the wind whistle past the house outside.

author: Kate Zambreno
title: Heroines
opening_line: She was supposed to fuck a god high up on his mountaintop, but she refused. She wouldn’t listen to Apollo’s reasoning. So he cursed her, a life sentence.

author: Kate Zambreno
title: To Write As If Already Dead
opening_line: There comes a moment when you are finally given some space and quiet, maybe an hour, possibly two, the occasional birdsong by an open window, and you must go to that other room and return to the problem you’ve been attempting to unravel.

author: Michelle Zauner
title: Crying in H Mart
opening_line: Ever since my mom died, I cry in H Mart.

author: Hans Zinsser
title: Rats, Lice, and History
opening_line: This book, if it is ever written, and—if written—it finds a publisher, and—if published—anyone reads it, will be recognized with some difficulty as a biography.

author: William Zinsser
title: Spring Training
opening_line: This book was born, though I didn’t know it at the time, seven years ago in Winter Haven, Florida, at the spring training camp of the Boston Red Sox. I was sitting in the grandstand in a sea of codgers, codging the time away.

author: William Zinsser
title: Inventing the Truth
opening_line: This is the age of the memoir. Never have personal narratives gushed so profusely from the American soil as in the closing decade of the twentieth century. Everyone has a story to tell, and everyone is telling it.

author: William Zinsser
title: Writing Places
opening_line: Of all the places where I’ve done my writing, none was more unusual than the office that had a fire pole.

author: Tom Zoellner
title: The National Road: Dispatches from a Changing America
opening_line: A summer afternoon in Kansas: shadows in the grass, and a diagonal slash cut into the earth.

author: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Raymond Obstfeld
title: Becoming Kareem
opening_line: I didn’t realize I was black until third grade.

author: Jane Addams
title: Twenty Years at Hull House
opening_line: On the theory that our genuine impulses may be connected with our childish experiences, that one’s bent may be tracked back to that “No-Man’s Land” where character is formless but nevertheless settling into lines of future development, I begin this record with some impressions of my childhood.

author: James Agee
title: The Partisan Review
opening_line: We are talking now of summer evenings in Knoxville, Tennessee, in the time that I lived there so successfully disguised to myself as a child.

author: Mitch Albom
title: Tuesdays with Morrie
opening_line: The last class of my old professor’s life took place once a week in his house, by a window in the study where he could watch a small hibiscus plant shed its pink leaves. The class met on Tuesdays. It began after breakfast. The subject was The Meaning of Life. It was taught from experience.

author: Madeleine Albright
title: Madam Secretary
opening_line: I didn’t want it to end.

author: Madeleine Albright
title: Prague Winter
opening_line: I was fifty-nine when I began serving as U.S. secretary of state. I thought by then that I knew all there was to know about my past, who “my people” were, and the history of my native land. I was sure enough that I did not feel a need to ask questions. Others might be insecure about their identities; I was not and never had been. I knew. Only I didn’t.

author: Woody Allen
title: Apropos of Nothing
opening_line: Like Holden, I don't feel like going into all that David Copperfield kind of crap, although in my case, a little about my parents you may find more interesting than reading about me.

author: Isabel Allende
title: Paula: A Memoir
opening_line: Listen, Paula, I am going to tell you a story, so that when you wake up you will not feel so lost.

author: Isabel Allende
title: Aphrodite
opening_line: I repent of my diets, the delicious dishes rejected out of vanity, as much as I lament the opportunities for making love that I let go by because of pressing tasks or puritanical virtue.

author: Isabel Allende
title: My Invented Country
opening_line: Let’s begin at the beginning, with Chile, that remote land that few people can locate on the map because it’s as far as you can go without falling off the planet.

author: Isabel Allende
title: The Sum of Our Days
opening_line: There is no lack of drama in my life. I have more than enough three-ring-circus material for writing, but even so, I always approach the seventh of January with trembling. Last night I couldn’t sleep.

author: Isabel Allende
title: The Soul of a Woman
opening_line: When I say that I was a feminist in kindergarten, even before the concept was known in my family, I am not exaggerating.

author: Gregg Allmann (with Alan Light)
title: My Cross to Bear
opening_line: I was sitting up talking, and I just kind of nodded off. But I didn’t nod off: I was Code Blue. I was bleeding inside, and I was drowning in blood.

author: Cleveland Amory
title: The Cat and the Curmudgeon
opening_line: “Some cats,” Shakespeare said, “are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon ’em.”

author: Roger Angell
title: Let Me Finish
opening_line: Most of the true stories in this book were written in the last three years and came as a surprise to me, the author. I’d not planned a memoir, if that’s what this is, and never owned a diary or made notes about the passage of the days.

author: Roger Angell
title: The New Yorker
opening_line: Check me out. The top two knuckles of my left hand look as if I’d been worked over by the K.G.B. No, it’s more as if I’d been a catcher for the Hall of Fame pitcher Candy Cummings, the inventor of the curveball, who retired from the game in 1877. To put this another way, if I pointed that hand at you like a pistol and fired at your nose, the bullet would nail you in the left knee. Arthritis.

author: Maya Angelou
title: Letter to My Daughter
opening_line: Dear Daughter, This letter has taken an extraordinary time getting itself together. I have all along known that I wanted to tell you directly of some lessons I have learned and under what conditions I have learned them.

author: Karen Armstrong
title: Through the Narrow Gate
opening_line: It was 14 September 1962, the most important day of my life. On the station platform my parents and my sister, Lindsey, were clustered together in a sad little knot, taking their last look at me. I was seventeen years old and was leaving them forever to become a nun.

author: Mary Kay Ash
title: Mary Kay
opening_line: There are four kinds of people in this world: I knew from a very early age that I wanted to be first on that list.

author: Isaac Asimov
title: The Roving Mind
opening_line: I have the roving mind of the title, as well as an easy touch at the typewriter (or word-processor), and editors have found that out.

author: Isaac Asimov
title: Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction
opening_line: I have written three hundred ninety-nine essays for Fantasy & Science Fiction. The essays were written with enormous pleasure, for I have always been allowed to say what I wanted to say. It was with horror that I discovered I could not manage a four hundredth essay.

author: Isaac Asimov
title: I, Asimov
opening_line: In 1977, I wrote my autobiography. Since I was dealing with my favorite subject, I wrote at length and I ended with 640,000 words.

author: Paul Auster
title: Hand to Mouth
opening_line: In my late twenties and early thirties, I went through a period of several years when everything I touched turned to failure.

author: Belinda Austin
title: A House of Sticks
opening_line: I never danced with my father but in his shed, I danced with his sawdust swirling around my bone-thin ankles. At the old age of 11, I sound morbid but Daddy is not dead, he has abandoned us as he did his other four kids. Joe never divorced his legal wife, making my siblings and me bastards, and our mother a fool. Daddy is a bigamist and my parent’s marriage is a misdemeanor—but the only crime Joe ever committed was leaving me.

author: Joan Baez
title: And a Voice to Sing With
opening_line: I was born gifted. I can speak of my gifts with little or no modesty, but with tremendous gratitude, precisely because they are gifts, and not things which I created, or actions about which I might be proud.

author: Russell Baker
title: Growing Up
opening_line: At the age of eighty my mother had her last bad fall, and after that her mind wandered free through time. Some days she went to weddings and funerals that had taken place half a century earlier. On others she presided over family dinners cooked on Sunday afternoon for children who were now gray with age. Through all this she lay in bed but moved across time, traveling among the dead decades with a speed and ease beyond the gift of physical science.

author: Clare Balding
title: My Animals and Other Family
opening_line: The first face I can remember seeing was Candy’s. She was my protector and my companion, my nanny and my friend. A strong, snuffling, steady presence.

author: James Baldwin
title: Notes of a Native Son
opening_line: I was born in Harlem thirty-one years ago. I began plotting novels at about the time I learned to read.

author: Maiwand Banayee
title: Delusions of Paradise
opening_line: When I was 16, I wanted to become a suicide bomber for the Taliban in Afghanistan.

author: Lionel Barrymore
title: We Barrymores
opening_line: In the watches of the night when old thoughts come to roost, some of them slapping their thighs and roaring, others hiding their faces, two particularly baffling notions often appear to beleaguer me. The first, common to most men, involves vast regrets and dilemmas about what I might have been or should have been.

author: Jean-François Beauchemin
title: Archives of Joy
opening_line: Every other day since the start of summer, and old deer with a grizzled gray snout has been wandering into my garden to dream away some of what little time he has left.

author: W. Kamau Bell
title: Vanity Fair
opening_line: I am afraid of the cops. Absolutely petrified of the cops. Now understand, I’ve never been arrested or held for questioning. I’ve never been told that I “fit the description.” But that doesn’t change a thing. I am afraid of cops the way that spiders are afraid of boots. You’re walking along, minding your own business, and SQUISH! You are dead.

author: Greg Bellow
title: Saul Bellow’s Heart
opening_line: On a visit to Chicago when I was eight, I witnessed a terrible argument, in Yiddish, between my father and grandfather. Driving away from his father’s house, Saul started to cry so bitterly he had to pull off the road. After a few minutes, he excused his lapse of self-control by saying, “It’s okay for grown-ups to cry.“ I knew his heart was breaking. I knew because of the bond between my father’s tender heart and mine.

author: Elizabeth Berg
title: I’ll Be Seeing You
opening_line: I am seventy years old. I am astonished to be writing this, as doubtful of the truth of it as if I had written, “I am a peacock.“

author: Candice Bergen
title: A Fine Romance
opening_line: It was midway through October 1985, as I waddled in a huge plaid tent dress through the ground floor of Bergdorf’s. I’d put on almost fifty pounds since becoming pregnant. A woman kept peering at me, looking away, looking back. Finally she approached. “You know, you have Candice Bergen’s face.“ “But not her body,“ I said.

author: Joe Biden
title: Promises to Keep
opening_line: Joe Impedimenta, my classmates hung that nickname on me our first semester of high school when we were doing two periods of Latin a day. It was one of the first big words we learned. Impedimenta—the baggage that impedes one’s progress.

author: Karen Blixen
title: Out of Africa
opening_line: I had a farm in Africa, at the foot of the Ngong Hills.

author: Kate Block
title: Spinster
opening_line: Whom to marry, and when it will happen—these two questions define every woman’s existence, regardless of where she was raised or what religion she does or doesn’t practice. She may grow up to love women instead of men, or to decide she simply doesn’t believe in marriage. No matter. These dual contingencies govern her until they’re answered, even if the answers are nobody and never.

author: Lawrence Block
title: The Crime of Our Lives
opening_line: It was in the eleventh grade that I knew I would be a writer. The conviction grew out of two awarenesses that dawned at about the same time.

author: Charles M. Blow
title: Fire Shut Up in My Bones
opening_line: Tears flowed out of me from a walled-off place, from another time, from a little boy who couldn’t cry. I had held on to the hurt and shame and doubt for so long, balling it up in the pit of me, that I never thought it would come out, or that it could. I certainly didn’t think it would come out like this. Not in a flash. But there it was. Some of my tears streamed over the arc of my cheeks and off the rim of my jaw. Others rounded the corners of my nose and puddled in the crease of my lips. I didn’t wipe them. I wore them. I looked over at the rusting pistol on the passenger seat. It was a .22 with a long black barrel and a wooden grip.

author: Jim Bouton
title: Ball Four
opening_line: Fall 1968 I’m 30 years old and I have these dreams.

author: Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Cleavage
opening_line: I was born in 1958, on June 22nd, the second day of summer. It was also the birthday of Kris Kristofferson and Meryl Streep, both of whom I later resembled, although not at the same time.

author: Peg Bracken
title: A Window Over the Sink
opening_line: You may have noticed, as I have, that if you ever find yourself declaring unequivocally that you will never do some one particular thing, chances are good that this is precisely what you will one day find yourself doing.

author: James Bradley
title: Flags of Our Fathers
opening_line: In the spring of 1998, six boys called to me from half a century ago on a distant mountain and I went there.

author: Laurel Braitman
title: What Looks Like Bravery
opening_line: Santa Paula, California, September 1994 It was a warm Saturday afternoon and the Santa Ana winds ruffled the tops of the avocado trees. I was at home with two good friends, all of us sixteen years old, draped like hormonal Dalí clocks over the living room furniture while we watched The Bodyguard on VHS and painted our nails.

author: Mel Brooks
title: All About Me!
opening_line: The writing of this book serves as a kind of confession. You, the readers will be my confidants. I’m going to tell you all my secrets. Things I’ve never told anybody. Things I don’t want anybody to know! I don’t want you to breathe a word of what you find out in this book. Keep everything under your hat! Wait a minute, wait a minute…that might not work. I’m not in a confessional booth, and a lot of you are probably not priests. This is a book! And this book needs to sell!

author: Rita Mae Brown
title: Rita Will
opening_line: My mother was mucking stalls at Hanover Shoe Farm outside of Hanover, Pennsylvania, within a shout of the Mason-Dixon line, when her water broke. Had the hospital not been nearby, I would have been born in a manger.

author: Susan Brownmiller
title: In Our Time
opening_line: I was not there at the beginning. Few people were. And although I can speak with confidence of a beginning, of certain documented rebellions sparked by a handful of visionaries with stubborn courage, there were antecedents to those rebellions, and antecedents to the antecedents.

author: Frank Bruni
title: The Beauty of Dusk
opening_line: They say that death comes like a thief in the night. Lesser vandals have the same MO. The affliction that stole my vision, or at least a big chuck of it, did so as I slept. I went to bed seeing the world one way. I woke up seeing it another.

author: Art Buchwald
title: Too Soon to Say Goodbye
opening_line: What started out the worst of times ended up the best of times. The big news of 2006 is that I’m still alive. After being in the hospice waiting to die, I said, “To hell with it, I’m going to write a book.”

author: Christopher Buckley
title: Losing Mum and Pup: A Memoir
opening_line: I’m not sure how this book will turn out. I mostly write novels, and I’ve found, having written half a dozen, that if you’re lucky, the ending turns out a surprise and you wind up with something you hadn’t anticipated in the outline. I suppose it’s a process of outsmarting yourself (not especially hard in my case).

author: William F. Buckley, Jr.
title: Nearer, My God: An Autobiography of Faith
opening_line: It was during the summer of 1938 that we were given the dreadful news.

author: Frederick Buechner
title: Telling Secrets
opening_line: One November morning in 1936 when I was ten years old, my father got up early, put on a pair of gray slacks and a maroon sweater, opened the door to look in briefly on my younger brother and me, who were playing a game in our room, and then went down into the garage where he turned on the engine of the family Chevy and sat down on the running board to wait for the exhaust to kill him.

author: Jimmy Buffett
title: A Pirate Looks at Fifty
opening_line: When I was growing up in Alabama, the beginning of the new school year was a bad time. It meant the end of summer, which is my season. I packed away my shorts and t-shirts, put on socks, shoes, and my parochial-school uniform, and dragged my ass to class.

author: George Burns
title: Gracie
opening_line: For forty years my act consisted of one joke. And then she died.

author: Michael Caine
title: What’s It All About?
opening_line: The first time I was in the United States, when I had just made Alfie, I was sitting on my own in the lobby of the Beverly Hills Hotel and heard the sound of a helicopter landing in the gardens opposite. This, the porter told me, was strictly illegal. He and I stood at the door to see who was so flagrantly flouting the law—presumably the President, of the United States or at least of the Beverly Hills Hotel. Across Sunset Boulevard, out of a swirling sun-flecked cloud of dust, six foot four and in full cowboy get-up, strode the unmistakable figure of John Wayne.

author: Michael Caine
title: The Elephant to Hollywood
opening_line: Well, it’s a long way from London’s Elephant and Castle to Hollywood. And the shortest distance between two points is not always a straight line—as my story is going to prove. But then I’ve never been known for doing things the easy way. I wouldn’t have minded easy, but things just never worked out quite like that. In fact—although I couldn’t have known it at the time—they worked out a whole lot better.

author: Ilia Calderón
title: My Time To Speak
opening_line: All my attention was focused on his face. It’s what I remember most clearly more than two years after our encounter. That face that had raged red as soon as he saw me, and continued angry, indignant. His nostrils flared with his agitated breathing, which he unsuccessfully attempted to control. He responded quickly, hot, like a lit fuse, not letting anyone else talk. And then, suddenly, I heard it from his own lips, “We’re going to burn you out.”

author: Frank Capra
title: The Name Above the Title
opening_line: I hated being poor. Hated being a peasant. Hated being a scrounging newskid trapped in the sleazy Sicilian ghetto of Los Angeles. My family couldn’t read or write. I wanted out. A quick out. I looked for a device, a handle, a pole to catapult myself across the tracks from my scurvy habitat of nobodies to the affluent world of somebodies.

author: Mariah Carey
title: The Meaning of Mariah Carey
opening_line: My intention was to keep her safe, but perhaps I have only succeeded in keeping her prisoner.

author: Rubin Carter
title: The Sixteenth Round
opening_line: RUBIN, my Christian name, comes from the Book of Genesis, Chapter 29, verse 32 of the Holy Scriptures. Other than both of us being black, that’s about the only thing the Bible and I ever had in common.

author: Bennett Cerf
title: At Random
opening_line: I am a rather unusual specimen in that not only I but all four of my grandparents and both of my parents were born on the island of Manhattan.

author: Charles Chaplain
title: Charlie Chaplin’s Own Story
opening_line: Life itself is a comedy—a slap-stick comedy at that. It is always hitting you over the head with the unexpected.

author: Liz Cheney
title: Oath and Honor
opening_line: This is the story of the moment when American democracy began to unravel.

author: Terri Cheney
title: Manic
opening_line: If you come with me on this journey, I think a word of warning is in order: manic depression is not a safe ride.

author: Terri Cheney
title: Modern Madness
opening_line: I was sitting next to Michael Jackson, admiring his feet.

author: G. K. Chesterton
title: The Autobiography of G. K. Chesterton
opening_line: Bowing down in blind credulity, as is my custom, before mere authority and the tradition of the elders, superstitiously swallowing a story I could not test at the time by experiment or private judgment, I am firmly of the opinion that I was born on the 29th of May, 1874, on Campden Hill, Kensington.

author: Shirley Chisholm
title: Unbought and Unbossed
opening_line: There are 435 members of the House of Representatives and 417 are white males. Ten of the others are women and nine are black. I belong to both of these minorities, which makes it add up right.

author: Agatha Christie
title: Agatha Christie
opening_line: One of the luckiest things that can happen to you in life is, I think, to have a happy childhood. I had a very happy childhood.

author: Connie Chung
title: Connie
opening_line: I didn’t start out wanting to be a guy.

author: Hillary Rodham Clinton
title: What Happened
opening_line: Deep breath. Feel the air in my lungs. This is the right thing to do. The country needs to see that our democracy still works, no matter how painful this is. Breathe out. Scream later.

author: Jacqueline Cochran
title: The Stars at Noon
opening_line: I am a refugee from Sawdust Road, which is located in the South close by Tobacco Road of theater and movie fame.

author: Judy Collins
title: Sweet Judy Blue Eyes
opening_line: It’s a Sunday night, and I am traveling from Hartford to New York City, heading in from a show. Rain pours down, and the driver of my sedan is battling the storm like a captain of a schooner in white waves. Thoughts of my life flow like the water around us: years of life, love and anger, rage and hope; the songs I have sung; the men and women I have loved.

author: Blayney Colmore
title: I Reserve the Right to be Terrified
opening_line: The road was steep. But it leveled off at the bottom, so you got a nice glide before the next hill. We’d ridden that road a lot, so we let the bikes run. Last I looked at the speedometer it read between 30 and 35 miles per hour. Exhilarating. Conrad and his daughter Karen were much more experienced and stronger bikers than I was. I followed them down the hill. They both skillfully avoided the board in the road. I never saw it. He told me later that he saw me launch from my bike like a rocket. “You must have gone 20 feet in the air before you landed.” When Karen saw me lying motionless on the road, she said, “Oh God, Dad, I think he’s dead.”

author: Pat Conroy
title: My Losing Season
opening_line: I was born to be a point guard, but not a very good one.

author: Pat Conroy
title: A Lowcountry Heart: Reflections on a Writing Life
opening_line: March 26, 2014 I’ve come to that point in my life when my memories seem as important as the life I’m now leading.

author: Kelly Corrigan
title: The Middle Place
opening_line: The thing you need to know about me is that I am George Corrigan’s daughter, his only daughter. You may have met him, in which case just skip this part. If you haven’t, I’ll do what I can to describe him, but really, you should try to meet him.

author: Kelly Corrigan
title: Glitter and Glue
opening_line: When I was growing up, my mom was guided by the strong belief that to befriend me was to deny me the one thing a kid really needed to survive childhood: a mother.

author: Maureen Corrigan
title: Leave Me Alone, I’m Reading
opening_line: It’s not that I don’t like people. It’s just that when I’m in the company of others—even my nearest and dearest—there always comes a moment when I’d rather be reading a book.

author: Norman Cousins
title: Anatomy of an Illness
opening_line: This book is about a serious illness that occurred in 1964. I was reluctant to write about it for many years because I was fearful of creating false hopes in others who were similarly afflicted. Moreover, I knew that a single case has small standing in the annals of medical research, having little more than “anecdotal” or “testimonial” value.

author: Noël Coward
title: Present Indicative
opening_line: I was photographed naked on a cushion very early in life, an insane, toothless smile slitting my face and pleats of fat overlapping me like an ill-fitting overcoat.

author: Harry Crews
title: A Childhood
opening_line: My first memory is of a time ten years before I was born, and the memory takes place where I have never been and involves my daddy whom I never knew.

author: Billy Crystal
title: Still Foolin’ ‘Em
opening_line: March 14, 2013, my sixty-fifth birthday. I got up that morning, padded over to the bathroom, threw some water on my face, looked in the mirror, and my uncle Al was staring back at me. My scream brought Janice, my wife of forty-two years, running in. I kept yelling, “HOLY SHIT! What the fuck happened to me?” Somehow, overnight, it seemed I had turned from a hip, cool baby boomer into a Diane Arbus photograph.

author: Salvador Dalí
title: The Secret Life of Salvador Dalí
opening_line: At the age of six I wanted to be a cook. At seven I wanted to be Napoleon. And my ambition has been growing steadily ever since.

author: Salvador Dalí
title: Diary of a Genius
opening_line: Ever since the French Revolution there has been growing up a vicious, cretinizing tendency to consider a genius as a human being more or less the same in every respect (apart from his work) as ordinary mortals. This is false.

author: Richard Henry Dana, Jr.
title: Two Years Before the Mast
opening_line: The fourteenth of August was the day fixed upon for the sailing of the brig Pilgrim, on her voyage from Boston, round Cape Horn, to the Western coast of North America.

author: Patti Davis
title: The New York Times
opening_line: During the early stages of my father’s Alzheimer’s, when he still had lucid moments, I apologized to him for writing an autobiography many years earlier in which I flung open the gates of our troubled family life. He was already talking less at that point, but his eyes told me he understood.

author: Sammy Davis, Jr.
title: Yes I Can
opening_line: They liked me. The audience was leaning in to me, nodding, approving, catching every move I was making, and as I finished with “Birth of the Blues” their applause was like a kiss on the lips.

author: Richard Dawkins
title: Unweaving the Rainbow
opening_line: We are going to die, and that makes us the lucky ones.

author: Simone de Beauvoir
title: The Autobiography of Simone de Beauvoir
opening_line: Young women have an acute sense of what should and should not be done when one is no longer young. “I don’t understand,” they say, “how a woman over forty can bleach her hair; how she can make an exhibition of herself in a bikini; how she can flirt with men. The day I’m her age…” [ellipsis in original]

author: Belle de Jour
title: The Intimate Adventures of a London Call Girl
opening_line: The first thing you should know is that I’m a whore.

author: Belle de Jour
title: The Further Adventures of a London Call Girl
opening_line: “What I want, what I really want…this probably sounds silly…is to please you.“ The client was fiftyish, dressed office-casual. Oh great, I thought, another half-hour of earnest licking from a man whose wife no doubt thinks her body stops at the waist. “That’s a gorgeous idea,” I purred.

author: Belle de Jour
title: Belle de Jour’s Guide to Men
opening_line: You might be wondering what, exactly, a prostitute might have to say about men and relationships… [ellipsis in original] Let’s put it this way: I have met men. Loads of men. Men of every conceivable shape, size, and type. In my work as a call girl, I have seen them at their most cocksure and at their most vulnerable. And if this experience has taught me anything at all, it is that this odd and inscrutable species we call Man is often libelously misrepresented in the female press.

author: John Denver
title: Take Me Home
opening_line: They met in Tulsa. Dad was a ploughboy from western Oklahoma; Mom was a hometown girl. He was in the Army Air Corps, studying the mechanics of flight at the Spartan School of Aeronautics, and she had been first-prize winner in a jitterbug contest the year before. It was 1942: She was just turning eighteen, a high-school senior; and he was twenty-one.

author: William Deresiewicz
title: A Jane Austen Education
opening_line: I was twenty-six, and about as dumb, in all human things, as any twenty-six-year-old has a right to be, when I met the woman who would change my life. That she’d been dead for a couple of hundred years made not the slightest difference whatsoever.

author: Bernadette Devlin
title: The Price of My Soul
opening_line: The Price of My Soul is not a work of art, an autobiography, or a political manifesto. Readers who expect one or other of these things will no doubt class it as a failure. Let them. I’m not basically concerned with its success, financial or literary.

author: Rachel Silber Devlin
title: Snapshots of My Father, John Silber
opening_line: My mother would be horrified by this book.

author: Joan Didion
title: The White Album
opening_line: We tell ourselves stories in order to live.

author: Joan Didion
title: The Year of Magical Thinking
opening_line: Life changes fast. Life changes in the instant. You sit down to dinner and life as you know it ends. The question of self-pity. Those were the first words I wrote after it happened.

author: Annie Dillard
title: The Writing Life
opening_line: When you write, you lay out a line of words. The line of words is a miner’s pick, a woodcarver’s gouge, a surgeon’s probe. You wield it, and it digs a path you follow.

author: Michael Dirda
title: An Open Book
opening_line: Daydreaming is my only hobby.

author: Caitlin Doughty
title: Smoke Gets in Your Eyes
opening_line: A girl always remembers the first corpse she shaves.

author: Frederick Douglass
title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, An American Slave
opening_line: I was born in Tuckahoe, near Hillsborough, and about twelve miles from Easton, in Talbot County, Maryland. I have no accurate knowledge of my age, never having seen any authentic record containing it.

author: Peter F. Drucker
title: Adventures of a Bystander
opening_line: Bystanders have no history of their own. They are on the stage but are not part of the action. They are not even audience. The fortunes of the play and of every actor in it depend on the audience whereas the reaction of the bystander has no effect except on himself.

author: Daphne du Maurier
title: Myself When Young
opening_line: All autobiography is self-indulgent.

author: Meghan, Duchess of Sessex (formerly Meghan Markle)
title: The New York Times
opening_line: It was a July morning that began as ordinarily as any other day: Make breakfast. Feed the dogs. Take vitamins. Find that missing sock. Pick up the rogue crayon that rolled under the table. Throw my hair in a ponytail before getting my son from his crib. After changing his diaper, I felt a sharp cramp. I dropped to the floor with him in my arms, humming a lullaby to keep us both calm, the cheerful tune a stark contrast to my sense that something was not right. I knew, as I clutched my firstborn child, that I was losing my second.

author: Dominick Dunne
title: Justice
opening_line: I didn’t start writing until I was fifty years old although an observer’s eye had been observing for forty of those fifty years, while trying out different areas of occupation.

author: Roger Ebert
title: Life Itself
opening_line: I was born inside the movie of my life.

author: Les Edgerton
title: Adrenaline Junkie
opening_line: When I was eleven, my father walked into his bedroom and caught me stuffing several of the coins he collected into my pockets.

author: Albert Einstein
title: Saturday Review of Literature
opening_line: Here I sit in order to write, at the age of sixty-seven, something like my own obituary. I am doing this because I believe it is a good thing to show those who are striving alongside us how one’s own striving and searching appear to one in retrospect.

author: Linda Ellerbee
title: “And So It Goes”
opening_line: I wouldn’t mind writing one of those books about the good old days—how I went out into the land and committed journalism, covering the important stories, every one of them, everywhere, better than anyone—but the thing about lying is that unless you’re a political candidate or a network vice president, you’ve got to set yourself some limits and hold fast.

author: Linda Ellerbee
title: Move On: Adventures in the Real World
opening_line: I packed up his comic books, sold off the bunk beds, gave away the last Star Wars sheet and threw out the beanbag chair that had bled to death in 1975. I tore down the six MASH posters super-glued to the wall between his room and mine.

author: Linda Ellerbee
title: Take Big Bites
opening_line: I’m not crazy about Florence except for the pig museum. If precisely speaking, it’s not a museum, that’s only because some fool in the Italian government doesn’t recognize a national treasure when he sees one.

author: Annie Ernaux
title: Shame
opening_line: My father tried to kill my mother one Sunday in June, in the early afternoon.

author: Marie Estorge
title: Then There Was Larry
opening_line: We all have secrets. In our lives, we’ve done or heard or thought things that we’ve chosen not to share with our friends, family, community, and colleagues.

author: Anne Fadiman
title: The Wine Lover’s Daughter
opening_line: My father was a lousy driver and a two-finger typist, but he could open a wine bottle as deftly as any swain ever undressed his lover.

author: Susan Faludi
title: In the Darkroom
opening_line: In the summer of 2004 I set out to investigate someone I scarcely knew, my father.

author: Edna Ferber
title: A Peculiar Treasure
opening_line: When I was a small girl living in Appleton, Wisconsin, I often was sent with a quart tin pail to the creamery which was three blocks away on the wrong side of the railroad tracks. The Ferber family, I hastily and grandly add, lived on the right side of the tracks. Any native Middle West American will get the social significance (and the revolting snobbery) of that statement.

author: Edna Ferber
title: A Kind of Magic
opening_line: To be alive is a fine thing. It is the finest thing in the world, though hazardous.

author: Harvey Fierstein
title: I Was Better Last Night
opening_line: Philomena Marano got the role of the Evil Witch and I was cast as the King. The King? Who wants to be the King? Sure, he gets a crown and a cape, but the Witch gets green skin, red lips, and long black fingernails. I wanted green skin, red lips, and long black nails! Second grade was not working out the way I’d hoped.

author: Isaac Fitzgerald
title: Dirtbag, Massachusetts
opening_line: My parents were married when they had me, just to different people.

author: Dionne Ford
title: Go Back and Get It
opening_line: If you are going to look for your enslaved ancestors, you will have to look for the people who enslaved them.

author: Frederick Forsyth
title: The Outsider
opening_line: We all make mistakes, but starting the Third World War would have been a rather large one.

author: Gene Fowler
title: Skyline
opening_line: The building of castles in the air made architects of us all.

author: Michael J. Fox
title: Lucky Man
opening_line: Gainesville, Florida—November 1990 I woke up to find the message in my left hand. It had me trembling. It wasn’t a fax, telegram, memo, or the usual sort of missive bringing disturbing news. In fact, my hand held nothing at all. The trembling was the message.

author: Anne Frank
title: The Diary of Anne Frank
opening_line: June 12, 1942 I hope I will be able to confide everything to you, as I have never been able to confide in anyone, and I hope you will be a great source of comfort and support.

author: Viktor E. Frankl
title: Man’s Search for Meaning
opening_line: This book does not claim to be an account of facts and events but of personal experiences, experiences which millions of prisoners have suffered time and time again. It is the inside story of a concentration camp, told by one of its survivors.

author: Helen Fremont
title: The Escape Artist
opening_line: Sisters are a setup. Shot from the same cannon, you’re sent on a blind date for the rest of your lives.

author: Kinky Friedman
title: Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die
opening_line: In April 1933, Willie’s mother, Myrle, gave birth to him in a manger somewhere along the old highway between Waco and Dallas.

author: Dorothy Fuldheim
title: A Thousand Friends
opening_line: This is a youth-oriented society, and the joke is on them because youth is a disease from which we all recover.

author: Paul Fussell
title: Doing Battle
opening_line: Late in the afternoon of March 15, 1945, in a small woods in southeastern, France, Boy Fussell, aged twenty, was ill treated by members of the German Wehrmacht. His attackers have never been identified and brought to justice. How a young person was damaged this way and what happened as a result is the subject of this book.

author: Patric Gagne
title: Sociopath
opening_line: Whenever I ask my mother if she remembers the time in second grade when I stabbed a kid in the head with a pencil, her answer is the same: “Vaguely.”

author: Mohandas K Gandhi
title: An Autobiography
opening_line: Four or five years ago, at the insistence of some of my nearest co-workers, I agreed to write my autobiography. I made the start, but scarcely had I turned over the first sheet when riots broke out in Bombay and the work remained at a standstill. Then followed a series of events which culminated in my imprisonment….

author: David Gerrold
title: Worlds of Wonder
opening_line: The very best writing instructor I ever had was an incompetent. A terminal alcoholic who could barely find the classroom each day, he was a bleary-eyed, red-nosed, overstuffed, walking elbow-wrinkle of a human being. Whatever writing ability he’d ever had, he’d long since drowned it, and the corpse was a layer of dried sediment at the bottom of a bottle. He didn’t like me either.

author: Elizabeth Gilbert
title: Esquire
opening_line: I was not the prettiest bartender at the Coyote Ugly Saloon. In my opinion, that would have been Caroline. I was partial to Caroline, though, because she had been so nice to me when I began working here. She was very pretty and also very funny. When I asked Caroline how she’d gotten her first bartender job, she cupped her breasts and said simply, “These.”

author: Elizabeth Gilbert
title: Eat, Pray, Love
opening_line: I wish Giovanni would kiss me.

author: William Goldman
title: Which Lie Did I Tell
